Airy white head disappears quick.
Dark orange to orange brown color.
Smell malts, hops and spices.
Taste lots of malts and hint of hops, sweets and some slight hints of fruit and spices.
Bit bitter and sweet and little bit spicy, but nothing really spectacular.
Expected more from this one.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
The flavor is very malty. I get some carmel,toffee. It has a thick full feel. But it does feel a little unbalanced. The malt seems to steal the show.

I am getting some strong carmel from the aroma and some light floral notes

Pours a chill hazed light amber color with a decent sized white head.

It finishes with a citrus hop bitterness. If this brew was a bit better balanced it would be awesome. I mean its still a good time but that would take it to the next level. How can you not like Rogue
Really disappointed with this. Too much Crystal and boardering on Vienna like. Little stale cardboard too. Was looking forward to it....shame

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2013 Re-rated a draft.  Malty aroma, clear amber, head fades quickly.  Sweet malt mixed well with hop bitterness, so it isnt too sweet or too bitter.  Much better on draft than in a bottle (which didnt have any of the malty sweetness).

12oz bottle (White Crane Bitter Ale) in a shaker.  Pours deep, opaque amber with a thick lingering head.  Aroma of malts, roasted, hints of nuts, and a little toffee.  Flavor mainly of the malts, as described in the aroma, with a light hop crispness at the end.  Full bodied, almost thick.  A pretty good beer.

A - Citrus with a bit of caramel
A -Full copper color with last cream colored head...a touch hazy
T - Light sourness with a mix of bitter and alcohol finish...Im a touch disappointed
P - Full bodied with light soft carbonation
O - I was ready for something great, but was left feeling unsatisfied

Poured a nice orange/brown, with a thin white head. Aroma is malty, but with hints of hops, fruits, and caramel. Flavor is malty, bitter, and small hints of flowers, as well as some fruity notes. Didnt get the sense of this being a bock beer, but good none the less.
Bottle. Pours a hazy amber color with tan head with good lacing. Aroma of toasted malt.  Taste of sweet toasted malt.

Bomber. Too much crystal malt sweetness. Tone that back a lilttle bit and it would be perfectly balanced. Hops are right. Alcohol comes through more than youd expect-but in a kinda good way, except it would make it difficult to have more than one.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2011 Great toasted orange color to this one, no head. I get a kind of sweet aroma, maybe caramel. Well balanced beer, alcohol is a little too noticable. Dont eat food with this, could hurt the palate. Good beer.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2014 33cl bottle from a friend.
Never met a Rogue beer I didnt like and this is no exception!  Nice amber colour and a great tasting beer
draught and bottle. pours a thick golden colour. heavy on the malt, flavours of caramel, chocolate, alcohol, and toffee. delicious beer, preferred it out of the bottle though.

On tap @ Northern Pacific Coffee Company. Pours a clear orange gold with a short head leaving minimal lace. Chewy, hearty maltiness with honey, tea, cocoa and  orange notes (but its not at all sweet like this would suggest). Hops are present but the malt predominates, as it should in a Maibock. Slight metallic flavor in both of the pints I had @ NPCC. Pairs well with meats, German and Italian foods.
12oz bottle poured cloudy amber medium head.  malty with a little hop back,  overall a good ale

Pours a cloudy copper with a nice creamy off white head. Nose is malty caramel, yeast, floral hops. Taste is sweet malts, earthy floral hops, with some bready notes. Palate is full body, good carbonation. Finish is sweet caramel malts balanced very well with earthy bitter hops. A very nice smooth and flavorful brew.

22 oz Bottle -- Pours burnt orange with a splotchy off-white head.  Aromas of roasted malt, honey, caramel, and yeast.  Really great toasty malt character.  Fairly dry palate with a bitter finish.  Feels a little thin.

Beautiful deep reddish brown color, great aroma, not too complex but perfectly balanced and thats right, a fuckin 10 for taste as this beer is one of the best I have ever had - In a perfect world I would piss this stuff so I could have a never ending pint of it!  I love to hit my favorite neighborhood pub, order up a dozen wings and chased it down with a few pints of this stuff.  Its the perfect way to spend a spring, summer, winter or fall afternoon.

On tap, pours a light amber color with a thin white head, the aroma is fruity with a nice kick of hops, the flavor has a great balance of the malt and bittering hops, finishes very hoppy and flavorful, very good.

Clear amber pour releases subtle floral hop and somewhat indistinct fruit aromas.  The surprisingly thin body was sweet and simultaneously hoppy and malty (caramel, to be exact), but the overall intensity was low and the finish short.  Maybe I expected too much from this beer but it was underwhelming.  I may try it again in a different setting.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 On tap in San Diego. Cant define the smell - fresh, sweet perhaps. Cloudy red-brown with almost no head. Taste is surprisingly refreshing. Nice caramels and sugars dominate the flavor. Slight Christmas spice behind malts. Smooth. No lingering aftertaste.

full body, medium bitterness, 
tastes great, lived up to expectations, enjoyable!

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a medium amber color with orange highlights and a 2-3 finger foamy off-white head. Fairly decent lacing.

Smell: Sweet aroma of malt and caramel with just a hint of floral hops.

Taste: Sweet toasted malt up front followed by caramel and a hint of alcohol in the middle then floral and citrus hops at the finish. Aftertaste is mostly hoppy bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a fairly high amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. You could knock back a few of these before you realize the alcohol is sneaking up on you.

Overall: Very solid beer overall, although Im not sure its really a Maibock. You could do a lot worse than this.

"Deep honey in color with a malty aroma and a rich hearty flavor." Well, thats right: It goes down easy as kiss-my-hand and the roasty, toasty flavor held true through a pint and a half. This is a much reviewed beer - and greatly appreciated. All I can really do is say that it continues to be a pleasing beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours a beautiful deep amber, hazy orangey brown. Light, white one-finger head. Roasty and caramel malt nose. Medium-light body that is creamy and smooth, almost fluffy in the mouth. Sweet malts dominate the taste but it has a nice hop balance that opens up to nice floral citrus note. Two thumbs up- definitely want to try this on tap again and try the double too.

12 oz bottle from the LCBO, served in an English pint glass. Pours clear amber with a frothy off-white head. The head slowly fades but leaves a decent amount of lace. The nose is mostly malt, with notes of caramel, honey, and toasted malts, along with hints of citrus and flowers from the hops. The flavour starts out with a honey-malt sweetness, but becomes very well balanced towards the finish with the introduction of a fair dose of American hops. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth but almost sticky texture and light carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice Maibock; it is beautifully sweet, but with a very nice American hoppy twist at the end. A fine brew! 2010-08-28

Orange with a fizzy white head. Nice crisp grainy citrus and hemp aroma and taste with a grassy hemp finish. Earlier Rating: 7/6/2007 Total Score: 3.4650 mL bottle.  Clear golden amber with white foamy head.  Malty aroma and taste with a crisp finish.

Bottle. Pours a deep copper color, with hints of amber. Nice head with a strong aroma. Aroma is strong with malts and sticky hops. Taste is similar, with lots of sticky hops and almost carmelized malts. Nice lacing. Theres something inexplicable about this beer that I really like, but I cant quite put my finger on it. Im pretty sure its due to the yeast, but whatever it is I really like it! I would definitely like to brew with it sometime. The beer itself is good, but not great.

Poured out a dark yet bright orange copper brew... ahahah crappy description!, small light tan head and very nice messy lacing. Mild caramel nose, citruses (mild and a bit hidden), sweet plum, a bit fragrant as well. The taste is fairly strong with some alcohol. Caramel, sharp bitterness, light cocoa bitterness, sweetness that sits under everything, molasses. Damn, why does the alcohol stand out so much? Feels a bit slick with a fairly long bitter finish. This is a pretty boring beer.

Pours a crystal clear  golden amber color with a white that quickly dissipates but gathers around the edges. Caramel malt as well as some sour fruit in the nose. The palate is clean and refreshing, light-medium in body, lightly carbonated with a lasting finish. The taste is mostly sweet with caramel malt up front, but balanced with dry leafy finish. This is an enjoyable beer that I will definitely drink again.

Rating from notes taken in early August, when I was having trouble connecting with the site ... How little can one rating matter? This has to be among the most-rated beers in the world. To add my own two cents, this features the abundant sweet pale malts that you associate with a classic maibock, but finishes you off with some hop bitterness in the American craft beer style. Those hops would seem to clash with all that sweetness, but somehow the yeast pulls it all together. The finish proves bitter in the same way that a baguette is bitter. This is unlike the run-of-the-mill ipas that cloud our judgment and palates, making that hop finish worthy both of the malts that preceded it and of the beers status as a landmark of American craft brewing.

A deep malt and hop aroma. Deep amber color with a thin head and clear as a bell. A deep malty flavor with the hops present throughout the taste. This was bitter in the finish but had such a great flavor... got to like the dead guy!

Bottle: Pours a Clear golden amber color with a small white head with decent lacing. Smells a little yeasty/bready.. but definately sweet. Flavors are first a lightly bitter hops, and it finishes with a sweet caramel malt. Lightly carbonated, an almost honey element hits the palate as well. Fantastic!
12 oz bottle. Pours hazy golden color with a large white head that dissipates slowly. Easy drinker with a honey finish. Good ale.

I have been drinking this beer for years, but have never tasted it like this.  I received a 64oz brewery growler from Wavers1.  Its so much freakin better than the bottles or keg versions we get in south florida.  With 2400 ratings, Im not going to bore you with the details.  Just know this, the closer to the source you get, the better this ale gets.....

Bought a six-pack of this at a local liquor store in FL. Rogue Dead Guy Ale was a staple of mine out west, but I have turned to German and Belgian beers more as of late, its nice to know you can go home again.

Poured 12oz. out of bottle into Rogue pint glass. Amber in color, I didnt remember what it smelled like, but the one I poured had almost no aroma at all. Smooth mouthfeel, moderately hopped, a great example of the style. Easy to drink. Still love this beer.

Serving type: bottle
On tap at BJs.  Hazy dark amber hue.  Aroma of citrus hops and caramel malt.  Hoppy, citrusy taste with hints of caramel.  Full, tangy body.   I would not guess it is a Maibock, taste more like IPA.
This beer doesnt do much for me. Somewhat bland in flavor and weak in body.Perhaps that is because I prefer strong dark ales and this is definately not in that class.

The Dead Guy is a bit lighter than I remembered (maybe an 11), with a nice amber pour.  It carries a tannish white head that persisted. A nice caramel aroma, and maybe some bready aroma, and a tiny bit of floral hop. Flavor is of caramel sweetness and bready biscuit malt, with a gentle bitter. Well balanced, with no overriding hop character that pushes forward. One of my favorites from back in the day, and it still holds up.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2015 A Maibock but with Ale yeast. So it doesnt taste quite like other bocks but it is still good. Seems to be on tap at the most random of places you wouldnt expect. Hops are more mellow and malt a bit more forward. Serving: Bottle and Tap

Just a fantastic brew.  Pours A honey-yellow with a substancial white head.  Has a bit of a citrusy-hop nose, but the taste is full bodied hops with not much bitterness, balanced with a bunch of malty tones.  Wonderfully smooth with a great finish that makes me want more.  Best drank at just a llittle cooler than room temp.
A nose of malty floral notes and barley, with a moderately complex palate of barley, earthy notes, caramel, and pleasant hops underneath a fine alcohol warmth.
nice rich brown color with a nice sweet aroma. taste of burned caramel sugar and molasses. nice

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2010 Très bonne bière...dans mes préféré...jadore lamertume du houblon..maintenant disponnible dans les SAQ du québec. Jai acheté 3 six-pack dans un Liquor store de Cape May au New-Jersey.
Pours amber with a big off-white head. Flavor is caramel, pine hops, with a good malt balance. Very nice and sessionable beer.

At lAutre Oeil. Pours copper, quite a malty and hoppy aroma. Taste lives up to aroma -- heavy body, full flavour. Caramel-heavy, slighly cereal. Hops are there, but seems blended enough theyre not noticeably citrusy, floral or sprucy. Gets an A+ for balance and body. Just wish it would be more complex.
Good stuff. Nothing really complex. Sweet caramel malt and the right amount of bitterness. Mellow and smooth overall, a good ale.
One of my favorite beers of the moment. Love the Maltiness and hoppiness of this one. Cant wait to try all of the other beers Rogue has to offer. Rated 7/22/2010

Pours a copper color with a good head that fades slowly. Has a caramel & Malt aroma with a hint of sweetness. Mild sweetness of caramel and malt with a nice bitterness and dry finish. Fairly light body that is creamy smooth. Very well balanced. Better than I expected. I did not notice the 6.5 ABV til well into the second one. These go down easy and good for a few. This is well worth seeking out.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a nice off-white, long lasting head.  Aroma of sweet malt.  Tastes of malt and hops blended nicely.
Excellent.  Excellent.
Just one of my favorite beers, a great combination of maltiness and hopiness, the combination works perfect for me.
Pours a reddish color with a white head.  A little over carbonated but taste of malts and subtle hoppy flavors. Taste great and overall a good beer
Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. Drinkble, tasty, not worth all the hate it gets, but not deserving of the praise either.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2013 Pours a deep golden-amber with big foamy head. Lots of caramel and grassy hops on the nose. Taste is much like the aroma...caramel bisquity malt balanced well with a generous amount of bitter hops. Assertive taste yet mellow mouthfeel and very drinkable. Creamy texture. Long lasting hoppy finish. True to Rogue form...very good.

Pours amber colored with a foamy off-white head. Smells of bread, raisins, and cheese.  Medium bodied with light carbonation, clean.  Malts with some hops at the end.  Very enjoyable straight-forward beer.

Out of the bottle this beer is out of sight. First impressions as this is sipped are caramel and molasses, a big smooth sweet introduction that flows into the hoppy bitter finish. Great combination of malt and hop flavors that mix to produce on of my favorite beers out there.

This maibock pours a deep caramel colour and is slightly cloudy. The tanned head is creamy and has great retention. Lightly carbonated. Aromas of caramel malts, some raisins, some nuts and mild hop. Very smooth, almost creamy mouthfeel. Light tasting, with some hop throughout, light bitterness in the finish and way into the aftertaste, a lingering hop kick comes out... like mixing a banana and some grass. Quite interesting, well-balanced and very smooth.
A pretty decent hoppy beer. Nothing terribly special about it, but does end up being hoppier than the average american ale.
This a great classic beer from Rogue, one of my favorite northwest breweries.

Cant believe I havent rated this yet.  Clear light brown with medium off white head, some lacing.  caramel malt aroma with some citrus and a big malty flavor with balanced hops and slightly bitter.   my go-to session ale.

12oz bottle pours a bubbly, slightly off-white head.  Aroma is hops with a little sweetness from the malt.  Taste matches the aroma at the start and finishes with lingering bitterness.

All in all a pretty good brew, though far from my favorite.  Id go to this when I wanted something bitter, but not overwhelmingly hopped or malted.

bottle. lots of citrus and bitter hops on the nose. plenty of hop presence and a nice malt back bone to the taste. Very bitter at first then the caramel kicks in. long bitter aftertaste with a malty touch. Very good.
From a 12oz bottle,smelled like citrus,Amber in color,white head,I was surprise this beer ended up to be good.

355ml bottle, 6.6% a/v

Pours firey copper colour with  a light tan head. Looks a fair bit like anchor liberty ale. Aroma is mostly hoppy, spicy/pine/citrus smelling. The taste is as the smell would indicate though a bit malty to balance out. Actually very well balanced between hops and malt. The palate is a bit creamy but with a very hoppy aftertaste. I like that kind of thing though so this beer is pretty decent in my view.
Great beer - pours with quite a small head but strong aroma, tastes a bit sweet and nutty with hints of banana, honey and sugar - goes down easily, some great tastes - recommended beer.

Draught at The Blind Pig Brewery.

Aroma: Slightly malty aroma
Appearance: Golden color with small head that recedes quickly
Taste: Light bitter taste
Palate: Light body with average carbonation
Overall: Good beer that is too easy too drink.
Pours a lovely amber red.  Rich malt aromas.  Wonderful malt attack which fades to a slightly bitter finish.  Very creamy mouthfeel on this brew.

Pours a clear, dull copper with a small head and despite that has surprisingly decent lacing.  The aroma is sweet, slightly bready, with a fruit component (grape) thats very nice.  Extremely clean and crisp beer with a lingering but mild fruit finish.  Very nice on the tongue, crisp carbonation, medium mouthfeel and very slick.  This is a nice take on the maibock style and a pretty enjoyable quaff.
Copper appearance with lively carbonation.  A hint of caramel... very simple with light hops.

Hazy amber, creamy off-white head, foamy lacing.  Floral and toffee aromas.  Has a bit of a metallic taste (bottle pour into shaker glass, so containers not the source) and a tad on the bitter side.  Medium-bodied.

The scent is that of cherries. The flavor, however, has an earthy residue. Its almost as if someone had pureed the entire redwood forest and filled it into a bottle. At the same time, there is a weird, abnormally cringe-worthy tinge to the beer. I could compare it to sidewalk chalk or childrens medicine. The bottle art isnt enough to scrub the quasi-gross aftertaste out of your mind. 

Oh yeah...and the color is like ship rust. Not that it matters.
Had this one on tap.  Pours an orangey gold.  Grassy aromas.  Hoppy, malty, and kind of sweet.  Big flavors.
I love this beer! This beer has opened my eyes to the Maibocks of the world.

(Bottle)  A nice looking beer as commercially described. Malt forward and nicely balanced with hops. Not overpowering; a mild and enjoyable flavor with subtle sweetness.  I gotta remember this around Halloween.

aroma of grass,earthiness,honey and caramel/toffee in that order..appearance of a cloudy red/lightbrown beer with lacing and enduring head which finally becomes a ring..taste has all of the above malty floavors from the aroma but..surprise! tingly hops as well that arent upfront in the aroma nice balance of each..tingly on the palate leaves a bitter then sweet aftertaste a pleasure to drink

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 Bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. A thin white top forms over a very ordinary-looking clear orange ale body. Smell is fruity hops with some malt and citrus tones. Taste is complex hops with flavors in the range of grassy-to-slightly-fruity. Not bad, but not very impressive either. Then again, this is my second Heller Bock and my first was completely different so I guess Im not really familiar with the style. Or theres some freak categorization accidents going on. :-P

650 ml bottle at JD McGillicuddys in Phiily. Here for the Coheed Show next door at the Electric Company! 
Nice dark copper pour with a thin head. This place served it at a nice temp  (I meen not cold cold) and the flavor really came out. Hops, cinnamon, wheat, dark lightly smoked malts. Its about time I rated this beer.
33cl bottle from Silja Line ferry. Poured a hazy, dark golden color with a big head. Aroma is malty and hint of yeast and spices. Flavor is more malty, quite sweet (raw sugar).  Enjoyed this one.
Strong caramel maltiness in a bottle. A little unjustified bitterness makes it a tough call at 11$ a 6 pack, but not a bad buy. Refreshing, as long as you can handle the finish.
Solid "go to" beer . . Nice mix of sweet natural caramel with the right amount of hops . . Refreshing as always . .
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 One of my favorite all time "staples." Nose and taste is complex nutmeg, sweet molasses and spices. Rated 11/14/2000 - Original Rating 4.4
Hazy golden pour from bottle.  Hops, honey and spice on the nose.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Mildly bitter finish.  Excellent!!

12 oz. bottle.  Pours an amber gold color, with off white foam head.  Aroma of honeysuckle, melon, lemonbread.  Flavor is a honey infused citrus hop taste, with notes of fresh hay, toast.  Nice bite to the finish, medium bodied, very sessionable.  I dont know why it took me so long to try this, its just the perfect session, i want a keg.
Bought a growler. Not much impressive about the aroma. Dark orange color with clean white head. sweet taste with a hint of citrus. very easy drinking great every day beer.

Bottle. Pours a Hazy dark orange-brown color with a thick sustaining white  head. Sweet malt nose with some caramel and fruit. Taste is hoppy and sweet pretty well balanced and easily drinkable. I liked it a lot
Caramel, english hops, and some spices.  Palate is lighter and crisp.  Flavor brings out a malt backbone, finishing a little bitter with a hop aftertaste.  Very sessionable.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2012 Pours a hazy dark orange colour with  medium off-white head. The aroma is of malts and hops with some fruitiness and a little yeast. The taste is malty and slightly sweet with some caramel to it, there is also a nice bitterness that it finishes with. Medium bodied with nice carbonation and fairly smooth. Overall very nice, close to the double dead guy and easily one of my favourites. Edit: Had this on tap for the first time recently, it is far superior on tap.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2010 12oz Bottle. Aroma lacks a bit of punch, though is very pleasant. A mellow cloud of vanilla, yeast, bread/dough, malt, fruitiness and some citrus/spice from the hops. Flavour is nicely balanced; comes on first with slightly toasty malts, almost Pilsner malt in style, but much breadier and very doughy, a little bit more vanilla, good bitterness creeping in bringing with it more citrus, orange-peel and spiciness. Body is quite gassy, and I wonder if this is due to it being in a smaller bottle, as I generally find that the 24oz bots are alot less fizzy. Still it keeps the beer light-mid bodied which gives the beer a very refreshing and quaffable quality. Abv is well disguised. Finish is nicely bitter with a touch of nuttiness and a bit of sweet bitterness reminiscent of Danish pastry. For Rogues sort of flagship beer I think its really good, perhaps not my favourite from what Ive tasted, but its faithfull to the core style, but still injects a good dose of US brewing which makes the beer pleasantly unique.

Pours a slightly hazy golden brown color with a big time head.  Aroma is of malts, yeast, citrus, and spices.  Flavor is of sweeter malts, yeast, brown sugar, slight aluminum, and dark fruit.  Leaves a sweeter aftertaste.  This one is excellent.
12 ounce bottle-a orangish amber pour-off white head -aroma and taste of caramel, dough, -nice bitter finsh -good beer

aroma is an enticing mix of dry biscuit, toffee, malt, earthy hops, and caramel.
slightly hazy orange/light-brown with small frothy off-white head.
flavor is sweet and biscuit-y with a balancing mellow hop bitterness; a bit of citrus and passion-fruit but mostly earthy.
its medium-bodied, fairly carbonated and a little slick with a dry slightly bitter finish.

Draft at small bar. Old standard, time for a rate! Cloudy dark orange with thick sustaining white head. Nose is subtle, pale malts with hints of melanoidins. Taste is sweet munich malts and tea leaves on top of a pale base, very light caramel, finishes with light sweetness. Low-medium body, watery texture, mild carbonation. One of my gateway craft beers with the great logo, this easy-drinking bock still holds up even as the palate has improved, very sessionable IMO.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2010 Bouteille.  Couleur blond miel de trèfle, collet blanc cassé.  Fine dentelle.  Arômes de houblons et de malts.  Pétillante sur la langue.  Saveurs de malt avec des pointes de caramel.  Bonne amertume.  Facile à aimer.  Bonne bière.

A- nice amber color with thick white head that fades to lacing that sticks with the glass. a little bit cloudy with black particles in it.

S- good smell of sweet malt and yeast.

T- not much to the initial taste maybe some malt and yeast. aftertaste is of bitter hops and alcohol.

P- Medium body and carbonation. Was not a smooth beer. somewhat dry.

O- It took me over an hour to finish the glass.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-07-2007 02:20:19

sample from bottle... a bit of spice and sweet malts on the nose... deep copper pour with an off white head... nice appearance... medium body with some caramel malts, nice and soft, some caramel over the top, sweet sugar on the sides... crisp finish with some honey and a biting smooth bitterness.  really nice beer - surprised it took me so long to buy this one.

Superb beer. Pours orange with a small, off-white head. Not a whole lot to offer on the nose, with a bit of malt sweetness and a touch of aromatic hops. On the tongue it has a delicious malt sweetness, with caramel and toffee leading to a nice hoppy, bitter finish. The highlight of this beer is the hedonistic mouth-feel. It is beautifully creamy - spot-on carbonation. Very well balanced. Rogues best beer?

12oz Bottle into Tumbler. 6.6%ABV. Pours deep orange/amber with a medium, tan head. Sweet malt aroma with subtle floral hoppy notes. Medium body with nice malt backbone overlying a well balanced hop bitterness and flavour. Slick-dry finish. Definitely a lovely beer to be savoured in quantities exceeding 12oz.
Small white head.  Great lacing.  Not a lot of aroma.  Malty with moderate to high bitterness.  Well balanced beer.

This beer, aliased as white crane bitter, poured a light hazy orange with almost no foam. The aroma had a hint of white pear and candy apple. Taste had a mixture of candy apple with a medium amount of citrus-like bitterness on the aftertaste. The citrus and the carbonation makes this a bit harsh on the palate.

Draught. Hazy amber with no head. Little, but pleasant, aroma. Medium body, light carbonation, nice mouthfeel. Unusual flavour Nice complex balanced foretaste with fruity, floral malty notes and a hint of chocolate, with a fair bitter finish. Overall, different and pleasant..

best brew Ive tried in some time... Orange-amber pour from a 12 oz bottle. Aroma of mild malts, citrus, and light aromatic hops. Excceptionally well balanced flavor with solid maltiness that is just short of sweet and well balanced hops in the finish. Clean finish with and excellent and complex finish. Great stuff.
One of the better, most respected breweries in the USA, and this one is their trademark. If a skeleton can drink it, so can you. Enjoy!

Amber color, small off-white head; sweet malty aroma with woody notes and hints of smoke; medium body, smooth carbonation; malty sweet, perhaps lightly fruity flavor with mild bitterness. I quess its simplicity was a bit of an letdown for me too, but I still enjoyed it quite much.
Bottle. Nice bitter hops. Some sweetness. Mild citrus. Just a solid all around.
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Drank this out of the bottle some time ago. Taste has some citrus, roasted malts and a mild bitter aftertaste. Not bad but nothing special.
Bottle.  Pour is orange with a small beige head.  Aroma is malty, cane sugar, and a light floral malt.  Flavor is also quite malty with a light spiciness and a nice floral hop component. Not bad.

Excellent all around ale. Moderate hops aroma with hints of malt.  Deep amber color, clear, minimal head.   Some bitterness, medium body, soft carbonation, clean finish.  Not overpowering in any way, just a solid go-to beer.
Pours a light golden amber color with a small white head. Light sweet aroma and tastes alcoholic with a strong hops aftertaste.

From a Bomber. Pours a goldish orange, almost honey color, Ample head that dissapaited. Aroma is citrus and hoppy. Medium texture in the mouth with tangy citrus notes evident. Slightly bitter finish. A nice balance to this ale.

From the bottle.  Pours a golden-amber with offwhite head, nice color.  Great balance of hops and malts in the nose and flavor.  Packs a nice punch but finishes smooth.  Not the first time Ive had this beer and hopefully not the last.

Purchased on tap at Winslows Tavern, Greenville, NC

Was expecting/hoping for more; wasnt terrible but I wanted more taste out of it.
Nice mix of flavors.  Some sweetness and roasted malts up front, a little hoppy bite and a refreshing aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2015 Apricot, nectarine, caramel, citrus, fruity and floral hoppy aroma. Dark copper orange color, hazy. Small head that disapates quickly. Taste is malty, apricot, nectarine, citrus, honey, caramel. Tiny hint of roast. Hops bitterness balances out sweetness well. Floral, tangy hops lingers on the tongue. Medium body+, nicely coats tongue. Velvety smooth. Overall an excellent beer. Nothing you can put your finger on, most of the flavors you have had in other beers but it all works here. Possibly the best palate I have had in a beer. A great drinker.

12oz bottle from LCBO. Pours amber with a decent sized off-white head, aroma of sweet malt, floral hops, alcohol, pleasantly mixed. Flavor is smooth and refreshing, slight hoppy presence, great malt character, some sweetness, citrus, a caramel notes, good body, very decent.

$5.50 / 220z bomb- Is Dead Guy sort of Rogues flagship beer?  It seems like this beer is often the introduction for many who have discovered Rogue.  Solid beer, but definitely little funky with the aroma and taste.  Im picking up bread, nuts, and some citrus on the tongue.  It is true, Rogue has much better offerings, but Dead Guy is a very good Bock.  When it is all said and done, I crave this beer about once a year.

Pours a dark copper with a medium off-white head.  Head dissipated quickly with minor lacing.  Aroma consists of caramel, malts and a hint of nuts.  Taste is sweet with a bitter finish.  Medium body with a somewhat creamy mouthfeel.  Nice beer but I have had better from Rogue.

This one was in the bottle at the local pizza chain. No clue as to how old it was.  It poured with little noticeable head and a dark brown liquid color.  Hops were a little citrusy against the slightly toasted malt.  Nothing too exciting here, but it would be a good session brew.  Hints of vanilla also.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Pours bronze with light beige head. Notes of yeast, caramel with some spruce? Taste caramel malt but also hops, spices and roasted malt. Good bitterness finish combined with oily texture.
Honey-Gold with minimal head; carbonation. Smells of caramel and honey. Taste has some hops and caramel?

On tap at the Yard House. A dark orange brew, with a subtle/hoppy scent. Did not notice a head in mine, the taste is tough to describe. I would have to say it is a strong and bitter hops one with a bit of tangy fruit. Not my favorite, but an interesting change of pace.

Pours a cloudy orange with a slight head.  Aroma of hops and sour water.  Taste is a little sweet caramel with a bitter hops aftertaste.  Decent alcohol content that allows you to sit back and enjoy this beer.

12 oz bottle from Crystal Liquor Barrel.  Cloudy orange pour with a huge foamy head.  Aroma is malty and slightly hoppy.  It reminds me of an IIPA that has sat around awhile and had its hoppy profile start shifting to a more malty balance.  Flavor is malty with some citrus/fruity notes to it.  Finish is a clean and slightly hoppy feeling on your tongue.  I love the uniqueness of this beer, not what I expected but in a very good way.
Copper color.  Aroma of malt and floral hops.  Really good balance on the palate with some nice bitterness from the hops.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 355mL bottle.  Pours a translucent pale amber with a small head.  Biscuity, citrusy floral aroma.  Flavours much the same, medium sweetness and bitterness and a bit of alcohol.  Medium-full bodied, soft carbonation and slick on the palate with a bitter finish.
dark orangish/red color, little head.  somewhat citrusy...close to grapefruit taste, with strong hops.  good, but overpriced.
I like the aroma. Its a little cloudy... reddish color. Has kind of a bitter taste to it, nothing too bad.

Bomber; just over a month old. Pours Dark orange. Light head with light lacing. Nothing special about the smell or taste. Bready malt palate with a spicy, bitter hop finish. An average beer at an above average price.
Tap.  Nice ale here.  Not too hoppy and very easy drinking.  Enjoyed with a nice sandwich.  The 6.6% wasnt noticeable.

(12oz bottle) opaque orange pour with oily bubbles. Nose of oranges, and grapefruit/citrus. Taste of light bitterness, buttery, citrus (pineapple, oranges, ruby red grapefruit), bready, with a well carbonated fruity finish.

One of my early favorite "go to" beers. There is nothing really super special about the aroma, but the thing just taste so damn good. Its very smooth and relaxing. You can really taste the malts and the hops.
Good heavy beer. A little hoppy for my taste but still had some nice flavors and smooth finish.
roasty, citrus, golden, orange, sparkling, white foam, sparkling, medium bitterness, full body, thin feel, lively, bitter. 2/14/2010

33cl bottle. Pours an orange/amber with a medium, frothy, almond head. Slightly tart nose with a powerful nose full of hops. Pleasant Saaz hops with caramel. This is so nice i will be trying to brew a clone version myself.

Bottle, home. This beer is somewhere between tawny and mahogany in color. The head is off-white and leaves some nice lacing. The aroma is nice - sweet, subtle caramel malt with some light, fruity hops. The flavor is a tad sweet and finishes with a mildly sour lager/malt flavor, but its well-balanced and goes down easy. The mouthfeel has always seemed a tad odd to me. I get a funny graininess at first. Dead Guy wont bowl you over with complexity, but its a solid beer and its easy to see why it has converted many a macro drinker.

Bottle, labelled White Crane Bitter.  Pours light copper with a finger of tight pale beige head. Medium to high bead. Smells of hay and flowers with some stone fruits. Taste doesnt live up to the aroma - its rather caramel sweet with subdued balancing bitterness. Moderately bitter and somewhat salty finish.

Pours pale orange with no head.  Smells of sweet malts and apricot.  Very faint.  Extremely light on the palate.  Thin. Cotton dry and bitter on the finish.  Wheres the malt???  Yet another example of why the coast should stick to their great hoppy ales.  Disappointment.

Slightly hazy golden blonde with a nice and lasting white head. Notes of sweet malts and apricots on the nose, mild carbonation, medium body, on the malty side, some fruity hops in there too, finishes pretty balanced between malts and hops, altough a little thin. Easy drinking tasty beer.

Glass. Pours a golden-rust with a thin white head. Has an exellent nose. Very floral, smells like a bouquet of roses. Slight hop notes, pine, grassy. Taste is delicious. More malty with hop undertones and a balanced sweet/slightly bitter finish, Smooth. Palate is medium. Not pilsener like, not a stout feel. Somewhere in between. This is overall a very good beer.
apperance was acceptable,aroma was woodsie,sweet but somewhat bitter finish.
An incredibly balanced beer - plenty of hops and a complimentary maltiness for this, my current favorite. Its a bit pricey though.

Dark gold pour from bottle, moderate head.  Understated hops aroma.  Well-balanced hops / maltiness.  Medium body, slippery mouthfeel.  Minor lacing.  Lingering bitter finish.  Not bad.  Bock is not my favorite style, but this is a good, solid example.
On tap. Poured a clear amber with a thin white head. Aroma had notes of pine and citrus with a bit of spice and malt. Malt was more apparent in the flavor with more of an undertone of hops.

This was okay. I was expecting it to be great, which might have had some-what of an effect on my ability to rate it, given how disappointed I was. Regardless, it had kind of a typical flavor, nothing special. The finish was kind of unsettling for me. I wouldnt buy this beer but I would definitely drink it for free!

From a bottle. Great nose, with some floral notes and a few spicy elements. Rich head leaves a decent lace; color is dark honey, almost into the orange or amber spectrum. Flavor is really pleasant; toasty malts up front give way to an almost astringent hop dryness on the finish. Easy to drink, and damned tasty.
Tasty, slightly sweet caramel-y cereal-ish malt forward with nice balancing hops and slight fruitiness. There is a weird funkiness in here somewhere though. Just a little cheesy.
A great beer with a distinctive taste.  Hazy orange color without much foam.  A little on the bitter side.

Definitely not what you would expect from the flagship product of the Dead Guy brand.  When I first opened the bottle there was a strong wif of malt, but this disappeared when I poured it into a glass.  Resembles a IIPA which is not surprising that they have a squared version.  PNW Hops add much robustness to the citrus and honey flavored base.  This is a clear winner on a hot summer day.

Appearance is orange, slightly brown. Aroma is citrussy with hints of pine. When you sip it, you definitely feel a cleansing carbonation and with the bitterness of the hops would make a very good pairing with some spicy food. Thin body. The finish is interesting- it felt long lasting but then had a real quick, crisp finish. Dont think Ive ever encountered that before.

Pours a deep, slightly hazy orange with a pretty thin white head that dissipates quickly. It has an aroma of grapefruit, malt and a bit of something else which I cant exactly describe, perhaps a bit resiny. The taste matches the aroma, and this beer has a nice mouthfeel with plenty of carbonation. Overall, a fine offering from Rogue.
a classic american brew that lives up to its reputation. tasty and balanced.

330ml bottle. Creamy rich light beige head with a brilliant orange coloured base, looks like sunrise in a glass. Citrus and floral hop aromas send the senses into overdrive. The taste matches the look and aroma. Wow what a beer, a brilliantly brewed drop in every way.

Copper honey color --  semi-opaque with a decent white head. Subtle aroma -- buttery crackers and citrus as well as pine hop notes. Taste is bolder -- dominated by citrus hops at first, but pretty well balanced by the bready, caramel malts after the first taste. Great carbonation, feels really nice on the tongue -- dances but disappears quickly. Good bitter aftertaste. I like this for a session beer.
Bottle. Smells and tastes like sweet caramelized vegtables backed up with some hops and quite a lot of malt. Nice one.

Pours deep golden and amber-like from the 12oz. bottle: Ive been looking forward to this rating for a while, since this is the one that started it all for me (hence "DeadGirl"). Nose is sweet malts, chewy grains, hay and rustic hops. Has a distinct bite of sweet biscuit, toffee, and roasted barley. Medium bodied. Faint alcohol presence. Drinkability: For such distinct flavors on the palate, this one stays memorable for its lingering softness on the mouthfeel. Like flavor waves. Rebuy: Yes. #250 on 22012010, DG.
650ml Bottle - Pours honey colored with small white head. Aroma is sweet fruity hops along with some hints of caramel. Flavor is bigtime fruity and flowery hops. Wellbalanced and quite nice.

Aroma: Hops, citrus, malts. Appearance: Hazy amber appearance. Taste: Nice balance of hop and malt. Strong, citrus, fruity hops took me first then the malts came over with some malty, caramel goodness. Fairly sweet, mild bitterness. Great sessionable quaffer. I really enjoyed this.

355ml bottle from SAQ. colour is copper, more on the dark side than not. has a thick, creamy white head that leaves a bit of lacing. aroma is bread and citrus, a little bit of hops and malts. taste has loads of toffee, its sweet and malty but a nice hops finish. very well balanced. this is my first beer from Rogue, great experience.

1/2gal growler from Liquor Barn in Santa Fe, NM. Pours a medium copper color with no head. Aroma is slightly hoppy with an overtone of herbs. Taste is woody with a slight smokiness to it. Just right as far as carbonation goes; Very smooth with just enough bubbly mouth feel. Not bad.
Pours out a deep amber color with a small to medium sized white head. Smells a bit citrusy, and tastes of citrus too, with a light hoppiness to the finish.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2010 Bottle. Aroma is toffee, malt, caramel and honey. Appearance is honey golden with an inch of fluffy white head. Taste starts off with strong toasted malt and honey flavors along with lemon, bread dough and butterscotch. Mouthfeel is slightly creamy with medium carbonation and a crisp, malty finish. Theres a nice balance between the sweet malt and the doughy yeast flavors. Its a uniquely American interpretation of a traditional German style that hides its ABV level very well.

Wow.  Second maibock of the evening and this one is outstanding.  12 oz. bottle to lager glass.  Nice pale amber with great thick lasting head that laces as it moves down the glass nicely.  I get citrus, caramel and some grain, pleasant.  Very balanced taste, bitter sweet and slightly savory.  Good mouth feel, medium body that goes with the style.

Bottle. Lovely beer this! Good copper colour with whitish head. Aroma has some fruit, citrus and a good clean malty aroma too. Drinks very nicely, I could sip this all day. Very well balanced, with good bitterness but no bitter finish, crisp and clean with a moderately full body. Definately would drink again, Im yet to find a Rogue beer I havent enjoyed.
cloudy amber with a thin off white head. Sweet aroma hint of citrus. Tastes slightly oaked and grassy. A bit fizzy for my liking but not bad.

12 oz bottle pours amber with minimal head into a lager glass.  Aroma of sweet malt with a nice bready bit coming through, little bit of hops and malts.  Tastes sweet and biscuity with a bit of roasted barley, faint amount of toffee.  Medium carbonation and body with a soft mouthfeel.  I honestly love how simple this is, makes me feel great.  This is the one that started it all for me. Yum!

Bright, clear amber beer with a lively looking carbonation and thin foam.  Reasonably damp and yeasty on the nose with boozy maltiness and a light smoking to it.  Full of intensely thick umami and soy sauce saltiness. Super intense, doubt I could have more than one in an evening. It is delicious as they come really and Im drinking it in some serious heat which may not be ideal.

12 oz bottle served in shaker. The commercial description fits this one well. Aroma of caramel malts with floral and spicy hops. Bright honey colored with a thin off white head which dissipates quickly. Sweet and slightly bitter  with a pleasing alcohol warmth. Nicely balanced. Medium body and gently carbonated. Highly recommended.

Bottle. 

Amber with a small off-white head. Very malty aroma, caramel and honey. Sweet flavor, good balance. Descent stuff.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a deep honey color with small off-white head.  The taste is light malt finishing strong bitter hops.  Not a fan.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle. Amber pour, small head. Aroma of caramel and malt. Caramel, malt, honey, and bread on taste. Some hop presence.
Dark hoppy with medium head and a nice aftertaste.  Distinctive label makes it a go to at any store.
Labeled as white crane bitter.   Sweet hoppy tang with bitter vanilla and malt backing.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2010 The aroma starts with honey with the malty-ness behind it.  Pours a nice amber haze with a thin head.  The beer starts with honey and malt, and ends bitter.  A full bodied texture on the palate.  A very solid beer.
Pours a honey amber with a good head. Smells of malts and honey. Taste is malty with caramels and a touch of honey with a nice hop bitter. Good mouthfeel with a nice finish that lingers.
It is deep honey in colour. Rich malty aroma, rich toasted caramels and cereal. Well balanced finish.

Aroma is malty with a slight hint of what smells almost like chocolate - interesting and complex.  The appearance was cloudy with a honey-like color, small head that seemed to dissipate quickly.  The taste bitter sweet - one can surely taste the sweet malts and the bitter hops both separately and in tandem.  The palate was amazing.  Seemingly, this beer has four different and distinct tastes depending on where this beer resided.  Hoppy, malty, bitter, full, soft carbonation - very refreshing to have such a complex palate.  Sweet on the tip to hoppy in the back of my mouth.  Overall, this beer would be a full twenty out of twenty, but the aroma could use some help.  Maybe with a slightly more lively carbonation it would help with carrying the aroma.  So many hops probably doesnt help with head retention with the hop oils present and carbonation might help with that as well.  But, just my opinion.

Pours amber with a small off-white head. Malty carmel aroma. Lightly sweet malty and a little bitter flavor. Mouthfeel is full with a strong hops bite.  Malt and caramel in smell. Little roasty and very rich in flavor. Slighty strong hops with very good mouthfeel. A lingering slightly bitter, smoked carmel aftertaste. Very pleasant.
Had on tap at two Rogue bar in Portland.  Golden body with honey.  Smooth, with a hint of honey, caramel, and toasted malt.  Medium to light body but well balanced. Not a long finish but a good beer.

Poured hazy, golden/copper with a bubbly, slowly receding head. Aroma of citrus hops. Taste was well-balanced with citrus hops coming through in the middle. Slight sweetness made the malt enjoyable as well. A good session beer.

Bottle from the Village Bottle Shop. This is a very good beer. Pours amber with a thin white head. The aroma is subtle but pleasant and intriguing, with notes of sweet honey and malt. The beer is medium bodied and has a solid, robust feel. The flavor is understated and controlled but incredibly balanced. Its slightly sweet, with some earthy malt, bread and hops. The finish is clear and balanced. The beer isnt dominated by any one of these elements, but altogether its quite a pleasurable elixir.
Pours a deep golden honey color. The nose is hops, caramel, and a bready malt. The taste is caramel, honey, and hops. Mouthfeel is medium-light and refreshing. Great beer.
very good beer with a strong character and aftertaste. Very complex blend of malts and hops make this beer very bitter and pours with a dark color. Wonderful beer

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2010 650mL bottle, pours a crisp golden with a thin white head. Aroma is caramel and sweet malts, a little hops. Flavour is a rich, full-bodied honey and caramel malt. Excellent brew.
Pours a translucent rose honey color with minimal head.  Sweet malty aroma with a hint of hops.  Brief malt taste at the beginning followed by an explosion of hops.  Lingering taste is pleasant.

a deep cloudy warn golden colour, with a nice od white head. first mouth full presents a full and warm mouth feel, fantasic flavour envelopes the mouth. a nice even bitterness shines through and lingers nicely to balance it all off.....

Warm golden amber pour into pub glass from a bomber picked up locally yielded only a small head but lots of lacing.  Probably my pour technique which doesnt return much foam.  The smell is as rich as any beer Ive ever tried, strong yeast essences along with a robust carmel and roasted barley.  Taste is very bold caramel and malt, a hint of sweetness and bitter hops but a very well rounded full figured taste.  Another amazing Rogue ale.
A nice full bodied beer. Pours nice with small head. Color is lighter then expected from the full bodied taste. Warm on the tongue with notes of caramel, well hopped to perfect balance

Bottle. pours a clear orange color with a small white head. Head dissipates to nothing. Nose is lightly fruity with a biscuity note. Palate is full and firm with a light film and a bitter finish. Flavors of light fruity notes like peaches and apricots, biscuity malt notes, and a firm fizzy and bitter finish.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2010 Dead Guy Ale

1997 22 oz. Regular & Halloween Bottles.  6.50% ABV.  (4.75 / 5.0)  Bock Ale--Rich, malty, hoppy ale.  Malt on top of hops, but both big.  Rich Amber color.  Caramel Malt flavor predominates.  Sampled 10/31/1997.

1998 22 oz. Blue Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  (4.75 / 5.0)  Bock Ale--Rich, malty, hoppy ale.  Malt on top of hops, but both big.  Rich Amber color.

1998 22 oz. Pink Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Bock Ale--Clear amber golden color.  Light hop fruit malt front.  Rich medium bodied brew with malty accent.  Fruit hints and light caramel  flavor.  Good but not exceptional.  Indication of high variation.  Sampled 10/30/1999.

1999 12 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  (4.75 / 5.0)  Bock--Light spice front with hint of floral hops is overwhelmed by rich toasted caramel body.  Lager smooth but ale accents to sweet crusty body.  Hints of ESB. Hop influence increases through taste to end.  Sampled 8/16/1999.

2001 22 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Bock Ale--Clear amber color. Rich lace head.  Mild hop malt front.  Sweet smooth malty caramel cherry body with thin Maier Signature dryness.  Balanced hop end.  Maier Bock!  Sampled 11/3/2001.

2002 22 oz. Red Label Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  (4.75 / 5.0)  Bock--Clear bright deep honey amber color.  Smooth mellow lagered floral hop fruit front.  Rich smooth butterscotch caramel cherry fruit body enhanced by light sediment.  Mellow balanced malt hop end.  MaierBock!!  Sampled 5/26/2002.

2003 12 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Bock--Clear bright rich amber color.  Lacy white head.  Malty tangy rich floral hop front.  Creamy dry sweet tangy rich caramel ester ale smooth body.  Rich malty balanced brew.  Tangy mild citrus rich hop spice end.  Sampled 10/31/2003.

2004 12 oz. Bottle.  6.40% ABV--30 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Amber Ale--Creamy lacy head.  Clear rich bright amber red color.  Malty mild floral hop front.  Creamy rich doughy caramel biscuit mild sweet smooth apple butter nut body.  Creamy balanced malt spice mild hop end.  Sampled 11/1/2004.

2005 64 oz. Red Growler.  6.50% ABV--45 IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Marzen Ale--Thin no lace head.  Clear rich amber color.  Mellow malty hop front.  Rich creamy smooth caramel fully fermented dry sweet mellow butter fruit ester body.    Mild crusty clean mellow hop spice tangy end.  Maibock.  Sampled 10/31/2005.

2006 12 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV--35 IBUs.?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Bock--Mild lace head.  Rich amber color.  Malty mild fruit mild hop front.  Smooth rich mild sweet fruit creamy butter caramel toffee rich hoppy Bock Ale body.  Mellow malt hop spice balanced mild tang end.  Nice.  Sampled 8/2/2006.

2006 64 oz. Red Growler.  6.00% ABV--30 IBUs.?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Amber Ale--Bock.  No lace no head.  Cloudy dark amber orange color.  Malty mild fruit ester hop front.  Flat fresh of the tap caramel fruit yeast ester body.  Mild tangy crisp clean fresh mild hop end.  Mild hop amber.  Overrated?  Growler packaging does not do justice to the brew.  Flat.  Sampled 10/31/2006.

2007 64 oz. Red Growler.  6.00% ABV--30 IBUs.?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Amber Ale--Bock.  $10.99 Each.  Mild lace head.  Clear rich amber color.  Malty mild fruit hop front.  Smooth crisp dry sweet lager smooth mild sweet caramel fruit body.  Smooth balanced easy mild hop end.  Crusty hints.  Amber Lager Ale.  Sampled 10/31/2007.

Chinookie Ale--Dedicated To U-DA-MAN 2007--2008 22 oz. Bottle.  6.75% ABV--40 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Pale Ale--Thick pour.  Dense rocky lacy off white thick lasting head.  Cold fizz haze clear deep honey amber color.  Malty floral Perle Saaz hop front.  Doughy cloying mild sweet rich caramel fruit chewy body.  Malty smooth mild hop spice cloying crisp dry Rogue Pacman end.  Sampled 10/16/2008.  2 @ $6.00 Each.

Dead Guy Ale--DIE DULCI FREURE-Dedicated to Ed Rose, a 21st Century Survivor--Handcrafted micro-piece by Rogue Ales--2009 Orange 64 oz. Growler.  6.24% ABV--40 IBUs.  (4.35 / 5.0)  Amber Ale--Bock	Dense lacy rich white head.  Clear bright thin honey amber color.  Soft hop delicate malt front.  Mild sweet smooth mild caramel fruit crisp clean Bock ale malt body.  Rich smooth delicate flavor.  Fresh refreshing balanced smooth mild hop spice end.  Very nice.  Sampled 11/25/2009.  $14.99 Each.

Dead Guy Ale--2009 Orange 22 oz. Bottle.  6.24% ABV 40 IBUs.  (4.4 / 5.0)  MaiBock Ale--Rocky lacy off white head.  Clear thin bright pretty amber sediment dust orange color.  Delicate malt hop aroma.  Medium bodied mild sweet rich smooth light caramel delicate breadfruit mild tangy tasty body.  Fresh smooth creamy mild hop doughy rich clean end.  Sampled 12/8/2009.  $5.99 Each.

Pours a murky bronze with standard white head. Aroma of caramel and raisin. Flavor is straightforward of caramel malt and raisin. A slight whiskey finish. I wouldnt seek it out but wouldnt pass it down.

Bottle at Hashigo Zake. Pours hazy amber, off white head. Sweet candyish malt aroma, lime citrus hop.
Quite sweet initial malt hit, backed up nicely by earthy hops. A great balance between malt & hops, with a dry finish.
Just yum.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2010 (12 ounce bottle)  Pours a cloudy copper amber color with large head that leads to a great lace.  Aroma consists of a great caramel malt balanced with a interesting yeast componet.  Nice mouthfeel, soft carbonation, clean finish and medium bodied.  Good beer.

The ale pours brilliant honey-amber, with a two-finger off-white head. The nose has a nice balance of yeast and malt.  Quite pleasant.  The carbonation is well-developed and very pleasant with very small bubbles.  The body is medium-light. Much lighter than I would expect of a bock, but then this is a Maibock, which is traditionally lighter.  It is also rather dry and lightly hopped. Excellent with lighter foods or deep-fried foods.  Quenching.  I am not certain that if I was a monk and this was a meal-replacement ale, I would be totally satiated.  The alcohol is not noticeable on the palate, but shows itself after a few sips.  The lingering is very pleasant and the malt shows very nicely.  The lacing is very sparse.

I found this beer easily drinkable with a well balanced blend of malt vs. hops.  The beer is a nice honey / amber color with out much of a head to get all stuck up in my mustache.  Overall I really enjoy this beer.

Bottle. Pours a translucent dark amber; nice white head that disappears relatively quickly. Flavor is, like most of the raters have said, quite balanced between sweet malts and bitter hops. Good stuff.

A: Poured with an average-sized, white head that dissipated pretty quickly to 1/4-finger or so. Body is a nice, orange/amber color, and hazy.

S: Very nice aroma that comes across as well-balanced, with the malt and hops, with some interesting fruitiness coming through that I cant place. Kind of like mango or pineapple or something.

T: Very tasty, and a smooth-drinking beer. Comes off mostly sweet from the malt and the fruit, but finishes with a mild bitterness that leaves a light dryness in the mouth. Doesnt taste like 6.5%... dangerous.

M: Medium-bodied and creamy, with average carbonation.

D: This is the definition of quaffable. I really enjoyed this beer... the fine balance and the addition of the fruitiness is very drinkable and nowhere near overpowering.

Im from Lousiana, a coonass if you must (a glorified louisiana term for redneck) So I love this ale. Its great to drink. I especially love buying it because it comes in the big redneck style granny clampet jug. haha. Its great.
Bottle. This was a wonderful beer. The balance was incredible. The malty sweetness with the hoppy bitterness was great. I highly recommend this one. Will drink again.

Bottle. Pours a deep orange with a little haze. Nice white head that disappeared pretty quickly leaving a little lace. Lots of sweet malt aromas, plenty of mead / honey and a little caramel. Also some earthy hops aromas and a little yeast. Flavours are quite sweet with heaps of malt and caramel. Roasted flavours near the finish followed by some hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is spot on. Nicelt balanced beer.

Pleasant sweet, fruity ale.  I dont understand how this could be considered a maibock, however.  Estery, fruity, honey-flavored characteristics are not unpleasant, but certainly resemble a West Coast ale more than a lager.  Nice warming character; reminds me of a lower alcohol version of Lagunitas Brown Shuggga.

Pours a clear amber under a thick head that dissipates rapidly, but leaves excellent lacing.

Malts come through strong in the nose. Slight bit of earthiness and some nice caramel/toffee sweetness.

Little bit of complex tastes going on here. Sweetness and slightly toasty malts. Mild hop kick. Little bready and fruity. Good balance.

Nice and creamy in the mouth. Just a tad to the lighter side of the scale, but still good.

Overall, a very easy drinking beer.

How many mead drinkers have smelled this familiar aroma.  Honey, malt, and fresh bready yeast dominate the nose.  Sweet malt, light hop, and nutty barley dominate the flavour.  Very nice hazy tupelo honey colour.  A little thin on the palate but overall a very smooth, drinkable ale.

Bottle. A sweet aroma, some bread, light sour. The white fizzy head has only a short duration,the body is red. The taste is light bitter, very dry in the mouth, the finish is a little bit medical. The body is dry, medium strong and with a normal duration. A nice Ale.

Got this 12oz bottle in Michigan while visiting family and drank it back home in Ireland.

Pours a slightly cloudy, copper gold color-very nice looking. Left about a 1/2 finger white head that didnt stick around for long.

Sweet, some maltiness, and some light hops notes hit the nose-all very balanced and nothing overpowering.

A good mix of hops, malts, sweet, and bitterness all come together quite nicely here. Tastes like asweet ale with some caramel hints

Goes down relatively smooth and well-rounded with a light-medium body and mild carbonation.

Id say that this is my first tasting of a Helles bock and I liked this version of the style, but I dont have alot to compare it to. The ABV is a bit high for me to make it a personal session beer. I think that you can get some Rogue beers here now too so that is nice-seems like they know what they are doing.

Pours a four-finger creamy head that fades quickly to a ring leaving some lace. Clear amber color. Hoppy nose. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Flavor is sweet/hoppy then a serious hoppy/bitter finish that doesnt really linger. $1.89 for a 12oz bottle from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.
Dead Guy is an alias for White Crane Bitter Ale it isnt anything like Dead Guy, different ABV, different look & taste:
White Crane pours a four finger cream head that fades slowly leaving a good lace. Cloudy brown/amber color.  Light carbonation and medium bodied. Malty/hoppy nose. Flavor is an almost sweet caramel, the hops are trying to dominate. $2.30 for a 12oz bottle from Glen Beverage Glen, NH.

This is a session drinker!

Pours a hazy orange amber with a 2 finger head. Lacing is pretty clingy and thick.

Smell is of sweet barley and hops. Well balanced aroma. Slightly spicy.

Taste is spot on my definition of ALE! Barley and hops are in perfect unison here. Not too much of either, and not too little. Sweet roasted, nutty barley and floral citrusy hops.

Mouthfeel is excellent! Getting the slight tingle from the bitterness and the slight thickness from the extra amounts of grains in here. Carbonation compliments both.

Drinkability is perfect. This is an all niter here!

Im still relatively new to the craft beer universe, but this and Dogfishs 60 min IPA are my favorites! These are my go tos when Im at the bar. Congrats to Rouge for another excellent beer!

bottle: pint glass: Great brew!  My first Heller Bock and very happy with the choice!  Poured a very deep brown, loads of visible carbonation which left almost 2 fingers of head.  At first it seemed thin and easy to drink, realized the brew was too cold.  After letting it sit, the flavors began to pop out... tons of malts, almost some oatmeal.  Undertones of citrus and earth, piny and bitter.  Very nice balance going on here...

0,33 l bottle, bought in Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam.
When i opened my bottle it flushed out like a fontain...The beer has a murky amber body with a medium off-white head what diminishes to a small lacing one.. Interesting and unidentifiable aroma. I do not know if i like it or no....It might be some malt and some sourish yeast with some fruits and some caramel. somesomesome. I am embarassed....Is this stuff an ale or a lager one? Or was it made with ale-yeasts on a lower temperature? Freaky beer...The flavor is malty and fruity with a bit of hop and honey. I do not know, i do not know....

Not sure what all the fuss is about this beer.  Decided to shell out the $7 for a bottle.  The overwhelming hop bitterness cancels out any malt taste.  Faint malt aroma.  Light body with a clean finish.

bottle: the label glows in the dark!!! Pours orangy gold with nice foamy head. Sweet and malty with a nice bitter finish. Great spicy notes. Maybe its just because Ive having so much oktoberfests, but it reminded me of that style... thirst quenching.

Pours  hazy gold with an off white head.
Aroma is earthy hops and light fruit notes.
The flavor was bitter grassy hops and sweet caramel like malts. Finish is bitter. Im on the fence over this beer.

pours out a pale cloudy yellow in color with a thin off white head that fell really fast, i barely got it to form one.  the body is a cloudy oarnge and has no bubbles that i can see rising in the glass.  the aromas are a sweet pale malt with apples and grass.  there is slight thin lacing along the glass.  there is a sweet toffee and caramel taste with a nice hoppy kick that was sutel and finished pretty dry.  the aftertaste is toasted malt and a resinous hop taste on the sides of the tongue.  thin to meduim bodied with nice carbonation and mouthfeel.
Golden to amber color.  Light fruity hoppy and sweet aroma.    Perfect balance of hops and malt.  Medium mouthfeel.  Fairly clean aftertaste.
Reddish and hazy. Nice light brown lasting head. Fresh aroma: Hops along with nutty maltiness. In your mouth there is smooth bitterness and toffee. Very lasting malty taste. Yum!
Bottled. Gold-ish color, tastes a little bitter. Not a lot of head. Less noticeable aroma at first.

On tap. Pours an amber golden color with a medium sized frothy white head. Aroma is mostly caramel and toasty malts, not bad, basic toasty, lightly buttery and biscuit. Flavor is hoppier than expected, getting some bite out of hops along with the caramel and toffee notes. A bit of nuttiness in the finish along with toasty malts. Not much bitterness, just sort of fades. Medium body and biting carbonation. Pretty sessionable considering the higher alcohol.
Tap. Poured a clear deep amber with no head.  Nose was malty and sweet. Light front with some malty sweetness in the finish. A bit bitter in the finish.
Pleasing hoppiness, with slight caramel notes. Nothing outstanding, but something I find myself returning to every now and then. Good beer.

Poured into a lager glass from a 650ml bottle.  Less like a heller bock and more of a sweet APA.  Aroma is malty with a lot of spice.  Light, bitter nose with a hoppy but well balanced body.  lots of bitterness and orange peel in the finish which lingers pleasantly.  Overall very satisfying with a bite that leaves a lasting impression.

I have had this one a few times now and was surprised to see that I did not rate it. It has a nice balanced aroma of fruit, toffee, and hops. It also seemed a bit nutty. It has a nice amber color with an off white head. Sweet, candyish flavors are what I notice first, followed by caramel, berries, and a nice, spicy malt character. Its balanced well with moderate hopping and a nice lingering aftertaste.

12oz bottle.  Pours a golden orange with a thin off white head with nice lacing.  Aroma is very mild, mostly sweet maltiness.  Taste is very malty to start, also some caramel in there, the middle is toasted malt, and the end reveals a bit of hop bitterness.  Easy drinking and smooth, a well balanced beer.  Very good.
UPDATED: FEB 9, 2014 Wonderful beer, great flavor, very smooth, nice copper color. I had a 12oz bottle.
I didnt know this to be a maibock style .... I thought this was an APA geared towards the masses - some flavor, nothing special.

Poured an off white head that was died quickly with decent lace on the pint glass. Decent light copper color with a little carbonation in the slightly hazy ale. There is a light toasted bread malt aroma that is challenged by a touch of grapefruit. You should find a light medium body and a crisp balanced mouthfeel with a slightly acidic short to average finish.

Draft 10.10.09

washed-out copper pour.  minimal to non-existent head.  sweet nose, with bready tendrils.  subtle roastiness with bitter finish.  sharp carbonation.  interesting interpretation of style.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2009 Poured orange with some visible carbonation and a smallish white head.  The aroma is complex: hops, bready malt, spicy yeast, and fruit.  The fruit reminds me if litchi and apricot.  The flavor is biscuity malt, apricot sweetness, and it finishes with a generously hoppy bitterness.

Poured from 12oz bottle.  Shiny copper in color with nice medium off white head.  Sweet malty nose with a bit of spice.  Flavor was sweet, bready, malty, fruity (apricots) and hops.  Overall not too bad.
Bottle. Pours an amber color with attractive loose head. Aroma is malty with a little spice. Flavors of biscuit, caramel, leather, spice, and some cherry. Nice finish. Good but nothing exciting.

30/09/2009. 750ml bottle.  Wow... its a highly hopped toasted oat porridge of a beer!  Maibock? Ale? Does not compute.  Nice simple beer, thats smoother than a babys bottom and very drinkable. If youre into melanoidin maltiness (like all those East Coast) then you just might fall in love with this Dead Guy.  This one doesnt quite grab me though.

Ive really liked all the Rogue beers Ive had so far. Moving their way up my list of favorite breweries. Had this at a little tasting I had and really enjoyed it. Copper pour with aroma of hops. Goes down really smooth. A very good beer

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2009 ~ Purchased this 12 oz bottle from Big Z Beverage in Huntington, NY. Found this 50% off, so at $1.25 I just had to give it a try. This is a nifty looking bottle with Japanese writing all over, and the Rogue name centered below. Appearance is light brown with a moderately good head. It has a light hoppy aroma, and a sweet pleasing taste. This beer is all right I guess - its just nothing that spectacular. ~
Been hearing a lot about this and it really didnt disappoint.  Great aroma of hop and malt.  Taste is hop with a sharp bitterness.

Light amber with loose off-white head. Aromas of sharp hops and malt, slightly roasted.  Slightly sweet, fairly bitter. Dry finish, sharp carbonation. A rich, hoppy, american interpretation of the style.  Decent brew; good all-nighter.

Not a bad beer per se, the Metropolitan Copper Lager I had before this one was much better.  Had this on tap at a mediocre bar, aroma is transparent and the taste is surprisingly hoppy (at least hoppier than I anticipated).  Meh.

Aroma is malty and a bit sweet. This is definitely a beer whose aroma does not betray its flavor. strong flavor of caramelized malt, slight taste of grapefruit. Bitterness is chorus to this concert of flavor. Wide spread distribution helps propagate the popularity of this beer. Maybe a slightly overratted
Floral/Sugar aroma, appearence is orange copper with white head. Flavour is a mix of sugar, a hint of breadiness & spice that finishes with a light flowery bittering finish.

On tap at Newport Pub.  Pours an orange amber with some lace.  aromas of brown sugar, biscuit and some citrus hop.  The palate on the tapped Dead Guy is nearly perfect.   The taste is a sweet sugariness with just a hint of bitter citrus.

Floral hoppy and malty aroma. Starts with very nice and strong hop flavour then maltiness appears which ballanced  by hop bitterness. Full body and right  not too high carbonation. Long and bitter aftertaste. Excellent brew.
Deep orange colour with medium white head.Aroma strong bitter with flavor of tosted malt and caramel,good full body and flowery hoppy finish.
Not as good as expected. The flavor left something to be desired. Next time Ill try it on tap.
Dead Guy poured orange.  Smells citrusy with  slight alcohol.  A little hops in the flavor, but balanced out nicely with enough malts.
US trip Aug/Sept 2009 - on tap at the Yardhouse - Smooth and creamy like an ESB with a weird sweetness to the finish that tastes a little sweaty and/or like licking a dead guy. Weirdly drinkable
22oz bottle from fred meyers, easy on the palate a nice sweet taste pretty malty has a honey taste.

BPW #15
On tap at BW3s in downtown Indy. Appearance is golden amber with little head. Sweet malt, light pepper, mild hop flavors, and slightly fruity. Mouth is pretty flat. This one is an ok serviceable beer.

Amber/Cider colored pour with a very generous amount of white foam and well covering slow lacing.  Subdued, somewhat hoppy aroma.  Hop bitterness from start to finish in taste.  Medium body.  Easy to drink, with little evident alcohol.
Bottle @ Goodbar Beer Club.  Nose is light honey malt, alcohol, undefined floral & tea hops.  Flavor is light caramel malt, slight butterscotch.  Nice solid bitterness with creeping alcohol.

Dans Bachelor Party Extended Weekend Rating #14 of 90. Tap at B-dubs downtown Indy. Pours deep golden, minimal head...much lighter in color than I expected, I dont know why I expected it darker, but I did. This has a sweet malty aroma with some hops mixed in. Taste is a good malt balance with earthy to citrusy hops. A decent amount of carbonation, and I wasnt blown away by the alcohol. Pretty good.
A golden beer with a decent head. Aroma was sweet, & malty. The taste was sweet, malty, & very bready with a taste that I can only describe as a malty middle.

Bottle - Pours a deep orange with a deep haze, off white head with a lazy fizz. Raw malt aroma with a citric undertone.  For a 6.5 ABV there is a very strong alcohol hit up front, afer that hit there is a bready, orange and malt hit.  Dry lingering finish, soft flowery hops.

Looks like a cloudy amber orange. Half finger of bubbly head. Looks like and IPA with more cloudiness. Looks thick & substantial.

Strong piney hop flavor. Heavy alcohol scent backed by a dry ale-malt smell. Citrusy to balance heavy alcohol. Good stuff.

Major blast of citrus (orange) and apricot flavor, with a strong alcohol flavor that is offset by the dry, bready malt. Strong but balanced, not overdone. A real strong ale, no extreme beer fetish.

Feels milky and thick. Smooth like a hefeweizen. Buttery and leaves a watery film. Strong but really drinkable. Nuanced and flavorful, especially considering that its so strong.

Pours a golden orange with a white head. Strong wheat nose, some bread and a lightly roasted/toasty note hidden in there. Taste is clean malts, and a mellow bitterness. The taste is long. A really good lager.
Extremely good, maybe they will have some troubles with the copyrights of the logo but the beer is defenitely good.

Mt Vesuvius was bottled up as thing gushed out all over the counter and my beer list.  Mildly hazed amber with a rapidly descending off-white topper.  Aroma of heavy toffee, toasted malt, fruity yeast and some citrus hops.  Taste of toffee, caramel, light citrus, alcohol and a touch of bubblegum.  Moderate bitterness and sweetness on the finish.
Had this beer on tap at Mad mex Robinson under other name Meierbock.  Really great especially the buttery ketone flavors.  Plenty of malt and hops, fragrant, clean finish

I love this beer. The grainy, malty, floral honey nose, the dark amber pour, the thin off white head, the strong but unusually well balanced sugar and bitterness, the honey, pollen, grass taste. I dislike the carbonation a little bit but it remains a remarkable session ale.

=the key word for this beer is umoffensive, if unexceptional. 

s=nice mix of the key ingredients. 

T=very good and sneaky, malts slightly overpower hops for a fun ride. 

M=smooth, surpisingly so. Not much in the way of carbonation, which is how I enjoy it. 

For me, this fits the definition of my quintessential session beer.
Bottle. Dark orange color. Agrumes and other pale fruits are dominant in the taste. Fizzy and hoppy, the yeast is also very present. Even with all this, Ive found that beer to be kinda bland.

Bottle. This one had been on my list for awhile and it did not disappoint. Pours dark reddish (similar to the label), with a crisp white head. The aroma is citrusy and malty, but with a hint of something darker and heavier. Flavor is outstanding with a powerful finish. Really great brew.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2011 8/21/09. One of my favorite stand-by beers.  Great malty brew with touches of fruit and citrus, like they say.  Good stuff. Re-rate 7/1/11. On tap in a pint glass. Slightly hazy amber pour with a small creamy tan head. Malty, caramel aroma with a hint of bubblegum. Sweet, malty entry with lingering bubblegum and a touch of dry coffee. Hints of chocolate in there as well. Not bad, but not as good as I remember when I was younger.
Bottle. A lot going on in this one. Rich malty aroma. Flavor reminded me of yeast and fruit, citrus maybe? Enjoyable.

20 oz draft at Bar Louie.  Orange/amber with frothy off-white head.  Aroma is biscuity malt, sweet and a bit smokey.  Taste of caramel malt, some citrus, and a bit of hops.  Medium body, a bit creamy and quite carbonated.  Not bad!

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear amber-orange with an average creamy off-white head that disapates to a thin layer but lasts throughout. Minimal lacing on the glass.  Nice sweet, malty aroma with caramel and a hint of citrus. Flavor is moderately sweet, some caramel, a slight toastiness and a spicy, bitter hop finish. Nicely balanced. Full bodied.

I have been pleasantly surprised by every rogue I have tasted so far, and this one is no different.  DGA is just an overall drinkable beer, ROGUE recommends you drink it wile eating pork/BBQ, but it goes well with just about any protein or just by its self.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2011 Bottle. The pour was a mildly cloudy copper/amber with an orange hue and a small (less than 1 finger) off white frothy head that had decent retention and good lacing. 

The aroma was of toasted caramel malts, citrus hops and a biscuit yeast with strong citrus, toffee and caramel notes.

The taste was sweetly bitter with a hint of caramel in the beginning then progressed into much bitterer flavor with a nice dose of citrus at the end, I am guessing a little lemon and grapefruit. The flavor stuck around long enough to let one enjoy the nice citrusy hoppy aftertaste.

Mouthfeel had a smooth creamy texture and a medium body with a prickly carbonation.
 
Overall a super refreshing ale that had a nice blending of malts, hops and citrus.  And one that is most definitely worth drinking again.

Bottled 355ml from crackedkettle.com. Hazy copper beer with a small light beige head. Malty aroma with hints of raisin, fennel, caramel, cherry, walnut, marshmallows, wood, berries and faint bittering hops. Sweet malt accentuated taste. Full bodied. A lot of fennel, raisin, walnut, berries and caramel showing up. Decent bitterness. Not much lacework. Long malty finish where some bittering hops sneak in. A nice beer.

Draft.  Pours clear amber with no head (for my pour anyway- Im not sure how so many others are getting such a thick head on this one).  Aroma of hops, toffee, malt.  Flavor is busy, with hops, toffee, malt, wheat, citrus, and spice, and both bitter and sweet.  Medium body.  A lot of fun to drink because it has a lot going on.

Light, hazy amber, big frothy beige head with good retention. The pale malt aroma has an unmistakable edge of peanut butter, interesting but not really desirable to me.  Flavors are a strongly floral on top of a big, honey-bread dough-nougat malty mess. Other contributing flavors are nut, mandarin orange, dust, and a bit of papery oxidation at the end. Theres a lot of flavor going on, but it doesnt work together for me. Full bodied, somewhat sticky mouthfeel.

(35.5cl bottle) Hazy, deep golden colour with a thick off-white foamy head. Sweet and bready cara-malty aroma with a distinctive touch of biscuits and butterscotch. Sweet flavour, medium to full bodied with a soft mouthfeel. Robust pale and cara-malty base with liquid biscuits; sweet and malt-accented finish with a whiff of herbal and resiny hops. Hearty pale Bock, just a tad on the sweet side (11.VIII.09).
This is a tasty, yet bitter beer.  Im not much for overly bitter beers, so I likely wouldnt enjoy having more than one of these at a time.  It was fairly tasty though.

A nicely complex ale. Poured a reddish gold with a foamy head, which faded in minutes. Smelled of sweet malts. The taste was dynamic, ringing with traces of honey, molasses, and bread. Very smooth with a mildly yeasty afteraste. I enjoyed drinking this beer very much.
A very pleasant beer, malty but balanced. Gorgeous deep amber color. Honestly, this page is the first time I thought of it as maibock; Id always thought of it as a slightly underhopped pale ale.
