Bottle.  Aroma is of fruit (apricot?) and malt.  Flavor is initially surprisingly sweet, a swirl of caramel malt and orange marmalade, and pine.  It stays fairly sweet throughout, though the finish reveals a hint of bittering hops that I assume were present from the start but overshadowed.  This beer is very tasty, thats for sure.  However, my quite fond memories of this beer when I first started drinking craft brew have proved off-base.  I think I might have placed merit on this beer more on the name and not the quality:  tasty as it is, I feel the malt is just a little too forward and sticky; the flavor also fades a bit too quickly.  For example, Smuttynose’s Maibock has much better balance.
Had on Tap at the Tav in Ellensburg WA. has a nice cooper pour with an off white creamy head. the hops were apparent but not overwhelming. has a nice caramel finish.
I hope when I’m dead I’m this malty.  Interesting body and aroma.  Nothing overpowering here, but pleasantly subtle.  Balance like a see-saw.  Very nice.  And the name sells the whole package.

I bought this a while ago because I liked the name and was pleasantly surprised. Finally getting around to rating it. Copper pour with a creamy head. Sweet and spicy aroma. Taste is interesting for a bock, its sweetness is balanced with a lot of hops. Nice finish.

Tried it for the first time in Oregon last month. Found a sixer at Windy City today. As good as I remembered. Nice redish tinged brown color. Aroma was less than I thought for the alcohol content. I like the carmel finish.

Bottle from the_Captain. Thanks Mark! LOVE the aroma on this. Little bit of fruit, little bit of a malt smell, smell a bit like cider too. Pours a golden brown with a nice off white head. Tasteslike a bitter/Lager combo to me. Nuts and malt/little bit oh honey maybe? Very dry palate that I dont care for but other than that a solid brew.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2008 I wasnt too sure about how this would turn out, but I am glad I tried it.  Very tasty and refreshing despite the higher alcohol content.  I think the key here was the clever mix of caramel flavors with the abundance of hops.
Carmel honey color.  Medium bodied bitterness and average balanced flavor and finish.  Malty aroma.  Not much head or lacing.  Not for novices.  But not enough for a family get together.

bottle: I was suspicious of how this one would taste given the relatively high alcohol content. My fears were for not and I should have known that Rogue seems to be incapable of brewing a bad beer. The high quality malts come through and the only thing that suggest that this is a strong beer is the label. There is no excessive taste of alcohol whatsoever. Excellent brew and a cool back story on its origins.
Very solid beer.  I was surprised with how good it was.  Strong alcohol..........................
Red-amber in color with a small off-white head. Aroma is mainly of caramel, nuts and a hint of hops. Flavor is of malts and caramel with a little fruitiness and hops.

bottle:  This pale bock was very good.  I’m big on malts and this delivered the goods.  I was wary of a beer 6.6% because often the alcohol content overwhelms the palate.  I think i might have found a new style of beer to enjoy.  Rogue puts out quality stuff.

Can’t believe the ratings that this beer is getting.  This beer was served at my favorite watering hole for a short time, and it was one of the worst beers I’ve ever had.  It only lasted a month due to poor feedback.  Maybe I’m missing something here.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2012 An old favorite of mine, had so many times Ive long since lost count. Funny but Ive always thought of this as a hoppy red rather than as a maibock. Not that the styles are totally unrelated, but whatever Dead Guy is, its a very floral, generously hopped beer that has a full and sweet malt presence, making this one of Rogues more balanced and enjoyable offerings.

Bottle.  Hazy amber with a small diminishing head.  Aroma is sweet malt and yeast.  Flavor is malty yeast with some tangy citrus.  Pretty decent, but nothing spectacular about this beer.  Not really what I expected as far as a "Maibock"

355ml bottle 
6.6% ABV 
I tried this beer on July 1, 2008 at Smokeless Joes in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a translucent dark golden red with a thin white ring for a head.  The aroma was sweet malt, and some floral hoppiness.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied with light to medium carbonation.  The flavour is a little sweet with a definite hoppy taste, not grapefruit strong, but still hoppy.

Bottle from The_Captain, served in a shaker glass. Thanks Mark. Pours amber with a fluffy white head. Smells of nuts and grass. Tastes include the aforementioned nuts and grass plus some caramel character. Lightly bitter throughout. Pretty nice session lager. (pacman yeast? aren’t they an ale strain?)

Slightly hazy amber pour with a medium foamy head that lasts.  Nutty caramel malt and citrus aroma.  Nice sweet malty flavor with hints of fruit and hops.  A touch of bitterness on the finish.  Well carbonated, refreshing on the palate.  Good.
Unbelievable that I haven’t rated this yet.  Awesome beer, great citrusey hop flavor, perfect malt and bittering hop balance.
Pours amber with white foam.  This has a nice dry finish with a balanced hop-malt flavor.  Highly carbonated, but quite nice, with a strong bitter finish.
22 oz bottle.  Pours a burnt orange with thin white head.  Great sweet, nutty flavor with a dry hop finish.  Nicely balanced.  Really liked this.
Hoppy aroma of toffeish-malts, orange, lemon. Malty, orange-fruity flavor finishes quite bitter.

Halloween Growler: Murky amber in color w/ a small, soapy off-white head that leaves a nice little curtain of lacing behind. Aroma is of sweet caramel w/ a hint of piney hops. Sweet malty flavor, mostly caramel w/ a slight hop bitterness that sneaks up on you. Syrupy sweet coating/aftertase lingers on & on. Not bad, but drinking more than one will be a chore for me...very sweet.

pours a hazy amber color with nice tan head.  malty air in the aroma.  there was a touch a sweetness in the taste that was off-putting to me.  not a bad beer, but i am not sure what the brewer was trying to accomplish.

I have had this beer many times before but have never rated it.  Its usually my standby when encountering a limited selection.  There is a refreshing, fruity quality to this brew, with a moderately dry, hoppy finish.  This would be a great summertime beer if you were in the mood for an IPA alternate.  I can smell the grilled chicken with the lime, chili pepper rub now.  Viva el hombre de la muerte.
very hoppy - cloudy - some citrusy flavors that linger on the tongue... had it at a bar in new brunswick
Slighty hazy golden color.  Off white head that mosty diminishes. Not much of an aroma present.  Thin mouth feel with a taste of alcohol in the finish.  Just didn’t do it for me.

Imbided a 22oz from Total wine last evening.  Had it before and while it is a decent bock Rogue’s done better.  Colored like a dark lager, with a respectable albeit a bit thin head.  Outstanding marketing on this product though, the label and title really catch the eye.

Bottle. Thank you LCBO! Appearance is orangy-amber with medium carbonation and a thick cream coloured head. Aroma is awesome.....malty carmels, licorice, floral hops, citrus and fresh garden herbs. In terms of flavour, everything gets better as this beer warms.....buiscutty malts, carmel, ripe fruits and a little alcohol followed by a mean hop kick. Mouthful is creamy, but just a tad thin. Overall an excellent beer.
Pours a honey color, with a thin white head.Aroma is sweet and malty. Flavor is slightly sweet and mildly bitter. Finishes smooth Very good.

Dark honey-orange colored. A bit cloudy. Small but nice foamy head. Aromas reminded me of lemon caramels every single time I smelled it ’till the end. Strong. Tastes are those of caramel, malt and a bit resiny from the hops. Good medium body. Liked it.

Pours a cloudy honey with a negligible head and lacing. Nose is very light. Whiffs of grass and citrus. On tasting, malt announces itself with a flourish, then blends in nicely with hops and pine flavors. Mouthfeel is light but with a good structure, and finish is crisp, smooth and lasting.
Pours a darker almost red color.  Not much head. Very pleasant sweet malt aroma.  Caramel and malt flavor with a honey aftertaste, light-medium body.

I have enjoyed this beer in the bottle for years and only occasionally on draft when I found my way down south. Now it is on tap in Vancouver at the alibi and it’s certainly the star of the show. Red and sweet and malty - maybe not a session beer but one I’ll be having a lot of until the keg runs out. Brilliant.

Appearance: Dark orangy-red brown. Little bit of head.
Aroma: Not much, actually. Bit of fruit and malt.
Taste: Sweet and some bitterness. Earthy aftertaste.
Info: 650ml bottle, 7/6-2008, 193/500

pours rich golden amber, malty and sweet honey on the nose.  quite decent on the palate, not overly carbonated.  Nice sweetness in flavour and relatively smooth finish.  overall not overly impressed (perhaps because I was looking forward to trying it).  It is a decent brew but nothing that stands out.

12oz bottle.  cloudy amber color with a small off white head and some lacing.  smell of malt, yeast, spice and flowers.  caramel malt and earthy grass in the taste.   biscuity and slightly dry finish.  well balanced.
bottle: Amber in colour. Sweet aroma maybe a bit of honey and you can tell there will be some malty taste...and there is, plus a tiny amount of hops. Didnt excite me too much.
Pours an amber honey with a white head. Aroma is hops and honey. Flavor is honey and sweetened hops. Floral notes. Body is medium but light to fair carbonation.

Excellent bronze pour with foamy head. Malty aroma-wet grass/flowers. Very prominent carbonation feel.  Sweet molasses flavor with a lingering bitter finish.  Actually was a bit too sweet for my taste.

Finially time to review on of the first craft beers I ever had.  Pours amber with a dissapating head.  Nice malty aroma with hints of caramel, spice, and very sweet.  Mouthfeel is thick with little carbonation.  Caramel and malt in the flavor with a nice sweet malt finish.  Another nice brew from Rogue.

A medium reddish brown, rather large head. Dont notice a distinct aroma particularly. A bit sweet, not too hoppy, had a malty roasted aftertaste. Plenty of carbonation, and pleasant after taste. Easy drinking, mellow, a nice new addition to the lcbo. a little pricey, however,

draft at ruby tuesday: pours a light ice tea colour with a small foamy off white head. a good aroma of caramel malt, slight citrus spice, touches of yeast and hops are there too. flavour is very nice full of malt, citrusy spice yeast, and a lingering of hops very good beer

UPDATED: APR 14, 2012 12 oz bottle from the LCBO. pours amber with a solid tan head that lasts forever. nice toffee malt aroma with some subdued floral hops. flavours are generously malty with hop bitterness showing in the end. very well done. smooth and sessionable at 6.6%. i could drink this one everyday.

Copper with a big white head that goes quickly. Nose is sweet with a bit of hops and some sweet alcohol. Mouth is alcohol, malty, smoke, pine nut, beech, hops, chocolate in order of appearance.  A good, interesting, solid beer. Nice.
Copper color.  Med-Full bodied with a fair amount of hoppiness.  Hints of caramel with a bit of chewiness.

Pours a mild amber with stark white head.  Super sweet aroma - molasses and caramel, honey and raisins.  Knock you in the mouth flavor.  Starts full, with a unique bitter creaminess - kind of like a sour ale, but not.  Then moves straight to a full on malt parade down the back of the throat with a kick of alcohol.  Damn good.  (JesseMs evaluation is more detailed, and more accurate.)

Bottle.  Good looking amber but with a fizzy head that goes away too fast.  The aroma is enjoyable and interesting.  Kinda of a honey/toffee mixed with a little raisins.  Bitter at first then sweet while kind of tingly down the throat.  Rogue has disappointed me before, but this did not.  Maybe my expectations were low.
draft. delicate honey aroma. lightly hopped, mildly malty palate.  biscuit flavors.  an easy drinking beer with some depth of flavor.  a solid session beer.

Bottle. Copper-y red with a decent white head. Floral hops and malts dominate. Starts bitter, sweet and slightly hoppy, then the malt hits, and the finish is nice and crisp. Slightly watery and mildly carbonated. Overall solid, will be buying lots of this thanks to the LCBO!

Pours a honey amber, with a nice creamy white head. The aroma is fruit malts and floral hoppiness. The flavour is top notch. A touch of bitterness at first, that gives way to some awsome malty, caramel, chewy toffee goodness, a bit of dried fruit, and then a hoppy bitter finish. Over all the beer is a little sweeter then I expected, especially after trying some of rogues other beers, but the sweetness is done well. I really enjoyed this beer, and Im glad the LCBO is finally starting to get some good american beer, even if it is only a month at a time.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 355ml bottle from the LCBO (yeah, you read that right, I was surprised too). Seeing as the last 10 ratings are more or less uesless if you want to know what this beer actually tastes like, Ill try to describe it the best I can (seriously guys, get you s*** together and analyze, dont just tick things off when you have them). Pours a deep copper with a medium, creamy, white head. Aroma is a nice aromatic blend of hops, but also fruity malts and some interesting ester characters. Flavour is quite interesting, bitter upfront, making way for some creamy sweet malts, toffee, caramel, fruits of vague distinction. Its actually decently complex, more so than I was execting. At only 6.6% it feels a little boozy in the finish, though not in an unpleasant way. Quite sweet and malty, with some good bitter balance provided by the ample amount of hops. A pretty neat beer that seems to really open up as it warms, revealing more sweet layers. Im glad the LCBO brought this one in.
Pours a copper color. The nose is like a traditional brown ale. Comes across the palate smoothly. It has nice clean lingering finish.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2009 Kick ass label forces you to take a closer look. Pours a copper color with a off white head. Sweet nose not to over powering. Smooth taste with a nice clean finish. Rogue is doing something right. Def will try it again
Dark amber body, crisp white head with a good lattice.  Heavy bread aroma. Medium palate, expected it to be heavier.  Long finish.  A good beer, but not a personal favorite.
Thick smooth mouthfeel.  Tastes thicker than it looks.  Dark burnt umber color, with a off white to almost tan head.
$11 a six-pack? I got a six-pack for $7.99 plus tax and really would have rather had a Two Hearted Ale. Its pretty good, pretty creamy and soft and smooth but not really justifying the higher price.

A decent brew, especially for the price, at $11 bucks a six pack its not much more expensive then corona and its a hell of alot better. If i was on a beer budget I would probably buy A LOT more of this.
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2009 This is my favorite beer that I have tasted so far.  Overall great palate and excellent finish.  Falling in love with all of the Rogue beers but this is my favorite.
If you dont like this beer, stick with wine coolers. It has slight fruit undertones, and just the right amount of hops. Perfect for any time of year, not too heavy not too light. A truley great brew.

Reddish body with a white head, aroma not very strong. I tasted a lot of maltyness with some fruit undertones and a slight hop flavor. Not bad, but it tasted too carbonated and certainly not worth the price.

Pours dark amber with little to no head. Aroma of light malts, caramel and a bit of herbal hops. Also a bit of chlorine. That one took me a while to nail, but its definitely that all-too familiar hotel hot tub smell. The flavor is milder than I expected - this would work really well as an eisbock (frozen/concentrated), but as is, it seems diluted. Luckily the chlorine didnt translate to the flavor - caramel malts and citrus rind, with floral / herbal hops on the back end. Palate is disappointing - I want this to be thicker. Not bad, but certainly not worth the price.
Light brown colour. Beautiful nose. Soft taste including lemon and grapefruit. A really nice beer with a nice bite of hops in the end.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2008 As white crane - bitter, deep, and luxurious. As Dead guy ale. Dead simple. Nice lace, head and body as White crane, but very nice as White crane. 

Glass: Concave Pilsener
Purchased at: Circle Liquors Super Saver, Pennington, NJ
Price: $2.50
Size: 12 fl oz
ABV: 6.6 %
Estimated Calories: 160C
RateBeer Rating: 82

Aroma 8 out of 10
Intensity: Middle
Balance: more Sweet
Impression: Nice

Malt Flavor: Grain Bread Sweet
Hops Flavor:Spice Resin
Other:
Notes: Very nice from an aroma standpoint.

Appearance 4 out of 5
Color: Amber
Clarity: Brilliant
Head Retention: Persistent
Notes: A beautiful beer. Brilliant, clear, and golden.

Flavor 7 out of 10
Intensity: Faint
Balance: Sweet
Impression: Nice
Malt Flavor: Grain Bread Sweet Toast Nut
Hops Flavor: Earth Floral
Other: Mild
Notes: Not an overwhelming flavor - not watery at all, but not hoppy nor very malty either. Deep in solidity.

Palate 4 out of 5
Mouthfeel
Sensation: Creamy
Body: Full
Carbonation: Faint
Finish
Length: Long
Intensity:Middle
Balance: middle
Notes: A very well balanced beer. Dull in impact, but not in craft. Well done.

General Impression: 15 out of 20
Craftmanship: middle to Excellent
Freshness: Fresh
Personal Taste: Liked
Notes: Rogue know what they are doing, but I have more likely favorites from them then Dead Guy. They do the craft very well.

750ml.  If this beer is indicitive of Maibock then this isnt my style at all and I will stay away for a bit.  From the first sip I regretted buying this.  It seemed overcarbonated too - not tons of little bubbles but lots of big ones.  The taste was just not good for me.

This is that perfect beer Ive been looking for. Lets be honest, even beer gurus need a brew on occasion that is NOT insanely hop driven, over-the-top ABV, nor sweetened like dessert. We just need a good solid option. Enter stage left, Dead Guy Ale. This may be the most well-balanced beer Ive had. It opens and closes with bread, and never are the hops overpowering, nor is it potbellied in malt. It is remarkably clean, but still complex. Not overly carbonated. Excellent with food. It is what macros pretend to be: clean, well-adjusted. The difference being this brew accomplishes with flying colors.

Reddish, honey color with a one-finger head that left a film throughout. Aromas of bread and malts, very little hops. Taste is the same, includes a bit of fruit - not citrus, more like pear. Medium to full bodied, very smooth and drinkable, nicely carbonated.

I was a little disappointed in this one and I am generally more than pleased w/ Rogues products.  Pours into a nice hazy, copper color with a nice fluffy white/off-white head.  Has notes of carmel with a roasted flavor on the finish.  It is a little flat, perhaps I expected it to have a little more texture and bitterness and perhaps a larger floral/citrus bouquet?  Not bad, but not great either.
12oz bottle poured a honey gold with a malty aroma, very dry and bitter...overall it just isnt my kind of beer.

Bottle. Hazy orange to brown beer with small white head. Rich malty aroma with aromatic hops. Some sweet fruity notes. Bitter finish. Flavor is bitter and very malty, though not sweet. Good hoppy bite in the finish. Full bodied and bitter palate with long finish. Thick mouthfeel thanks to malts. Matiness and bitter are in good balance. Overall a very malty and bitter beer with with enjoyable mouthfeel.

I must have been unfortunate with this bottle, bought @ Knightly Spirits in Orlando in February 08 and drunk in UK. There was no head, the beer poured a hazy red colour and lacked any discernable taste. This is the first US beer which has failed to impress and not typical of other Rogue Ales I have drunk.

~Pours a cloudy golden amber colour with white disappearing head.
~Sweet and caramel malt aroma, a bit of spiciness.
~Taste is sweet and raisiny. Starts like honey and ends a little salty.
~Feels a little thick, but smooth. Abrupt finish.
~I normally dont like sweet beers, but this one is pretty good. Sweetness 
takes me right to the edge of being too overbearing. Interesting beer.

Interesting flavor mix - my first maibock. Maltiness is a bit more present but still blended well. Hops still there in the nose and on the finish, leaving a slightly dry palate. More drinkable than most stronger, hoppier pale ales, but still in that taste theme minus some hoppiness.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2008 Loved this beer. Aroma was very nice, very fruity. Flavor was malty at first, but well balanced. Really, really easy to drink. Very smooth, very enjoyable taste. Highly recommended.
Clear amber with a fresh, citrus hop aroma.  Classic ale flavor.  Smooth, rich flavor with mild bite.  Very enjoyable and fun to serve friends.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 Golden honey color wearing a nice white cap. Hop then more malt hits my nose. Nice even palate. Flavors are arranged evenly. A well made brew. Nothing overdone, nothing missing. Like a special bitter. The younger, deader brother to Brutal bitter. Probably a better session beer.
great session beer - good flavor, aroma - excellent mix of malt flavor with hops.

Super easy to drink the flavor is not the most memorable but its enjoyable with a nice balance. Its not the greatest beer in the world but i might pick it up again.  Perhaps the style is a touch bland for my tastes

12oz.  Pours clear amber with a white head that leaves quickly.  Nose is a bit subdued, but shows some dried cherries and caramel.  Body shows some more caramel, a bit of honey, some earl grey tea, and of course some bitter lemon rind from the hops.  Palate is very good with a certain amount of viscosity and dry finish.  Some lager-like properties when the finish lingers.  A good beer.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2008 Pours  slightly cloudy orange color, with a malty aroma and loose head. Taste is slightly malty, tasted a little watered down. Not my favorite, but something I would buy again. Goes great with pork chops
Poured orangish-brown from a bottle with a thin head. Malty aroma, very light taste. Not very memorable, and somewhat expensive.

Always an old reliable. This one pours nicely with a big head copper coloured body, and nice retention in the head. Best off the tap, in my opinion. It is full bodied with plenty of retention, and a wonderful creamy mouthfeel.
Hazy amber with medium off white head. Sweet aroma with notes of caramel, ripe fruits and malt. Flavor likewise with a light bitter end.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 22 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a slowly collapsing off-white head. Dry woody aroma hops. Medium sweet initially. Mildly hops flavoured. Light woody note. Mild bitterness into the finish. 6-3-7-3-13=3.2

12 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a minimal white head. Light spiced and light hoppy and cardboardish. Light citric and hoppy flavoured with a decent caramel malty flavour. Smooth and malty finish with a light bitterness and fruity note coming through.7-3-7-3-13=3.3

Bottle. [Courtesy of yespr, thanks buddy] Average thick creamy head that mostly lasted. Fair display of lacework. Cloudy amber colour. Aroma of mild hops, grain, caramel, fruit, bread. Over the palate came mild herbal notes. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation and light dry texture. Moderated bitter and sweet flavour in balance. Dry and bitter finish.

Coppery colored with little white head. Sweet, caramelly and strongly nutty aroma with still fine hops and lemon. Not the most traditional bock but Ill take it. Medium bodied. Flavor is also fine with same nuts dominating, aftertaste turns to finely hopped with some flowers and some grains. Maybe hints of bocky spices here, still hard to compare German ones.
Good beer with lots of aromas and a great overall appearance. Not what you would exprect from a "German" style beer but still good

Pours a deep amber color with a nice rocky head.  Aromas include an appetizing mix of roasted malt, caramel, and figs.  Medium bodied, with a complex malt taste that gives way to a well-rounded hop bitterness.  Long finish with lingering hints of molases, sweet malt, and dark fruits.  This is a well balanced beer with a complex interplay of sweet malt flavors and bitter hop flavors, very versatile beer.  Try it with spicy barbeque or mexican food.
Bottle. Really sweet and fruity aroma with hints of caramell. Flavor is really fruity and sweet with a nice hop touch to it. Finishes with a bitter and a bit malty tone.
12 oz. bottle (bottled as White Crane) from Bottleworks.  Very nice dark ruby color, and a taste to match.  Brown sugar, and nicely roasted malt and maybe just a hint of rye.
Nice amber color with a very large frothy head. Strong and bitter at first, but it got better at the end.
my first heller bock.  thought it was an amber till i saw it on here.  that being said, it kinda tasted like a standard amber.  caramel/malty, small hop presence.  nice beer.
Bottle.  Dark amber pour.  Sweet malt aroma with just a little fruit.  The taste was malty with a touch of bitter at the finish.  Good carbonation.  Its OK.
Bomber. Pour orange copper, hazy with a dissapering head. Aromas of malts and caramel. Taste malty, fruity . Bitter but not overwhelming dry finish.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2008 12 fl oz bottle. wow. wheaty, bitter, sweet mallty and fruity all extremly well blended into one bottle yummy! amberish in pour, nice frothy head with some substance. alcholo hidden but noticable in the after taste.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2008 This is what I want a beer to be.  Medium amber colored, big white fluffy head, clean and crisp, little bit bitter and a lasting clean finish.  That and a scary ass bottle.  Instant classic.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2008 330ml bottle (Opus K, Lohja) 280308 shared with FatPhil and Anna
Color:dark amber, flat head few bubbles
Scent:Fruits,sweet hops pine
Taste:strong hops,pine, somehow sharp, fruity.alcohol presents
Re-rated 210508

Bottle at Bishops Arms Järntorget göteborg: Hazy red colour,flat head. Aroma of lots of US hops, and nice sweet/fruity nose. Flavor is sweet and fruity, some caramelly mouthfeeling,medium body, and has a nice medium fruity/hopy finish. Nice.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2008 Pours golden-red with practically no head. It tastes good, kinda sweet but a little thin. The hops are not strong, yet they seem unsupported somehow. This beer is fine and I could drink plenty of it.

P.S. For some reason Im tasting white grape in this beer. Also it starts to look like white grape juice once you get down to the bottom of the glass. Huh

Strait out of the bottle into a pilsner glass this brew has an amazing cloudy orange color with a slightly red tint. A good amount of head that is not quick to dissipate. Upon first sniff i get a sweet hoppy smell. When I dig a a bit deeper a muted fruit scent is detected. It has a very balanced taste: Clean wheat with a delightfully mild bitterness which seems to complement the flavor nicely. The mouthfeel is very smooth all the way through. I hate to use the same descriptor twice but it finishes absolutely cleanly begging you to drink more. All in all this is a highly drinkable beer. I could easily enjoy a few of these on an average night with some good food and great company.
Taste is strong , but not overpowering . Like the slight tase of the hops at the end. Very good beer , sip and enjoy !!

Aroma:
Notes of roasted and melanoidin malts. Slightly earthy.
Appearance:
Deep golden/copper, brilliant, with a persistent white head and light lacing.
Flavor:
Roasted malt and bready/toasty in the front, with some alcohol in the middle and end, along with some light bitterness in the after.
Mouthfeel:
Medium body, with a light bite from the carbonation and very light astringency from rosted malt - possibly some tanin extraction.

Fantastic beer!! Definitely a staple in a good beer collection, but not for the faint of palate.

pours a rich golden/orangish color with a nice half inch thick foamy head.. a bit of a bitter bite that mellows into a subtle sweet flavor on the back of your tongue.. i happened to have enjoyed it more after having it sit for a few minutes instead of cold right out of the fridge, a very nice beer
Rogues Dead Guy Ale is a little sweet, not too hoppy, and there are roasted malts in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2009 small whitish head that disappears quickly and leave no lace behind. Orangey in color with a little bit of haze like a dark hefe. Smell is of pine and lemon/lime citrus with a touch of doughy yeast mixed in. Hops come through on the taste along with some carbonation that settles nicely.

Bottle pours a honey amber color with a foamy tan head.  Lots of caramel malts in the aroma, some rye and honey.  Flavor is malty and sweet with a slight bitterness in the finish.  Smooth and easy to drink.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a light brown with a bit of amber, little to no head.  Smells primarily roasted malts with a mix of citrus.  Good medium body with a sweet flavor and a slight tinge of bitterness.
My firts rogue product.  Nice aroma clean crisp color.  Flavor was moderate hops and overall a good ale.

Pours a cloudy orange, almost like a heavy hefeweizen.  Pretty.  Light, but steady cabonation.  At first glance it almost looks like a chick beer.  Smells sweet.  Hard to taste anything else.  Very syrupy and fairly heavy.  just caught a taste of something fruity (ignoring the beer club members gay jokes).  Interesting beer, but nothing I would buy again if I saw it on tap.  Its just so sweet...

Pours a hazy orange / brown color with a small white soapy head. Aroma of malt, hops, citrus and caramel. Taste is hops, malt, yeast, citrus, quite a bit of sweetness battle the formerly mentioned elements and they sorta just make friends when they go down the hatch. This beer was one of my "gateway" craft beers, and while it isnt amaizng it is a pretty solid and well done brew.

Poured a deep amber with minimal white head. 

Smelled of caramel malts and hops primarily, underlying hints of citrus.

Taste was similar to the scent, the hops make an appearance at the beginning and end of the taste, malts and fruits hitting you in the middle.

The hops left my mouth a little bitter and a little dry.

Definately drinkable, certainly not a bad ale. 

Id heard good things about Dead Guy Ale, and though it didnt quite live up to all the hype (IMO), it was certainly worthy of some praise.

Serving type: bottle

Pours a hazy amber. On the nose, it has aromas or bread, honey, and malts. Nice malty flavor with a balance of hops to it. Almost a floral/honey character with this one. I really enjoyed this beer. There is only one drawback to it: $13 for six beers. Thats a bit steep in my book. Anyways, solid brew and i would recommend it and i probably would drink it more often if it were not for the price.

Pours clear copper with fluffy off white head. Aromas of bread dough, malt and honey. Big malt flavor and some sweetness. Medium body with mild carbonation and a smooth mouthfeel. A pretty good maibock.

Im not a huge fan of this beer. It is the most accessible Rogue Ale, but Im always wishing (when I come across a store that only carries Dead Guy) that something ELSE was their flagship brew. It pours amber with an off-white head. The aroma is very sweet. The taste was too sweet for me, with a lot of citrus flavors. I wish I liked it more, but I dont.

Bottle. Pours a hazy amber/orange with a big off-white head. Sweet aroma. Floral hops and malt. Becomes candy-like as it warms. Has a weird note  reminds me of chlorine when used in swimming pools, but it doesnt actually smell like chlorine. As it warms, it turns into a more spicy note. Flavour is sweet with notes of raisins, bread and milk. Finish is sweeter than the initial flavour. Notes of prunes. Lingering bitterness as well as milky notes. That weird chlorine-thing is here as well. Dont really know what to make of this Its not bad, but doesnt really do anything for me. But could do without the milky notes. Hmm 13-04-08.
On tap.  This is a nice well balanced ale.  you would now guess that it was 6.6%.  some flavors of hops and malts.

12 ounce bottle-  pours a nice amber golden with an average wheat colored head.  Aroma is sweet and floral.  Taste was almost too sweet with a citrus flavor predominating.  Not bad at all, but I think the sweetness would soon become cloying.  Worth a try.

tap first, 12oz bottle after.... tap was oxidized, gross and nasty, from Ruby Tuesdays in Athens, guessing they dont have much traffic or clean the lines.

bottle: much better, pours a nice gold amber, with a near white head, taste is intriguing, some initial hop taste then immediately carmel malty goodness, and that is what sold me on this, easy drinking.

Bottle and on tap.  Copper color pour with off white head.  Hops and malt aroma.  The sweet yeast and hops malt mix is very distinct on the pallet.  Decent carbonation keeps it lively and the combination of distinctive ingredients makes this a smooth and flavorful beer.
12oz bottle: pours golden amber with decent head, aroma heavy in caramel, flavor filled with lots of caramel also slightly sweet and decently balanced with hops.

Bottle.  Pours an orange-ish amber color with a small white head.  Subtle aroma with hints of citrusy hops.  Nice balanced flavor with some sweetness to match the bitter hops.  Nothing extraordinary about this, just an all-around good beer.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Re-rate 8/8/09.  Copper color with a thin head.  Caramel malty, toffee, and a decent hoppy bite.  A bit resiny.  Overall a solid beer, nothing too spectacular but something I could probably drink anytime.  Original rate on 3/13/05.

Randon heller bock tasting...Copper clear hue, creamy egg shell head, malty sweet character predominates in aroma and flavored with carame, niether overpoweringl, much grain. Not much hop or fruitiness.  Minimal metallic mouthfeel, meduim palate.

It is a beautiful amber color with nice head and lacing. Smells very sweet, caramel, and fruity/citrusy hop notes. The taste is amazing! Rogue never seems to fail to make an amazing beer! Fruity hop bite and a malty sweetness to it. I can see how people could think that this is more of an IPA then a Bock. Amazing.

Bottled. Hazy orange colour, small white head. Aroma is sweet fruity hops along with some hints of caramel. Flavour is bigtime fruity and flowery hops along with some nectary hints. Wellbalanced and quite nice. More IPA/APA than bock.
Not a bad ale but I dont see the need to stock Vermont shelves with a so-so beer brewed so far away. Nice label though.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber with off white medium head with minimal retention. Aroma of hoppy floral and caramel. Flavor has citris, sweet, caramel, and medium bitter. Medium-full palate, medium carbonation. Very slight hints of clove?
Good beer!

1 pt. 6 oz bottle.  This ones right in line with my taste.  Color is a clear rich amber.  Not, terribly thick head but the head is at the same time fizzy and fluffy while it lasts.  Nose is of clean fresh malts.  Taste is dominated by hops.  But its a really good bitter-sweet hop flavor.  Notes of carmel and honey in the flavor as well.  Finish is dry and hoppy, with slightly bready under-notes.  The hoppy flavor and finish is more like an American IPA than a heller bock.

Nose is heavier on malts, sweet aroma.  Body is also sweet malts, and a bitter hoppy bite.  Good body, full without being thick.  Seems maybe too carbonated for what it is trying to be, but its not a huge flaw.  Flavor is ordinary, hop bite is average.  Pretty decent beer to keep in the fridge, though.  I tend to enjoy it as it is versatile without being bland.

Pours a coppery gold color with thin head.  Good blend of hops and malt in the aroma.  The flavor is nice and hoppy, without being overpowering.  Unfortunately not much else in the way of other flavors.  Smooth mouthfeel if a bit watery.  In short, its good, but not great, as a standalone beer.  But, as one of the commenters below mentioned, it really does complement bar-fare food well.

Bomber purchased from Boars Head / Bread Garden in Iowa City, IA. Poured an orangish copper hue that was slightly hazy with a medium thick head that dissipated slowly (and pretty much completely). Big malty aroma with some telltale Rogue hop notes. Initial taste is bitter with a sharp maltiness that has small hop profile and mellow sweetness. Finishes with a crisp bitterness that is pleasant, albeit not my personal style preference.

330ml bottle (Opus K, Lohja)
Big malty aroma, soapy and dish-watery. Not selling itself to me very well. Some aromatic hops, and a bit dusty. Anna mentioned nuts and wood, and unlike me quite liked the aroma. Taste is quite thin, but has a mellow walnut and woody maltiness. I prefered the taste, Anna was less enthralled. Carbonation was soft. If this is a Maibock, Im a Dutchman. (Though US brewers not having a clue about European styles seems to be the norm.)

On tap at the Cactus Club in Milwaukee.  Very slight head to it, very clear with an orangish hue.  Aroma was a bit malty, spicy.  Flavor was rich and hoppy, with a hint of malt.  Palate was a bit on the thin side but it went down easy.  Id probably have one again.

This actually used to be one of my favorite beers but I hadnt had it in a while, now I dont really see it making it back to the regular rotation.  Pours amber with a thin head.  Heavy malt aroma and flavor and some caramel in there as well.  The hops werent as present as I remember.  The beer tasted sweet.  Average beer.

I  have heard many good things about this one, and left slightly dissapointed. Its a bit watery, but the flavor isnt too bad. A bit sweet, and some malty aroma. Its lacking a little body, but overall, not bad.
12oz bottle, clear tan color with med white head. slightly nutty initial taste with a slightly sweet finish. i had heard good things about this and wasnt disappointed.

Pours a medium gold color with a light white head.  Smells a bit bitter with some hints of malt.  The flavor is malty and bitter as one might expect from the aroma, but the flavor is a little weak.  The beer also feels a little thin in the mouth.  This isnt a bad beer, but it is lacking a little in body and flavor.

Very disappointing. I was expecting a great beer and got not much at all. I am hoping I got a bad six pack. The malt flavor was small and that wrecked my opinion of the beer. The hops were over powering and way out of place. Mouth feel was thin. Hopefully, the folks on the west coast that hail this beer as one of the best are getting a different product.

The good beer with the crazy name. Taste is good, beats all your macro-brews by a mile. Good on the palate, goes good with pizza, hamburgers, brats, etc. I have seen it in a few stores here and plan to get some more.
(USA) Orange/Brown color with a Sm-White Head. This Brew has a Caramel/Citrus Aroma with a nice crisp taste!!!  The plate was smooth and well balanced. Very good Beer!!!
bottle, amber color, nice hop taste with malty honey/caramel tones, sweet finish
Very balanced for a maibock.  Strong hoppiness to pair with the honey and flowery flavor.  the finish has an oddity to it I havent found in other heller beers.
Tap. Amber in color. Little to no head. Aroma of malts and hops, a bit of a sweet hint. Has a smooth balance of malts and hops. Has a mild aftertaste and hardly any bitterness. Good drinking beer.

Hazy orangey amber, medium disappearing pale head. Nose is toffeeish malts, honey and light flowery hops. Flavor nicely malty with sweet honey notes. Finishes drier with strong flowery & citric hops. Medium to full bodied, malty and round palate. Honey reminds of a bock, but what about the surprisingly strong hoppiness? Simple but pleasant.

Rich malty sweet aroma with a citrusy hop background.  Flavor is the opposite.  Huge hop character with barely enough malt.  Ive had it on tap before and it seemed a lot more balanced than this bottle.  Hopefully I can update this review when I find it on tap again.
dark honey color...sweet aroma, nice caramel hops, good flavor and a nice finish  got this on tap

Subtle malt aroma...not much in the way of a hop boquet. Flavor is a bit unbalanced....not enough malt character on the front and an uneven hop finish. Not a bad beer but not something that I would really get again.

Amber pour. Fairly decent head.  A nice beer.  Sweetness balanced by hops.  High quality malt flavor.  Hints of caramel and the alcohol is present towards the finish.  Expensive, there are better beers for less.

Hazy amber colour. Tall coarse light beige head. Crisp typical clean lager aroma. High carbonation level. Slightly nutty malty aroma. Restrained hops. Somewhat fruity maltiness. Finish is crisp and dry.
Amber in color with a pretty good head.  Some hops and malts in the aroma.  Easy to drink.  Nice sweetness in taste well balanced.
Tried this while on a business trip.  A good balance of hops and malts, in both aroma and flavor.  Poured a reddish orange, and had a sweet after-taste

Overpriced, but not bad at all. Very well balanced, and kind of reminds me of some of the better english and even some scottish ales. Reserved but present hops, and just a bit of caramel sweetness. Like I said, very balanced, and very easy drinkning.
Bottle, poured a copper color with a full lacing head. Nice sweet aroma. Big surprise when I had this beer its awesome, a nice balance of sweetness and hops.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2009 Bottle... poured a deep burnt orange tone with an instant forming frothy head, beautiful lacing.  Sweet, floral aroma.  Pretty well carbonate to balance the alcohol presence and lots of flavors of hops, sugary fruits like berries and malt.  Ive always enjoyed this beer and Im glad I picked it up again.
I am told the label glows in the dark. malty aroma. sweet at the beginning with a hopy mellow bitter finish.
22oz. floral honey fragrance. Beautiful deep amber glowing body. Mellow yeast and malt flavor followed by a nice hop bite with a mellifluous hop and smooth butter finish.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2009 A spooky label and an unappetizing name can mask a good ale.  I thout there might be a connection to the Grateful Dead band, but apparently the name is a reference to the Mexican Dia de los Muertos.  Cloudy orange-honey look, not much of a head.  Fruity, floral aroma, with some cheese.  I have never tried a heller bock before, but this seems like a bock with extra hops.  I taste sweet malt, oranges, bruised fruit, and figs.  The hops are clearly present, and malt and yeast are in the background.  This is for sure an interesting brew, and not quite like anything else I can think of.

this is a safety net beer, one i can find a lot of places that i like more than other common micros. its buttery like movie theatre popcorn, only there is not corn just popped hops? thats a strange one but the way i feel.  stone fruit too, not peach, not nectarine, not apricot but somehow a concoction of all of them.  i dig rogue and dont know what a heller bock is but when im in louisville at the outlook and the bourbon is too much i reach for a dead guy.

Orange brown pour, slightly opaque with a white head.  Sweet aroma, with some minerals and meatiness...almost like soup.  Bitter grain flavor with lots of malt.  A little bit of fruit.  Good, nothing special though.

650ml bottle, Microbar, Clapham, 8th Feb 2008. Pours a cloudy orangey amber with a potent aroma of honeyed malt. Lovely smooth mouthfeel with alcoholic warmth and hop bite coming through once the honey and caramel flavours recede. Some great subtle hop flavours at the finish too. Fierce in places but nice overall.
Buttery caramel nose.  Deep orange amber with a pillowy head.  Rich malt, some toffee notes, nice subtle hops to back the malt.  Smooth long finish.  Really well put together beer.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Sweet fruity aroma, orange mainly, cookie dough. Hazy, orange color, beige small head, few lace. Sweet, orange peels, cookie dough, bitter dry finish. This is not a Heller Bock imo. More like an Belgian Ale with American Hops. Furthermore quite weak and dull.
Pours an orange amber color with a white head.  Sweet caramel aroma and taste accompanied by a bitter flavor.  Well balanced and good overall.

(1 pt. 6 fl oz.)  A nice open amber color when poured.  The aroma is pretty basic, although there is a bit of sweetness.  The flavor continues to be sweet with a noticeable caramel taste.  A really great feel.  Medium bodied and easy to enjoy.  A nice basic beer overall.

Poured into my Eichhof bier mug. Hazy caramel colored, with a healthy white head which leaves some spotty lacing.

Aroma is very toasty and malty, with a surprising fruity character.

Flavor is extremely smooth, with a sweet but dry maltiness and some subdued hops. The only evidence of the ale yeast here is the mild fruity ester notes. The malt profile, however, is pretty true to the German style it emulates.

Mouthfeel is very smooth and this beer is extremely easy to drink. Solid beer.

Overall, a delicious beer. Smooth honey-scented aroma, rich hearty taste, and the malt-hops balance in the finish is probably one of the best I have ever encountered, especially coming from someone who is definitely a malthead not a hophead. You taste the malt on the front end and the hops on the back end, but neither of them overwhelms the other. This beer definitely has entered my top ten.
A very tasty brew.  Pours orange amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is very fruity and sweet.  Taste is very smooth and dangerously drinkable.  Will drink again in large quantities!

I had this once before my rating days and decided that I should have this again to rate it properly. Deep brown pour. Flavor and aroma are mildly fruity. This struck me as more of a weak barely wine than a heller bock, but then again, my knowledge of bocks is limited.
Pours orange-brown with a fine, white head. Aroma is lightly citrusy and hoppy. Mouth feel is moderate. Flavor is lightly hoppy with some undertones of caramel. Good, pleasant, balanced beer.

I sampled Rogue Dead Guy Ale on draft at Yogis in Bloomington. I was attracted to the color, but dissapointed by the small and quickly vanashing head. The taste was very sweet and smooth. This is a very easy to drink ale that was very good with a cheese burger.

This is the one but to bad its 10 bucks and up a 6 pack. I like everything about this one. not to strong not to hoppy just perfect. Had it at issaquah brew house. Out of the four I had it bet out  Charley 1981 and believe me that is a damn good beer
Dark amber color. Nutty and subtle, with notes of stone  stone frutis and malt. Good bar beer.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2008 Big offwhite fine-laced head. Amber body with floating particles. (Uh oh, is this bottle old? Rated a second one, same thing. Thats probably two old bottles.) Delicate toffeeish caramelly aroma with nutty notes. Sweetish roasty toffeeish taste with resiny, medicinal notes. (Yeah, it’s old. Second one had less emphasis on the medicine and more on the resin.) Dry caramelly aftertaste. Good. (0.341l bottle at Bishop’s Arms, Avenyn, Göteborg. Probably past sell-by date, but can’t find any date marking on the bottle. Probably on the cap, which the barkeep has. Should rerate. Tried rerating at Beer Palace, Oslo, also with disappointing results.)

The Dead Guy Ale! Its aroma is malty.  Its appearnce is a dark gold, maybe like a hue of honey.  Flavor-wise this is very good.  Its not too hoppy, its got malty charachters.  Its palate is somewhat bitter, but otherwise a solid brew.

Bottle. Aroma of some pale malts and some bitter/floral hops. Flavor survives based almost entirely on the hop presence, malt adds some sweetness but basically is just there for refreshment. Palate I almost gave a 4, but in the end, aside from the hops, pretty weak over all. Is this a maibock or an ale? I usually appreciate mixes of styles, but I just didnt get this one. I enjoyed drinking it, so I cant go too low, but still wasnt overly impressed.

Bottle.  Poured an orange/amber color with a creamy white head.  Aroma of wheat and floral and citrus hops.  Tastes strongly of wheat, wheat malt, and some hops.  Cross between an APA, hefeweizen, and heller bock.  This is an excellent beer to chill with!
bottle.  very nice beer!  orange tint with cream head.  goes down very smoothly...reminds me of an IPA

I have always liked this beer.  I think its a little pricy, but Rouge brews always are.  Id pick it up more often though if it was more in tune with what Widmer, Dechutes and some of the other local brews that I find in the grocery store are charging.  

Poured from the bottle a really nice cloudy organe/amber color.  Quite a bit of carbonation.  Put on a decent off white head that didnt last too long.  Virtually no lacing whatsoever.  Aroma is not too pronounced...maybe some hops, malt and something else I cant quite put my finger on.  Taste is where this beer is pretty stand out.  Enough hops to keep the hop head in me from complaining, but malt is defenitley more upfront in this one.  Some warming from the alcohol, but not too much.  Short dry finish.  Pretty nice overall.

The label on this beer drew me to try it. I like the orange amber color. The head fizzles out quickly and doesnt leave much lace. The aroma is malty and sweet. It has a nice sweet taste as well, but almost too sweet. Overall, a pretty good beer worthy of any dead guy.
deep gold/brown, hoppy, not so malty, wish i could get it on tap where im from.

A deep golden brown color. The nose is hopps  and some malt. The taste is slightly hoppy with a sutle malt undertones. a very well made beer and very good to drink also The finish is slightly acidic with a little bit of the finish lingering.
Amber colored beer with no bite whatsoever. Might be the perfect session brew. If you can find this on tap, do so in a hurry. Very easy to drink ale. Off to get some more......
Amber color with a white head that did not last long. Malty with hops and a bit of bitterness coming in at the end. Like most here I found it to be good but nothing I would look to buy again.
poured deep amber, nice foamy head. hops and fruit to the nose. a little dry finish. good but not that good
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Bomber:  Aroma is nice grainy aroma with a hint of caramel malt with a light note of the Saaz hops detectable in the aroma Appearance is a clear golden amber with a large sized off white head that lingers.  Taste is like candied caramel, malts a light twang and some grassy notes intermingled.  Palate is lightly sweet on the lips with a clean finish.  Overall, Its good but not great.  A solid bock in my opinion.  Cheers!

Pours amber-brown, whte head drops cleanly. Aroma is dark fruits over a malt base. Flavor is toasted malt with some bitter hops coming through at the finish. Alcohal warmth is not over-powering but more than expected for 6.6% ABV. A nice beer Id have again.

Heller bock?  I dont get that one...  Oh well.  This beer pours a cloudy amber with a medium white head leaving no lacing on the sides.  The aromas are very light grass and hops.  On the palate it is kinda dry with light hops to a little more malt and finishes quite long.  I really liked this one.  Not quite a session beer, but easily drinkable!  Cheers

aromas of malt, cereal, grain.
copper color/ transparent / very little head
malty on entry and turning semi bitter and dry on finish, hops dominate on finish, which is of course dry & semi-bitter.  balance is not quite right for me

heller bock was not anywhere on the bottle.  This beer pours a beautiful dark hazy amber with a very small head and not a lot of visible carbonation.. dont let that fool you, the mouthfeel is bity and very lively.  The aroma is pretty hidden, mostly a malty macro alcoholic smell.... dont let that fool you either.  The front is very lively carbonation, a little bit of a burnt malt but midway thru the hops take over and please the soul.  The hop linger is fairly short, and i get sort of a wet burnt sweet aftertaste.  Im not going to say this is outstanding other than I absolutlely love the middle of this beer!  I just dont get whats happening up front or afterwards... Ill buy it again, just because of that beautiful center.  Expensive as hell!

Bottle. Pours copper with thin beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is sticky caramel and toffee malt scents, grain ester fruitiness- cherries, peach, grapes and light floral notes. Flavor is simple grain, lightly sweet, some resiny floral hop flavors, alcohol burn overtones, creamy mouthfeel, Finish, alcohol burn and moderate lingering bitterness in the aftertaste.

Ah Yes, Dead Guy (Mang) Ale.  A decent brew not bad / not spectacular.  Beer has a brown rust coloration with hardly any lacing.    Slight alcohol burn on the finish, but not too bad.   It almost reminds me of a scottish ale except water down, which is good to me cause I usually think scots are too strong.  Anyways not bad.

Red amber with nice foamy head that dwindles slowly. Nice colour. Not getting very much aromas off this. Which is kind of strange for something over 6% alc. Taste is bitter with the alcohol coming through in the aftertaste. Nice little burn.
tap at the sanctuary.  Reddish amber with a thin white head.  Carmely and hoppy aroma.  Flavor of honey, piney hops, bread, and tart fruit.  Finishes slighly bitter and dry.  Good mouthfeel.  Nice

Bottle @ Microbar, Clapham. Pours murky amber / orange colour with thin white head. Aroma is marzipan, oats, bready, sour fruits. Taste is toffee, malts, earthy grains. Finish is dry with raisins coming through late on. Very enjoyable indeed, good stuff!!

Bottle @ Microbar, Clapham, London. Nose of a marzen. caramel, bread and a hint of hops and cream form the bouquet. Pours an opaque amber coloured beer. Small disspating head. Some carbonation. Taste is sweet with notes of honey, marmalade, malt and hops. Quite brilliant.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2008 Poured copper color from a 22 ounce bomber. Minimal head and lacings. Where others have noted subdued hops I find the bitter hop note to over power the malts. Ends on a dry slighty bitter ending. Dont think Ive had a German-style Maibock before so I am just looking at this as an Ale. A very nice and tasty brew. Paid about $3.49 US for the 22 ounce bottle.  An all around fine beer. If this is all I could get it would be fine.
tan/amber on the pour. Nice malty nose. Sweet caramel malt and orange rind hopiness on the finish. good brew.
UPDATED: MAY 19, 2009 12 oz. bottle.  Very malty with medium hops.  Pours a bronze tan color.....beautiful.
Bottled.  Clear amber pour.  Decent head which dissipates quickly.  Sweet and malty flavor that lingers on the tongue.  Nice beer.
On tap at the Sanctuary in Iowa City. Pours a hazy amber, full malt to start with a nice bitter finish.  Quite drinkable.
UPDATED: JUN 23, 2008 light off white head, pours light orange.  Sharp on the palate.  Light, Tasty malt finish makes this beer very drinkable
Just did not work for me...palate was really unbalanced, smell was a mix of cat urine and garbage disposal.  has a nice cloudy look and a fruity finish, but blah overall

Dead Guy, or Dead Mang as it is known arounf these parts; pretty interesting brew to say the least. Very malty and orangish. Flavor of hops is noticable, but not overpowering. Decent lacing. Nice balance and flavor. I took a liking to this and have one every now and again.

Poured and amber color with a small white head. Very strong malty aroma. Starts out with a sweet malty flavor and ends malty with just a little bit of hops in the middle. Left a plethora of lacing on the glass. My kinda beer!!

Pours a light amber with a finger of quickly dissipating, soapy head.  Strong malty aroma.  It hits with a crisp maltiness that mixes with a fresh hoppy bitterness that meshes together to make a nice, interesting, drinkable beer.

Bottle. Pours with a off with head but very quickly fades away. Some lacing. Cloudy amber color. Good and bitter and a little dry and had somewhat a malty flavor and aroma. Palate is a bit harsh but still very good

Slightly cloudy amber color with a thin off-white head.  Slightly maltly and citrusy aroma, a little bit of earthy hops.  Sweet grainy start moves on to a mild hop finish.  The finish was quite sweet.  A very clean drinkable brew.
Very solid ale, great aftertaste, definitely would buy again would rate more but need to get back to the State of the Union drinking game
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 3, 2010 Tried on Beer Quest 2010 with all the guys. This was number 15. Good malty beer.  Very apparent in the aroma.  Small amount of hops.  Very flavorful and enjoyable to drink.
Had on tap. sweet smoothness and fairly drinkable for a darker beer. Nice maltiness, very little hint of hops.overall very solid beer.
From a bottle pours an orange color.  Aromas of sweet malts and hops.  Starts out sweet then switches to the hops and ends bitter.  Overall good brew.
I love the orange color of this beer. this had a nice bitter sweet balance. very good beer.

Orange pour with a small white head.  

Smells very sweet and malty.  Smells like bread. 

Very sweet and malty taste.  Dont taste any hops with this one, all malt.  Little one dimensional in that its all malt and a little sweet.  

Not a bad beer, but not sure I could have more than one or two with the sweetness.

Bottle into Pilsener glass.  Pours a glowing amber with a thick, khaki head.  Smell is sweet malts.  Very promising beginning.  Drinks a bit too bitter, particularly for a Maibock, and greasy.  The sweet maltiness is present right ant the start before yielding to the bitter, and returns in the aftertaste.  Some might call this complex.  I found it a bit of a chore.

12 oz bottle pours a coppery color with a half inch off white head.  Aroma of sweet malt.  Flavor is grainy and sweet malt with litlle to no hops present.   Disappointing considering my love of most of rogues beers. Maybe I got a bad bottle?

I dont think Ill ever understand the hype behind this very simple session beer offering from Rogue. True maibocks, while more reserved and subtle in style, can be quite interesting without lacking depth of flavor. Dead guy simply falls flat for the purported style. It pours a simple flaxen colour with a weak head and a very basic "beery" nose. The flavour is one dimensional and unremarkable.
Bottle/Tap.  Orange pour with a tiny white head.  Aroma is sweet and hoppy with a bit of citrus.  Flavor is quite sweet and citrusy.  Decent brew; easy drinking.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2008 Nice beer overall.  Nice aroma of caramel malts.  Beautiful red/gold color, hazy, with brownish white head.  The flavor was sweet, with a balanced hop bitterness.  Very satisfying.  It is a true bock in that it is a thick bodied beer.  The palate is sweet with a slight hop twinge.  Very nice beer.
Bottle: Poured a orangish brown with with creamy off white head. The aroma is full of malt some hops. malts with earthness to it, with jagged hops.

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass, giving a coppery color and a bit of a head that didnt last. Had a sweet smell, but didnt overwhelm the nose. The taste was too rich in hops for my taste. Not necessarily a terrible beer, but just okay.

Thin head that did not hold long. Sweet pear aroma and slightly malty.  Started sweet then could taste the Hopps then sweet again at the end and I like that.  They serve it at a local tavern here and I will order it there again.  Its the most interesting thing they have on the beer menu.

Pours a copper color with a thin head. Smells of sweet apples. The taste is a little off but still good. Taste like sweet fruits with a touch of hop. The Palate is nothing special but still cuts it. Overall this is a good beer.

Keg.  Pours a hazy orange with a thin white head.  Aroma is fruity yeast and European hops with some malt.  Flavors are malt, hops, little earthy, some fruity yeast as well.  Smooth with no hint of the 6.6%.
Cloudy amber-orange body with white head. Interesting, sort of fruity/sweet aroma. Satisfying malty taste. The slightly higher alcohol is well-hidden.
Amber of color and an orange/beige head. An aroma of malt, blackbread, hops, notes of liqurice, fruits and apples. A flavor malt, liqurice and hops - a bitter finish.

22oz bottle.   An interesting beer.   Fruity and sweet, with a different yeast character than typical bocks.   Mellon and caramel dominate, with moderate and flavorful hops.   My first ever Rogue beer, and Im intrigued.
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2008 One of my favorite socializing beers. Goes down smooth with enough alcohol to give you a kick. Highly recommended.
Sweet smelling and sweet tasting. It is suprising that this beer is 6.6%. It tastes like it would have a lower percentage. This beer finishes quite clean with a honey like aftertaste.

A Mes rate: Bottle thanks to Reakt.Semi hazy golden amber with a slim white head. Sweet malt aroma with some wheat and yeast. Full on but not amazing. Sharp malt, yup thats what I said, flavour. Convincing impression of a German Bock. Sadly, it is equally comparable in its bland maltiness. A little cardboard on the finish. Had many many bottled German beers that are so very similar to this. Personally its not something I would want to replicate.

[dec 2007 - ABV 6.3%] Dark amber body, generouos off-white head. Rich malty and fruity aroma. Earthy, caramel and toffee notes with just the right amounts of hops to add balance. Warm and full mouthfeel. Doesnt quite taste or "feel" like a german Bock. Deep and full of taste.

This is a solid beer for those who avoid darker heavier beers.  Pours to a golden amber, with bubbly white quarter inch head.  Hints of malt and fruits with a sweet somewhat dry finish.  Great beer to drink in massive quantities since it is lighter on the stomach as opposed to most porters, imperial ipas, and stouts.  Decent beer.
From bottle. Aroma of hops and fruit. Amber appearance, good white head. Good flavour of malt, hops and fruit. Decent texture. Bitter finish. Easy to drink, very good beer.

Poured little head that dissipated and was a nice copper hue.  The aroma was largely malt, grain, and alcohol.  It was very sweet.  The most prominent feature I felt was a graininess throughout the beer.  It was easy on the palate and quite dry and bitter on the finish.

I like this one quite a bit. Much better than there American Amber. Aroma is mainly malty with some light grapefruit, apricot, grapes, and yeast. Pours a medium cloudy amber with a small off-white head that goes away. Flavor is good, sweet throughout with a nice alcoholic bite in the finish. Quite nice. I would by this again and serve to dinner guests, well worth getting a sixxer if you can find one.

Pours copper with relatively modest head. Aromas of citrus, and oddly enough, an alcoholic note. Flavours of yeast and citrus- especially orange. Body is medium and finish  is bone dry. Id have this again.

golden amber with thin beige head. slightly hoppy  and fruity - hint of cherries? Tastes of bitter grain, malts, and a bit peppery. Well balanced and clean. A good beer, but not as flavorful as I had hoped...
Bottle:  Poured an amber color with very little head.  Aroma was slightly fruity and floral while the taste was very malty.  This beer was just OK for me.

650 ML bottle. Poured a nice copper color. There was a small head after pouring, but it quickly disappeared. Definite smell of fruit and light hops. Very pleasing taste of hops and malts. This beer was very enjoyable and seemed to get better as the beer warmed.
Draft Poured copper with little head or carbonation, almost like a British bitter.  Fruity nose and quite hoppy.  Well balanced and great tasting beer.
Bottle. Head is small and disappears fast. Fruity hop nose. medium bitterness. nice normal easy drinkable well hopped ale.

Pours a medium amber/copper.  The little head that was present was gone before my first sip.  Light malt (bready) and fruit aroma.  Taste is malty, with almost no hop presence.  Finish is slightly bitter and a little bit dry.   Beer has almost no carbonation, but the palate (although creamy) is a bit thin.  Overall a very good beer.  I wish the alcohol is a bit lower, as this one has the taste of a session beer.  Regardless, it is one to keep on hand.
Pours coppery-haze, light perfumy hop aroma with hints of malt.  Bittery-sweet-smooth taste with a genuine toasty-malt punch that dissapates into sweet-hoppy in the finish.
A pretty decent beer with a light aroma and sweet honey flavor.  A nice beer to drink while watching a game.

RATING 200!!!  The very first beer when I moved to Texas was this (not a Shiner, shocking), so time to try it again- 12 oz. bottle- poured semi transparent murky dark copper/amber color, off white head that formed a ring.  Aroma of malt, yeast, and a low hop overtone.  Hits the mouth with a sharp medium body, hops come on heavy in the middle and seem to increase on the finish.  One to enjoy slowly.

One of my favorite beers also,  Poured a decent head, then dissapeared quickly.  Smells of malt and honey.  Didnt know it was 6.6% the alcohol is very well hidden.  This beer is a great one to drink when playing music, good vibes, high times.  Let the good times roll....

One of my favorite beers! Nice honey color, and very hearty. A nice head that goes away quickly but the beer is very well balanced and after a couple it begins to tastes like pure chocolate! MMMMMMMMM!

Bottle from Stateline Liquors in Elkton Maryland: Nice deep amber with a definite bitterness and strong hop taste.  Very well-balanced.  Probably one of the best hoppy ales I have had that did not come out of a hand-pump in a pub in London.
bottle. pours rich amber with off white head. Smells of malt with light hop. Tastes nicely blended between malt and hop balance. A hoppy aftertaste that is very pleasant.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2007 yes yes yes yes! a great all-around all american beer! praise this beautiful land! praise it! amber pour, hints of barley goodness and thick maple syrup like pancakes mm mm good!

Bottle from the Astoria alehouse. Aromas of caramel and pale malts with some floral hop. A copper sort of color with a minimal white head. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.  Flavor is roasted malts, with some balancing bitter - probably floral hop. Its really a bit malty for an APA, but it does not suggest an ESB. Leaves a bit of tingle in the mouth. It really makes a strong statement.Earlier Rating: 1/7/2007 Total Score: 3.6Bottle from the Astoria alehouse (as Chinookie). Aromas of caramel and pale malts with some floral hop. A copper sort of color with a minimal white head. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Flavor is roasted malts, with some balancing bitter - probably floral hop. Its really a bit malty for an APA, but it does not suggest an ESB. Leaves a bit of tingle in the mouth. It really makes a strong statement.

Prior 3.6 rating awhile back: Aroma of malt adjusted with honey fruit notes. Interesting. Very. Quite clean. Perfect amber color with a nice white head. Chewy and firm mouthfeel. Starts with a taste between light and dark fruits. Caramel toffee impacts, and the finish is nicely balance with hop.  Great.

12-oz. Pours crystal clear medium amber with a dense, fluffy platinum blonde head. Decent little rings of lace. Plenty of plumes of rising bubbles. Soft and moderate nose of yeasty breadiness. Not great promise there. Nice medium body with tinglingly active carb. Nice big toasty, tea-like mid-palate with nuts and peppery goodness rising through the mix as the finish nears. Slightly piney, peppery, herbal finish. You could certainly do worse than this for a session beer. Lots of body and breadth of flavor as hellers go.

Bottle. Appearance: Gold with off white head. Aroma: Yeasty. Some citrus. Palate: Medium. Flavor: Same yeasty malt dominates the flavor. Citrus and floral hops in the background. Overall: A very easy drinking beer, but not excellent. Rogue makes much better beers than this.
Almost reddish tinge to the amber pour.  Lots of caramel/malt in the flavor. Good amount of hops too, but the malt really is dominate.   [will rerate from home.. had this at the pub]

This poured a light tan almost amber color with a thin white head that dissipated quickly. The aroma was of some piney hops with a good amount of malts mixed in. The flavor was much the same with the malts being the dominant flavor with some citrus fruit and hops in the background. The malt flavor is nice and sweet with a touch of caramel in there. This one is easy drinking that goes down nice and sweet. Pretty good session beer.
I poured this beer from a bottle.  It had an interesting aroma that was similar to the smell of sweet bread being baked.  Mildly sweet with a nice medium sour finish.  Pretty damn good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2007 Bottle pours amber, with small, creamy head that leaves a moderate amount of lacing.  Sharp scent of alcohol, mainly. Long, long, nutty bittersweet flavor. Smooth palate.  Flavor intensifies slowly.  Very pleasurable hops end.
Is this an ale or a lager, as befits the bock style?

Pours a copper-amber. Aroma is very fragrant with floral and citrus notes. Definitely carries over to the taste. Hints of citrus and bubblegum. Nicely hoppy. Nice complexity, carbonation. Overall, very decent. Good, even.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2010 Bottle. Moderate note of light bread for the malt, light grass for the hops, moderate dough for the yeast, and peach, wood and honey in the background. Head is small and white with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is hazy tan/copper. Flavor is very lightly sweet and lightly acidic to start, then finishes lightly bitter and a touch sour. Palate is medium, creamy with a lively carbonation and a dry finish. Nice aromas, a little confused, but nice.
12oz bottle poured out all amber/dark copper. minimal head. nice aroma of malt and sweet hop action. very smooth on the palate. great after taste.

This beer was poured from a bottle. Poured a rich amber/orange color. Nice head that faded to a smooth ring. Nice smell, nectar of the gods like taste. Out of all of the beers I have tried so far this one I like best. Good all around. Nice balance of hops, slightly sweet taste with slight bitter finish. Mouthfeel good and clean. I like it a lot.

At brewery in Portland...or thier tap house is actually where it was. Fantastic maly brew. Honey gold in colour with tons of white frothy head that lasted in the glass until I finished. great hop balance. An excellent brew

Bottiglia da 65cl al Pub del Duca; versa colore ambrato intenso con buona schiuma persistente. Aroma molto dolce, miele e zucchero candito; sapore ben bilanciato invece con note di amaro aromatiche e sentori sbruciacchiati nel finale.

You gotta love it.  Everything these guys do is good to me.  Very pricey for me at $11.99 a six pack + tax, for how common tasting this is compared to other Rogue brews.  The only bad park was a weird aftertaste that kinda sticks with you.
good for its sessionable qlualities, but nothing too outstanding, nothing bad, just a good session.

Great label and packaging, solid beer. Not my favorite Rogue, but common and tasty. Nice, sweet malt flavor with some hops to keep things balanced. Great reddish copper color to match the deep flavor. A bit of a one-note brew, but it is a good note!
A cereal nose up front and it looks great on the pour.   The mouth feel and taste is great well ballanced malts and just a small hint of hoppiness.   One of my standbys

SMELLED AND LOOKED GREAT,INITIAL TASTE WAS GOOD BUT IT HAS A STRONG
MALTY ALCOHOL TASTE IN THE FINISH.
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2007 Hazy honey color with little head.  Sweet malt aroma.  Taste is nicely balanced sweet malt with mild hops.  Finished clean with little aftertaste.
This beer had a very nice aroma and appearance.  I really just didnt enjoy the taste.  It had a very strong alcohol taste.
This one was almost too strongly hopped for my taste.  It has a maltiness to match the hops. Almost a barley wine.Overall its just too strong and sweet.
Malty and sweet with decent hops.  One of my favorite beers to pair with cajun food.

12oz Bottle - Gravity Room - Olympia WA. 
Aroma  A deep malt and hop aroma.  
Appearance  Deep amber color with a thin head and clear as a bell. 
Flavor  A deep malty flavor with the hops present througout the taste.  
Palate  This was bitter in the finish but had such a great flavor this is a great beer
Overall One of the better beers of the world.  Dead Guy ranks with the best and is a great beer for all.
Draft at Joe Cracker in North Port, FL.  Copper color, full bodied taste, both hops and malt are prevalent but the balance is good.  Mild bitterness, good carbonation.
cloudy copper pour with a malty aroma.  Maybe a bit too sticky sweet but still very good.
Pours a dark orange with very very little head. Aroma is malty. A little to sweet for my liking. Not a bad brew but probably my least favorite rogue.

Had this beer on 11/01/2002.  Aroma is malty with a hint of yeast.  Color is a rich orange brown with low carbonation and almost no head.  Taste is heavy and sweet.  Starting with a heavy/medium body to goes down with a sweet rich feel .  Finish is a wine like malty sweet flavor backed by a mild bitterness.

Thanks Tish! Wow how have i not rated this yet? pours hazy orange amber with a good off white head that disappears. honey caramel hay aroma with light fruity dried apricot notes.  Sweet honey dry hay light bitter caramel flavor. lingering dry bittersweet honey caramel hay finish with some fruity apricot notes. medium body. moderate carbonation. not a bad beer...just not one of my favorites.
Pours an amber/orange color and tastes of lightly bitter hops.  More malty ale than hoppy.  Its very drinkable and smooth for a hop ale.  Excellent overall.

I remember trying this one on tap at the Yard House and thinking is was just OK.  I enjoyed it this time around from the bottle much more.  Poured a clear copper color with an impressive and lasting off white head.  Aroma is anything but "dead."  Full of hops flowers and citris, it lead to a full bodied ale.  Smooth, malty and well balanced.  Not overly hopped and not to heavy it had great concentration.  Dry finish will have you reaching for another sip fast.  Be carefull.  Youd never know it has 6.6 abv.
Malty bouquet. Pours a light amber with a small vanishing white head. Hoppy at first, caramelly in the middle, roasty malty in the finish. Good beer from a good brewery.

6-pack from Total Wine, River Edge, NJ...bottle pours a cloudy amber color with a sudsy white head...aroma is sweet, floral...taste is much of the same with, what I found to be, a bit of a dried apricot flavor...smooth mouthfeel...quite different from other ales Ive had...not bad.
Draft. Amber color.  Nicely balanced leaning slightly to the hop side.  Mild flavor thats not overpowering
Murky amber color. Mild taste with a nice balance of hops. Finished well with a nice balanced bitter taste.
Bottle.  Poured very nice amber.  Nice smell of hops.  Hops blended very well into flavor, causing a smooth taste and finish.  Tis good.

Bottled, consumed on 11/10/07.  Pours a very carbonated cloudy amber-orange with a long-lasting head composed of fine white bubbles.   Hoppy, earthy nose with a metallic undertone is not terribly appealing.  Flavor is relatively mild.  Light maltiness is well balanced with citrusy hop notes and moderate astringency.  Overall mouthfeel somewhat thin but thats okay.  Goes down smoothly with lingering, lightly bitter aftertaste.  Very nice, aside from the aroma.
Beautiful amber color. Really great appearance. Sweet malt flavors balanced with a hoppy finish. Relatively thin mouthfeel but not necessarily a bad thing. Great session beer.

Nice malty aroma with just a touch of hop aroma.  Beautiful amber beer in the glass.  The flavor is definatly the best part of any good beer and its the best part of Dead Guy.  Nice caramel/munich malt backbone with notes of earthyness and light grassiness (not in the typical bad way).  The profile is very balanced with just enough of the hop flavors/aromas coming through to add balance too the malts.  Finish and mouthfeel are full and not lacking.  Overall this is a versitile beer good for just about anything from pork chops, to steak, to a session beer (just a bit heavy on the abv to be a true session, but hey its good stuff).  I never turn one of these down!

650 ml bottle from Bevmo. Pours a translucent copper color with a medium off-white head that left plenty of lacing.  The aroma was light with malts, yeast and a bit of pepper spice. The flavor was similar to the aroma with plenty of sweet malts, biscuit, and pecans. The mouthfeel was a bit thin up front- but rounded out to a pasty fullness by finish. The finish was slightly bitter hoppy, with more sweet malts lasting a long while. Overall: A very enjoyable and quaff-able beer. Recommended.
Draft at Busters in Minneapolis. Cloudy amber in color with a light malt and hop aroma.  Medium bodied with well balanced flavors on the malty side. Good lacing and a good session beer.
Pours hazy amber with a thick off white head. Malty, hoppy caramel aroma that is very subtle. Taste is very smooth, malty with a hint of caramel and hops. Very balanced and really tasty.

Bottle poured into a pint glass.  Hazy orange/brown colour with a medium white head that reduces down to a film with nice lacing.  Aroma is mildly hoppy and a little more hop in the flavour with a nice sweet, malt balance.  Enjoyable beer.

One of the better options on the shelf.  Mildly malty. Almost full bodied, but a tad lacking in the flavor dept. Medium/strong aroma smelling slightly hoppy, and more floral. Medium head, moderate lacing. Better than average taste overall.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2007 This beer is good, but not great.  It is a copper amber with a thick, lasting off-white head and good lacing.  The aroma is rich malt and slightly floral.  The taste is fairly mild, malty, a bit sweet with a light bitter balance.  It is primarily rather dry  with a biscuit element near the finish.  Its smooth, fairly tasty, and pleasant, but not incredible.
Package is better than the beer. By no means bad, but lacking compared to other Rogue brews.
