Starts off with an hoppy bite but the caramel malt sweetness balanced it out quite nicely. Hint of spice and alcohol on the finish as well. Medium-bodied with a dry and lively mouthfeel. While not true to the original style, it is still well done and recommended.
Golden brown, ruddy, thin lacey head. Aroma = caramel. Taste has a woody sweet start, bitter finish. Pretty hoppy beer.
A very good bock.  I was suprised at that I liked it.  I could smell honey and brandy. It was on the sweet side but it was very good.
spicy malt aroma, cloudy and rusty in colour, not much head, spicy and peppery flavour with a very sharp finish, quite complex.

12 oz. brown bottle. No freshness date seen. Poured out a cloudy, copper color. Aromas of Cascade hops right away. Slight malt aromas, but not much. Slight caramel taste to it. Not much to say here gang, I've had better beers. I wouldn't go out of my way to buy it again.

Slightly cloudy dark amber color with a half inch tan head.  Malty aroma.  Initial taste is hoppy, too much for my pleasure.  Aftertase is also too sweet for my liking, but this is a good beer overall.  Definitely a beer from the Pacific Northwest.

Clear amber body with medium beige head.  Aroma is light, medium sweet, caramel, spicy.  Taste is modeately sweet, malty (some caramel, some nutty), spicy.  Mild earthy/floral bitter finish.  Medium body, pairs well with the gumbo-esque dinner I had.
The aroma is light and malty.  The apperance is a mid amber with a thick off white head.  The flavor is hoppy and smooth.  Overall not to bad.

Quite a sweet beer this one, and not bad for it.  The aromas consist of sweet caramel and a hint of fruit.  The flavour is fruity, as expected but also has burnt toffee and caramel sweetness.  This has a good level of sparkle and warming alcohol to finish.  Not bad.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2006 October 2006 - Bottle from LCBO. Dark amber witha decent sized beige head and lacing. (3+) Lightly spicey notes and mild hops in the aroma, pleasant mildly earthy malt with light caramel notes. Pleasant bitternessis light but lingers with just the right amount of balancing malt (crystal?). Average palate. Solid and quaffable. 7/3+/73/14 - 3.4

July 2006 - Hazy orange amber with a small white head that fades fairly quickly. Sweet malt with something a bit different to it that I can not quite place in the aroma. Lightly spicy malt with an interesting lingering tangy malt character. Average palate. Not doing much for me really but its not unpleasant. 6/3/6/3/12 - 3

Nov 2000 - Bottle fromm LCBO in Mississauga. Smells and tastes like malt extract. Not much hops to notice. Bit of dark fruity smell. Big aftertaste... not harsh, but a bit of a kick in the pants! Mine had very little head... not sure if its supposed to, and Im not sure how old my bottle is. Cool label. Nice amber color. Not bad... Dont know if I would buy it on a regular basis but Im glad I tried it. 5/2/5/2/9 - 2.3

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) an orange-golden color with very little off-white head which disapates to nothing quickly.  Aroma is a fruity boquette of wild berries, and caramel-honey.  Flavor is malty, but then mediumly (mediumly?) hoppy.  Hops is an unpleasant characteristic, in my opinion.  Strips the mouth dry and replaces it with a paint thinner-bitter finish.  Not one for the charts.  Sampled at 73 degrees Fahrenheit.

Tried this one at the Abbaye in Northern Liberties, Philadelphia. It seemed to me that the barmaid/owner could care less that she poured an absolutley flat beer and served it to me.  Flavor was evident though, I would have bet this was a stong ale.   I'll have to re-rate with a 22 oz. bottle next time.
Bottle: O.K. nose apricot,honey,brandy. Reddish orange color. Sugary sweet toasted malt with a slight grapefruit bitterness. Creamy, syrup finish. A little too lite & sweet for my overall preference
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: A burnt amber with a medium creamy off-white head.  Aroma of malt, pacific and english hops, chocolate and seawater.  A malt taste backed by hops with a taste of chocolate.

Pours a slighty hazy dark orange with a mild off-white head that dissipates quickly, but there is nice lacing--thank god.  Aroma is a woodsy, buttery one.  malt, malt, and more malt which disappears almost immediately.  This beer is very smooth, but rather one-dimensional.  The palate is pretty watery.  I think this beer is quite overrated.

Deep amber brown color with minimal white head.  Aroma is apricots, caramel and hay.  Flavor is sweet malt with bracing hops, but a little unbalanced.  Lingering bitter, metallic finish.  Nice medium body with little carbonation.
Hazy, copper with a small, white head.  Malty and caramely nose.  Flavor was malty with a little hoppiness in the finish.
Sweet beer. Really malty probably too much. Could use more hops to balance.

I found the malt character of this beer to be too pronounced.  There is hop bite at the end, but the hop and malt flavors never coincide.  I thought this beer was interesting at first but the more I've had of it the less enjoyable it gets.
Sweet fruity flavors. Not as hoppy as I was expecting, but good none the less.
Poured a reddish color, with a sweet candy aroma, huge white head with nice lacing.  Mild hop/caramel flavor, with slight alcohol taste.
Hazy golden brown color. Not much aroma. Small tan head. Not too much flavor going on in this one. A mild hopping with a musty malt flavor. Really kind of boring and uneventful. I was expecting more.

Amber in color, light tan small bubbly half inch thick head. Very appealing to look at. Smells of light floral hops and yeast. Start and middle are a little bit empty, but ohh the finish is so nice. Good fair amount of hops with a nice dry hop bite. Sip or drink it slow, its quite smooth with a nice hop bite. Drink it fast and watch out, the hop bite bites. Has a light body feel and leaves a dry hop tang in mouth and tongue.
On draught. Appearance: hazy, honey colored w/ a medium white head. It has a malty taste up front w/ a bit of a funky tart finish. Maybe grapefruit or lemon? unique, to be sure
I dig the Dead Guy. I nice amount of hops and enough malt to get this beer going in your nose before it begins playing with your tongue. Very easy drinking, a great quaffing beer.

Probably the blandest Bock I have tasted.I have grave doubts whether it should be even called by that name.Considering the complexity of the ingredients that the brewery says are in it this is a very simle ale.Pors nice with a moderate head, looks quite good but is rather boring.Nothing distinctive about it and not a lot of kick for a 6.6 ale.
In my opinion this is just a classic "beer".  No muss and no fuss.  Just a damn good tasting every day down home kinda beer.  I could drink this beer every day.

Bottled. Tart bitter flavour. Golden, reasonable from the pour. It had a cranky bitter hop finish, giving it a cheap & corn syrup personality. Best bitter flavour without finesse. WARNING: Dont drink this as the last beer of the night. Wow betide thee that does.

bleaugh. an utter steaming turd in a bottle. overcaramelly malt flavours wallow in a sickly stew of sweaty/cheesy/banana esters. a bit cardboardy - maybe oxidised. and the finish is just random bitterness for no good reason, a consolation prize for all the sweet thick cloying crap you have to endure to get there. no balance, beauty or delicacy of any kind here.
I got this one on a whim (i'm easily swayed by funky labels) and i honestly found it to be pure whatevery.  Mediocrity in a bottle!
reminds me of a strong red beer.  decent body to accompany a reasonably tasty flavor.  gives a powerful impression, but doesn't overpower you...

A bit odd, motelpogo likened it to Golden Syrup, which i can't disagree with. Quite sticky and sweet, with a touch of salt at the end. Kinda like a bock, just with a bit more hops that i'd usually expect in one.
UPDATED: JUL 7, 2003 rerate - ok- with a clean palate I can get this bear.  not my favorate style and still could use a bit more carbonation but there is a good mix of malts

Overall, not a bad beer.  It's got a nice amber color, and the hop level was just right...not too strong.  
Lots of malt makes for a slightly alcohol-y taste.

Has a amber color with some carbonation and a sweet malt smell.  Taste is kind of malted and finishes a little bitter.  Overall another disappointment from Rogue, I was expecting a bit more malt from this style.  It wasn't bad, just nothing special...

Nah!  I just don't get this beer.  Since tryig it over 5 years ago, I just cannot seem to enjoy the crazy malt profile of this beer.  It is just way to peaty (sp).  While I am the first to admit that maibocks and bocks in general are not my fave, this beer is simply to out of whack for me to enjoy.  Teh beer pours a decent brownish amber and has a faint smell of hops as it is poured.  Teh first sip is dominated by peated malt which continues throughout the beer.  The beer has a chalky/gritty finish.
Clear orange/amber color with a medium, short lasting light brown head. A very mild slightly hoppy aroma. Good balance between the hops bitterness and malty sweetness.

Yum, yum, dead guy in my tum. Smooth and sensual this mellow blend exudes quality. From the delicate sweetness, crested with musty malt and a citrus"y" hops which capstones the experience. The aroma is soft and perfume-like and speaks of roasted caramel. The head is a nice shade of dirty blonde and clings until the final swig. Nice color and consistency. Well done.
Reddish color. Malty aroma, nicely hopped. Didn't notice that it could be a bock. Nevertheless a good beer.

The Dead pours a rich, slightly hazy honey colour.  It yields an average size off-white head, that diminishes fairly quickly, leaving some lacings.  Good yeast and malt aroma, with a few citrus notes.  Starts out sweet initally, and has a few fruity notes, but very few.  Chalky, medium bitter finish.  Nothing special here; I have others I would prefer.  It has potential, but it lacks the character so many other beers have.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2004 Very nice arome and hop balance. I particularly liked the malt aroma and how the ale kept it's Dead Head. Every time I drink this, I like it more and more. Medium bodied with a faint taste of honey buried in there somewhere.
nice hoppy flavor one of the easiest to find of the Rogue Ales, so it does lack a little bit, some nice malty flavor as well, beautiful amber color

Death, come sweetly to me/  
Poured sprightly with deep amber hues/
And murky, pleasantly bearing a head/  
Now pay the ferryman his dues./  
Carried across the caramel Styx/  
Headed to my burial vault/  
From a unrepentingly hoppy life/  
Peace found where there is malt./  
Strangely, calm settles upon me/  
Putting my suspicious soul at ease/   
Generally not a fan of Rogueish living/  
The Dead Guy beer doth please.
Bottle.  Definitely hoppy.  Not what I would consider a bock.  The only word that I can seem to think of to describe is tangy.

Pours with a crystal clear amber body topped by a medium thick head with lots of lace. Slightly sweet lemony malt arom a with a good hoppy background and a slight smokiness.  Slightly sweet yet bitter and hoppy  flavor with a slightly malty character. The finish is short and bitter.  Medium to full bodied, slightly tingly and slightly dry.
This is a nice red-brown creamy ale.  Fruit is prevalent, and the bottle is cool.  I was pleasantly surprised.  Definately would drink again.
UPDATED: MAY 15, 2003 A hoppy brown color beer with a creamy taste.A little fruit is noticed about half way into the beer. A good beer for a true bock beer.

Weak head with some lacing.  Bit cloudy with a nice bronze color and a sniff of hops in the pour.  Not what I was expecting in something identified as a bock, but a decent ale all the same.  A hoppy bit of aftertaste.

Deep golden copper color with large white head. Rich roasted malty aroma. Rich sweet malty flavor with hints of berries. Smooth silky medium body. Sweet fruit flavor continues through middle and tapers to slightly roasted 
finish. Some mild hop bitterness also present in middle through finish.

Malt, malt, malt!  I want it!  Where is it?  Oh wait, it’s here under all these hops.  Thin, fine, creamy, head.  Saaz hops, fruit, and the barest hint of malt in the nose.  A little bit of berry and malt in the mouth if you swish it around.  Creamy.  Finish is hops.  They tone down as it warms, but you can’t drink the whole beer warm...only the last half or so.  Sticky grapefruit aftertaste.  Maibock my ass.  If they added this much hops in May, it’d be mellow in time for Oktoberfest.  If it looks like a pale, smells like a pale, finishes like a pale. . .I mean, come on.  This sucker ain’t a bock no more than I am Italian, which is to say not at all.

Dead Guy tasted like a cross between an amber and a bock, living up to the latter as it warmed up.  Dark tan/amber in color, dominated by sweet malts, yet hoppier than most European bocks I've tasted.  A nice beer.
Very good beer with lots of flavor and nice malty tastes. The packaging and name of the beer also gives it that unique and fun beer drinking experiance.
Hoppy and apple nose, but light. Dark orange color, medium fast diminishing head. No carbonation at all. Hoppy and medium bitter. Ok but not the hit.
Smells almost like nothing, maybe a little malty. Look of amber with a bitter, malty taste. Nothing spectacular. Business as usual

A decent beer from one of my favorite breweries, but there is nothing really special here. A fruity maltiness recalls apples or plums with a modest hop finish. Relatively full body that has an orange color. Well balanced, but a quick taste profile.
UPDATED: JUN 3, 2003 Copper in color with a decent white frothy head. Light malt aroma with a hint of sweetness, caramel? Flavor is moderately bitter with  some spicyness. Bitter finish

Lovely amber color, medium head that fell rapidly but did not subside entirely.  Strong Pacific Northwest hop aroma.  Great malt flavors with big, but balanced hop bitterness.  Spicy finish.  Lovely beer that will take you home quicker than you expected.
This beer pours dark orange.  It is very odd and drinkable, but not too terribly enjoyable.

On tap. Ale? Bock? What is this stuff? More like an IPA with the hops. Little head, dark orange brown color. Smooth, sweet at first but a largely bitter aftertaste. Pretty good, not outstanding, I just have no idea how to classify this.

12 oz. Bottle, I only add that as in some ways I miss the old glow in the dark label (Do they still make them?) Hazy amber color with a smallish cream colored head.  Light pine, citrus and malt infused aroma.  I have never been a big fan of bock ales, they seem to be like an APA without the real hops for an APA or the crispness of a lager.  Lightly fruity. Not saying I don't like this one, it just lacks any definition, any characters that make it stick out and say DRINK ME!  Somewhat like a lot of browns and reds out there.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2003 I had this for the first time recently and enjoyed it very much. It poured a nice head that laced the glass as I drank it. The thing about it that impressed me the most was that despite its intense hops, the malt flavor came right through. This is American brewing at it's best.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: This is perhaps the sweetest hoppy beer I've had.  I found it be far more complex than any other Maibock I've had, with a sweet honey-malt base followed by some very pleasant bittering hops at the finish.  Lovely!

Sweet malty nose, combined with a darker amber color.  Very little white head from my bottle.  Smooth taste, somewhat sweet. Hints of carmel, and fery slight impression of chocolate.  Palate does indeed come off with a bite at first, then falls off.  Im not a huge fan of bocks, but this one certainly is acceptable, to say the least.
A nice beer. Amber in color, hoppy and fruity. Pretty much your basic   IPA.
slight tequila aroma. light caramel color with a bitter flavor. Palate goes from strong at first to smooth.
Body is honey with a decent white head.  Aroma is malty and hoppy.  Flavour is tart yet fruity and finishes hoppy and chewy.   Good but Rogue as others that I prefer.

Good rose colored ale. First sip has a nice tartness to it and a smooth aftertaste. Quite a hearty flavor for an ale. I had it with a nice american burger and I feel it really enhanced the flavor. A new top american brewery on my list.
Strong malt aroma ubundantly hoppy, alcohol thins the palate slightly, strong fruity, hoppy finish.
Red with hardly any head.  Malt aroma.  Flavor of an American dark that became too sweet as it warmed.  I don't understand why this is rated so highly.

Reminded me more of an amber ale than a maibock.  Malt seems to dominate the hops, but still like the balance.  Found a pleasant molasses-like  accent in the palate.  Distinctive flavor in a good beer from a world-class brewer.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2008 Bottle.Small white head that mostly diminished, spotchy lacing, hazy, fast rising carbonation, and a orange golden hue. Nose was caramel, bitter, hoppy, grapefruit, and malty.Ditto for the flavor.Fairly smooth mouthfeel and medium in body.Decent for the style, nothing truly outstanding IMO and probably not one I want again as I didnt care for the flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 Nice hoppy aroma. This brew formed a nice medium head without too much carbonation. It lasted only a short while though and left an excellent lacing on the side of the glass. It is a cloudy light orange brown color. It has a slight aftertaste but is still on the mild side. A nice drinkable but unimpressive beer.
Aroma of hops. Pours a beautiful orange-amber, cloudy, with a meaty head. Lacing extrodinaire. Mouthfeel is chewy, hoppy blast at the end. A quality beer.
Good stuff. Full-bodied with a nice color and flavor. You can definitely tell you're drinking a "real" beer.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2003 Excellent beer. Cooper color with a nice head. A good hop flavor with the malt making its self known. Nicely balanced. A bock? I dont know but for fans of IPA's, APA's, or any hoppy beer, you cant do wrong here.
Great looking deep read/amber in color. Definite bursts of flavor all the way from the time it touches the lips to the swallow.

What an appropriate named beer for my 100th rating.  Not an exceptional beer, but I like the design of the skeleton with the beehive hat.  Caramel, coffee and toffee flavors with a hint of bitterness.  Mellow palate that hides the ABV.  Can't think of a easier beer to drink while coding up the bastard child of ratebeer.  Soy loco y con pistolo!
Dead Guy is a great everyday ale. Nice malty body balanced with subtle but omnipresent hops. Very nice.

I've passed this up on the shelf time and time again.  Rather pleased at the selection.  Malt tones in the front.  More bitter and floral to the end.  Light copper in color.  Good session I would say if I had to.

Really really nice.  I had no expectations, as I had no idea what this beer was, and it's just plain really good.  One of the best mystery beers I've gotten in a long time.  Malty and heavy, with a bit of a hoppy undercurrent.  Very nice.  Full bodied beer, wonderful to drink.
One of my favorite beers.  Rich and creamy without the bitter hops Rogue is noted for. Slightly sweet and very clean. Very nice.

Medium white head atop a honey-colored cloudy body.  Breadlike and slightly hoppy aroma.  Overall flavor is well balanced with a slight sweetness with mild (but noticable) hops.  Nice dry finish.  A pleasant ale.
nice amber color, medium sized head.  Sweet malt aroma, taste is of sweet caramel malt with a touch of hop bitterness at the end.A bit thin on the palate and not overly complex but still quite nice
Good red/rust color; Average white head; Aroma was sweet, clean, lovely. Good dryness from the hops. Nice maltiness as well. Tiny hint of alcohol. A standard bearer.

Draft: redish color, small white head. Aroma is pretty faint, though there is a touch of hops, and maybe a bit yeasty. Flavor is slightly hoppy, a little malty, with a bitterness throughout. Palate is pretty thin. There's not much to say bad about this beer, but there's not much good to say either.
Reddish-amber hue with sweet roasted malt aromas. Full body with fruity accents and a long hop finish. Rich and hearty.

- a slightly opaque amber color, light bubbly head, aroma is malty with a definite hop touch, sweet caramel and buttery as well; flavor has a sweet maltiness with a bitter/hop filled kick, butter toffee, caramel, light fruitiness (bananas), good texture

Small head which dissapates quickly.  Not much carbonation.  Seemed a little bit flat to me.  Decent foggy dark amber color.  Roasted malt aroma with slight overtones of fruit.  Hops present in the flavor but seems to be a little weak/watery in the flavor dept.  Slightly bitter and hoppy finish.  Not a great beer but complemented the ham dinner I just ate really well.  I guess every beer has its place.

Hazy light amber liquid, intermitent lace and quickly diminishing off white head.  Seems too dark for a true Maibock, but then again, it's also supposed to have lager yeast.  You go Rogue!  Nice Munich malt aroma to start followed by yeast, then light raisiny and a little bit of alcohol.  Other fruity esters seem absent even as it warms.  The Munich Malt flavor is interrupted very abruptly by the hop bitterness and there's some hop flavor as the beer heads down my throat along with some resinous hop mouthfeel.  The raisiny aroma does not come through much in the flavor and this beer seems to be balanced toward hops, which seems slightly out of my expectations.  It seems a little astringent due to overhopping and it also has a medium body.  Also not what I'd expect out of a Maibock style (lager or ale).  The carbonation is very nice, but this is definitely not my favorite beer from Rogue.
Nice beer.  Nice off-white head.  Noticable Malt and hopps and appropriately balanced.
Very rich, malty flavor and good color, smooth with an aftertaste, but not very irritating.
Nice tan head. Malt/yeast aroma. Slightly cloudy amber color. Rich malt taste--you don't notice the hops.

Nice dark amber with quickly diminishing head. Full bready malt flavor, but dominated by the Pac NW hoppiness. Flower petals, piney resin, soap and grapefruit. There is a nice smoothness about it with the hops reigned in enough to provide an astringent bitter finish, but still leave the lining of the digestive tract intact. Standard sort of well-made West Coast micro-brew - not a criticism.
I drink this beer when I cant chew down another Arrogant Bastard.  Its good but nothing to write mom about.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2003 (11Feb2003--12oz.bottle)
Disapp compared to my recollections of this beer.  Though others doubt that this is a bock, I can see it; it resembles carbonated, alcoholic iced tea, just like Shiner "Bock". ;)
Pours with a small/medium head, off-white, spongy, mostly receding.  Persistent, fine carbonation.
Medium amber in color, with considerable haziness.
Lots of fruity esters in the nose.  Also yeast, alcohol, and faint hops, though I couldn't detect Saaz.
I found a yeasty sourness to dominate the flavor early.  Considerable spicy hop bitterness.
The body is strange; a full peachy mouthfeel initially, but always finishes thin and dry.  This doesn't improve as the beer warms.
Kind of a clumsy brew.  Needs more crispness to be a bock; more "meat" to be an IPA.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 RERATE: A nice reddish orange color and creamy, slightly off white head start this one.  The aroma is nice, as well, though a little weak to be exceptional.  Flavor is very nice, and a lot different from how I remember it.  Slight bitterness in the aftertaste is nice, but FAR from being strong.  Flavor is full and nice!  A good beer, as usual, from Rogue!

Very nice orange-amber color, not much foam, subdued aroma. I like this brew, it has some characterstics that can be sensed in some of the  local IPA's or American strong ales, but is more laid back and therefore not quite as interesting. It works well if you are not in the mood for something more bold.
One of the first of Rogue that I tried.  Nice and hoppy as are most of Rogue's brews.  The bottle art is good too, although that is not a depndable indicator of what is inside.

Yet another winner from Rogue. Pours out to a very, good-looking amber in the glass with a light head. Carbonation is lively but not overbearing. Aroma is that of fruit with some floral overtones. Taste is nice and malty with a good dose of hops on the swallow, but not too much. I really like this brewery.

Slightly hazy orange color.small fine beaded off white head that doesnt last long. Nice spicey nose, some citrus notes. Medium bodied brew has a spiceyness to it.Taste some vanilla in the background.Decent malt and hop balance. Finishes fairly dry with a slight bite at the end.Good drinkin brew.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2003 Don't know why it's called an "ale" and a maibock; I don't think a beer can be both. Anyway, pours a bright, almost fluorescent orange. Creamy malty aroma--smells surprising deep for a lighter-colored beer. Flavor is smooth and malty with a pilsener-type mini hop bite at the end (not surprising given the Saaz hops). There are some fruit flavors here, mostly banana and peach, with a bit of walnut. Has one of the smoothest and most enviable textures of any beer I've drank.

A great meduim bodied beer.  I love the artwork on the bottle, and while it is being poured, you catch a bit of a fruit aroma, a balanced taste that is very mild and smooth, perhaps I did not pour it correctly but this beer had almost no head at all.

Orange tint to a dark golden colour. Fruity-strawberry smell and malty & hoppy tones. Medium body with a very light taste and a very subtle aftertate. No detectable characteristics keen to the beer. Too bad the taste doesn't give you as good of a beer as you'd expect from the smell and colour!
This one doesnt know if it wants to be a good heavy beer or a good light beer. Medium heavy in body mellow in flavor with a very mild hop flavor and aroma
not too heavy.  Clean and drinkable.  Well balanced medium hopped finish.  Little to no head.
One of my favorite beers.  A bit heavy at first, but once you get through the first half, the extra alcohol kicks in and you don't care.  Seriously, though, this is a great beer from Rogue.
This one grew on me as I downed the bottle.  Not the best Rogue has to offer, but a nice lighter ale.
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2003 pours a dark amber, malty with a semi-strong bitterness, not a real strong taste, but a good ale
Nice malty ale.  Fruity/grape flavor yet not too sweet.  Not as full of a taste as I had hoped for.  The flavor sorta dies on ya... maybe why it's named Dead Guy?

Amber body with rising carbonation, smallish white head, malty, sweet nose with a hint of hops. Sweet backbone with a fair bitterness. Bitterness and some fruit in the finish. Slight alcohol presence at the end. Decent ale, nothing special here. RERATE: Now I"m getting some smoke character as it warms. That"s worth another point. ;)

Wow.  There is a log going on in this glass.  A very nice dark amber color, with an off white head.  Theres a taste of orange, or some other citrus fruit to this beer.  Has a good bitterness that seems to stay with you, but isnt overpowering.  Complex taste and aroma.  This seems like a good cross between a Bock and an Ale.

Pours a dark, honey-like brown with a malty aroma (and what seems to be a dash of hops in the scent). The taste is rather bitter, but not to the point of being unbearable. Worth buying once or twice, but I couldnt make a real habit of it.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2009 [rerate needed] A harsh flavor was a good thing with this beer, with rich smokey flavors, and I find myself enjoying this one more and more.  Sure, its somewhere between a bock and an IPA, but there is an flavorfull quality about this beer not found in other bocks.  Hop sweetness mixes with a heft malty back amid flavors of pine, honey, caramel, and brown sugar.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2003 Not bad for a West Coast beer. Scent of Cascade-like hops pervades the first whiff. It"s not overwhelming, thankfully. Color is hazy brown splashed with red & gold hues within. Slight bitterness due to the hops. Wheat and malt taste within as well. Slight honey taste does it wonders. Not a bad attempt at an American German beer.

Re-rate:    I didnt want to change the numbers on this, but actually to elaborate more on what I noticed in the beer.  The aroma is strongly of West coast piney, perfumey hops.  The flavor sees much more malt than the aroma.  I think its really pretty good.  6/15/2002:  Deep honey/amber color.  Nice flavor of malt.  Hops in the finish.  Enjoyable.

Golden Amber.  Lingering head, perfect amount of hops in the aroma.  Bits of sunflowers and citrus that transports me to an open field with a crisp refreshing breeze.  Nice lingering bitter finish, much more reminicent of an ale than a bock, but another great selection from Rogue none the less.
This beer is a crisp sooth tasting Malibock that is not too sweet, and the bottle is cool
Slight metallic aroma which turned me off from the start.  Good color and a head.  Metallic aroma went away as it warmed.  Tasted quite malty, very little hops with a bitter and very dry finish.

In one six pack of this beer, I had 4 totally different experiences.  The first was one of the most boring ales Ive ever tasted.  The second was a fruity wonder.  The third rich and dark with a great hop aroma.  And the fourth showed the richness above, but with very noticeable alcohol helping the hops to frame the malt.  I cannot account for this variety.  But leaving aside the first sample, this beer is rather nice.
Nice amber color w/ lasting off-white head.  Hoppy aroma.  Nice sweet start with a bitter finish.  Nice carbonation.
Mediocre. Not enough flavor to satisfy, but beautiful and aromatic. All of Rogue brews are very distinct, must be the PacMan?
Love the skeletonized pope. Not very bock like at all with floral hops in the finish and some bite in the body. Eh whats to say? Im drinking at 4pm in the afternoon what more could I want?
I dont know if I believe this is a bock. Very enjoyable with a hint of hops trying its best to peek through.
umm...this beer isnt good or bad it seemed to snoop on the down side of the two, then again I dont care, I have the number one beer in stock hidden and gaining power. yea man.
deep honey color with malty aroma--wait I read that someone where before.  Very light with dry finish.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: I saw the bottle and i was like "Gee, this is gonna be the good..i mean look at the label, its got a skeleton on it"...then all went to hell. The aroma was that of pure malt..maybe some yeastiness, but the aroma was very weak and hard to distinguish. The Dead Guy Ale poured a very medium to darkish orange, but was very bright orange with mininal carbonation and practically no head in the light (the head lasted about 10 seconds, and that was with effort may i add). The taste was just a battering of malt on the tongue followed by one of the most god-awful hop bitternesses i have ever had to deal with. It ended very dry and unclean in my opinion..i like the carbonation aspect, but the maltiness is overboard, and the spicey/bitter finish is just terrible...it makes me cringe in horror..it almost has a grapefruity aspect to it. To say the least i wont be going near this again.....this has almost as much malt as a malt liquor for cryin out loud!!!

Not bad.  This is not exactly my favorite style, however, I do enjoy a change of pace.  It was more like a sweet ale then a true bock.  A little hop mixed with a heafty malt sweetness.  Well balanced.
I love Rogues version of this Maibock. It was crisp and clean with very nice color. Quite malty to the nose and the slightly dry finish was pleasant.
Very malty smell and taste. Bitter and full of hops. An appreciative amber with a kick ass bottle. Should be in everyones rating list.
Another fine Rogue product from a recovering Rogue hater. Malty flavor with light hops. Very good.
Nice floral hop nose with a bit of malty goodness.Good balance to the flavor with a little bitterness near the end. Decent session brew.
Amber with lasting off white head. Small bead. Good hop/dry malt nose.Carmel malt flavor.Faint lingering hop finish
Nice color the aroma seemed kind of lightly malty nice hops in the taste a a slighlty bitter finish hmmm might have been the beer before might have to rerate at a later date again to be fair
This was pretty good, but it is not the greatest by any stretch.  I really like the label.

I really like this beer.  One of my first exposures to west coast micro beers, and still one of my favorites.  Nicely malty, nicely hoppy ... seems hoppier than anything that could honestly be called a German-style beer; the hoppiness is more like an IPA but the taste is, well, roguish.  Very nice beer with pizza or a sandwich.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2014 4/17/14 re-rate: over 11 years since my original rating. Have had it a couple of times since, though probably not more than that. Not my favorite aroma. Overripe dark fruit. Murky orangish amber with a think mostly white head and very little lace. Interesting that ratebeer calls this a Heller Bock and Rogue calls it a German style Maibock in its description. Drinkable, with a softly bitter finish. Pretty good although nowhere near the 4.4 I rated it in 2002. 12/1/02: The label and name have always intimidated me, but I am glad I finally overcame what was misguided fear. Very malty nose, sweet. Reddish-orange in color with good head retention. Off-white head and great brussels lace. Quite bitter in flavor, the malt from the aroma doesnt come out as much in the taste. This is one tasty brew. Can tell it is high in alcohol content. Another winner from Rogue! 8,5,9,4,18
kind of weak for a bock, but what can I say, Its a classic & oh so drinkable.
This was a great beer...it made me fall in love with the Rogue Brewery...the name is very cool and the aroma was powerful in a good way. Definentely give it a try.
Red amber colour, long lasting fluffy white head. Aroma is sweet, fruity.  Taste is initially malty, leading to a hoppy bitter finish.
Great beer. A little much on the hops for me, but overall very good bock.  Slight cloudiness, and wonderful finish.  Very light and cleansing.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2003 Was 3.4 Its smooth for a dead guy. Cloudy orange amber with light orange white head. Which is really thick and slow to disappear. Strong hop aroma clean hop taste and no metalic notes. Creamy mouth feel with bitters on the back of my tounge. No alcohol notes great for a strong ale.
An ok ale. Red in color. Not a bad Bock brew. Very Smooth with not much character. OK
pale in color, light in flavor.  This was a nice descent pale with plenty of yeast.

Copper hued with a light head.  Malty aroma with hints of caramel.  The body is semi-thick and chewy.  It finishes with a fair amount of bitterness and a slight warming effect.  An overall decent brew.
Nice golden aroma.  Good head no lacing.  SLightly cloudy.  Rich flavour of yeast malt and hops.  Thick body.
great beer. its not the most aromatic, but the taste is fantastic and its a very pretty pour.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 amber color with an off-white head; malty aroma, super creamy
 malty flavor, I don't find the hops over powering, In fact, I find them completely, if not over-balanced by the malts
Another good brew from Rogue.  Malty nose with a nice, hoppy flavor.  Thick and decently bitter for a bock.  I enjoyed it.
Bottle- Nice honey color. The aroma is quite hoppy, as is the flavor. The malt appears about midway then gives way to a hoppy finish. The finish tends to be quite acidic.

Reddish bronze color, looks like orange blossum honey. No head except a small ring of bubbles circling the glass. Malt, toasted wonderbread and floral hop aromas. Malty semi-sweet flavor gives way to a semi bitterness. Finish is bitterly acidic. This doesnt really fit as a bock. Negative points for hiccups!

This beer is more typical of my disappointment with Rogue than the Imperial IPA, which Im a huge fan of.  Dead Guy is pretty much just that - lifeless, unexciting, slightly sticky malt body with some dank graveyard weeds serving for hops.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2003 A cloudy, brownish red in color. Hops are nice and citrusy with a floral hint but are slightly overpowered by a sweet malt. Thick, sticky mouthfeel without much carbonation. Interesting but far from great.

Ordered a draft of this stuff. Very undistinguishing. Pretty hoppy but much too sweet which weighs down the tastebuds. I found this beer to be extremely filling - I declined to finish my glass. Has that ultra-generic microbrew flavor that I HATE - see: any Petes brew, all seasonal Sam Adams, any Sierra Nevada, etc. Boring. Bloaty. Bleh.
A very nice, unique bock. A good balance of yeast and hops. Pleasant amber color, very easy to drink.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2005 Bottle. Head is initially small, frothy, off-white, fully diminishing. Body is medium amber. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, toasted bread), moderately hoppy (apricot, herbs). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, moderately acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Strikingly average and certainly not bock-like or German in character at all.  Smells like an American amber ale or perhaps an English strong ale.
Wonderful beer.  Nice and hoppy, not too heavy on the malt.  Much fresher taste on tap than in the bottle.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2003 butter yeasty aroma that causes as many smiles as hanging out with Team Fucked Up at the beach.  It just says drink me.  Excellent ballance, all I can say is that it makes me smile.  Good hops, malts seem really strong as well.  Awsome.

Bock?!?!? Hoppy and bitter. Cloudy and reddish copper. No head to speak of. Theres a little maltiness in there but not like a real bock. Ale yeast for a bock, interesting. A different sort of brew, not terrible, but not good enough to be really interesting.

The medium-brown color gives a hint of the subtle complexity of this unique ale.   Overall, it has a medium body, but, as ales go, it is very rich.  There is a subtle maltiness and a lot of hops.  There are very vague, yet enjoyable, hints of flowers and caramel.  Nice finish, too.
It tastes like alcohol, smells like alcohol...looks like alcohol?  Well, it also tastes like flowers.  Not bad, I guess.  Very hoppy.
Tap.  This was the first beer at the Rogue pub in Portland that would end in Newport, OR with 18 samples over a week.  Deep honey color.  Malty and grainy flavor.  A rich full flavored beer.
Good crisp, hoppy brew. Not my favorite of styles but certainly work trying.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2003 I have drank great ales for 20 years from all over the world and Rogue Dead Guy as well as Sierra Nevada Pale Ale are the only American Ales that would rate with the best from England, Scotland, Belgium and Germany. Dead Guy you are a winner. Readily available at bars in Oregon this stuff is in a class of its own, when it comes to American brewing. With Anchor Steam Beer of San Francisco, one of the truly American creations. Hats off to those guys at ROGUE. THE First MAIER-ALE. If you get some bottles that dont taste great, try again, it is unpasteurized so the Pacific Northwest is really the only safe place to try it!
A very good beer. Strong and well-balanced malt and hop flavors. A good degree of complexity. Heavy-bodied though. Dont expect to drink many at a go.
Yeah! the label still glows in the dark.It was quite delicious;Medium hops with very fruitty ripe peach flavors.Nice smooth finish.
Great copper color. Good combination of malt and hops. This is a damn good looking ale. Follows suit of other Rogues.
Nice malt and hop balance, with a good hoppy finish.  It has good head retention and beautiful dark copper color.

Hoppier than I expect from a bock, and than other people here seem to be saying, makes me wonder if I got an off batch. But still very good nonetheless. I found the aroma to have quite a hoppy kick, and the flavor I would characterize in much the same way. It was a very good blend of malt and hops, with hints of some sour malt that seemed apple like. A very good beer, I will come back to it.

Tasted from tap:
Nutbrown, no head.
Strawberry aroma and taste. Long, nice malt aftertaste.

8/07/02: Living in the Great Northwest, I forgot Rogue also markets this stuff goes by names other than Dead Guy Ale. Regardless of label, what strikes one immediately about this brew is its gorgeous orange-amber color; head has canyons carved in its off-white sea-foam. Aroma is fairly light--equal parts malt and yeast--earthy...Flavor has the immediate malt presence one expects from a bock, but is nicely bittered as well...The flavors are sequenced so that the traditional bock maltiness is not compromised, but then the complex roasty-bitter follow-up steps to the fore and a conspiracy of various malts and hops provides an impressive complexity to both the main body and finish. Carbonation is fairly restrained, which allows diverse array of flavors to emerge. For such a flavorful offering, it is surprisingly light as well.  This is not exactly your traditional maibock, but in true Rogue style, it blazes a trail in a bit of a new direction...Delightful! Re-Rate 10/21/02: Molasses tones come through more prominently in aroma this time around, and overall temperment of this brew seemed softer from my last sampling, but no less satisfying...One of my favorite Rogue offerings...

Very nice beer, lingering malt flavor with a strong hop flavor to balance the malt.  Reddish Amber in color, good Belgian lace.  Drink a few of these in a moderate amount of time and you will either be dancing on top of the bar or sleeping under it.

Amber liquid with moderate foam retention.  Assertive aroma full of flowers, caramel, honey, and lots of toasty malt.  Flavors are very well balanced.  Finishes simeltaneously hoppy and toasty with substantial bitterness.  A perfect beer for converts.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Orange-amber colour with minimal head. Fruity and flowery in both aroma and flavour, with a good balance of malt and hops. Not mindblowing, but a solid and pleasant brew.

Dirty orange/amber hue with a moderate size off white head. Lovely bready and molasses-like aromas. Not much hops for the nose to inhale. Very full bodied mouthfeel that is extremely malty with some notes of brown sugar. Its called Dead Guy Ale but is a bock? Go figure.

Light amber color, medium head. Medium bodied, amber ale. Fairly malty, yet with a nice strong hop bite. Some hop spiciness. Smooth taste. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is crisp and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Orange/reddish in color with sour mash tasting malts.   Long finish, longer after warming.
Golden in color, white head.  Honey is definitly present in the taste.  Aftertaste in somewhat umpleasent.
This one is a bit above average on all accounts.  Nice orange appearance with a somewhat sweet, fruity aroma.  Quite malty flavor with a touch of hops.
Another tastey Rogue beer. Like most Rogues, this one has a very distinctive flavor. The bottles are good, but it is even better on tap.

For a beer called Dead Guy Ale I was expecting something a bit more killer, something that would thrash my senses and leave me bewildered like the Shakespear stout. I found this to be the least hoppy of any Rogue Ive had. Pretty mellow, with a pervasive maltiness - which is typical of bocks, but I was expecting something different. I may come back and re-rate this later, but for now I am left with no great impression. But even a mediocre response to a Rogue beer is usually better than average. Ill be bock

Deep orange color.  Very malty, molasses with a little metallic taste.  Very nice.  My only complaint with this is that it leaves a strange aftertaste on your tongue, almost like some diet/sugerfree things do.  BEST LABEL!

red-ish colour, carmel,malty
fairly well balanced.
somewhat fruity
This beer has a sweet malty aroma.  Starts out with a honey sweetness and finishes with a pretty good hoppy kick.  Not a typical maibock by any means.  I enjoyed the 22 oz. bomber.
Kinda average for a Rogue beer.  At least it washes down my pizza well.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2004 Rerate Pretty much the same description all around - except I notice much more of a hoppy citrusy flavor.Very hoppy for a bock, not as well balanced with the malitness. Original 3.9 Aroma - slight citrus to molasses - hard to place - but very present. Appearance - large frothy off-white head - orange color. Flavor - sweet - with a strong finish a nd a slightly bitter aftertaste.

Hazy reddish-orange brew with a thin creamy head. Hoppy smell with hints of orange, though the scent isnt very prolific. Sweet citrusness to this beer when drank. Some spicyness and a bit of earthyness. Slight bit of peppery bite in there as well. Leaves a nice hop aftertaste. Feels a bit syrupy, or thick in the mouth. Good beer.
Im not too sure this is a bock, but I know its a very good beer. Perfect hop/malt balance and beautiful to look at.

Golden-reddish amber hue.  Off white head quick diminishing but leaving some nice lace.  Fruity bready yeast aromas, raisons, currants.  Malt and sweetness first, medium bodied, and balanced flowery finish, yeast and bitterness linger.  Im glad its not overly hopped,a very nice brew from the masters at Rogue.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2004 ReRate-Even though i really like this brew now, i dont think its a bock still to this day.  Tastes like a malty/spicy hopped APA still.  Pours a nice orange hue with huge off white head.  medium carbonation.  sweet malty aroma with some sharp pineyness/spicyness in the hops.  flavors are very smooth malts with a long bitter finish from the saaz hops.  A very solid beer that you can get anywhere.  Again, this tastes like an ale, not a lager.  


22oz "bomber" bottled as "dead guy ale"
This is not a bock-this is an APA with a little different twist to it.  Malt up front-cascade hop middle and a very bitter finish that is hard to describe(saaz?)  definately not what i was expecting, but an interesting suprise to say the least.
Pretty tasty stuff.  Little head nice color.  Alcohol becomes a lot more noticable as it warms, but i guess thats normal.
Bocks are my favorite style of beer and this one is a wonderful bock.  A very smooth and rich beer with a great taste.
UPDATED: APR 3, 2007 Very malty, but well balanced with a generous helping of hops. Much like an American pale ale.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2003 Re-Rate: Dark red with toffee head.  Hard to pin down malty sugary aroma.  Flavor is heavily candied malt.  Bittery edge at end.  Not as good as a remembered, down from a 4.0 at original rating.
Nothing to throw up about
I think a 3.61 Average is a little high for this beer, but its not bad.
I had the Dead Guy.  Ale that is.  Full of flavor, and just damn tasty and refreshing.

Aroma of roasted malt, and essence of butterscotch. Red/amber, big fluffy white head. Hoppy taste with fine maltiness. Big mouthfeel, good tongue tingle. Very nice aftertaste like bitter almonds. Terrific!
beautiful reddish copper colour.  nice malt hop balance.  might be dangerous at 6.6%abv;  this is very, very drinkable.

I found this beer to be lots of malt, and not so much hops.  I have had it several times and felt that way.  It seems very sweet to me and reminds me of Stone Pale Ale.  Lots of really great and rich malt flavors with just enough hops to keep it from being sickeningly sweet.  This is a great session beer.

I am suprised that this falls under the rubrick of a maibock. Same malt character, true, but quite a bit more hops exhibited than in the classic maibock.  Still, ignoring the style, nice malt sweetness and excellent hop zip.  A great beer to herald the coming of summer.  I could drink a number of these at one sitting, or sip one slowly over a long evening.

The aroma and taste were a little too bitter for my tastes. This is a well crafted beer with a beautiful copper color and thick creamy head. The taste was full of sweet, tart, bitter, apple-like flavors. Good ale, but wrong taste for me.
Another superior Rogue Beer.  Nice alcohol tang, sweet flavor, blended hops and malt.  Very nice.  Very Very nice.
super flavor, hoppy perfection. delicious aftertaste, a fine ale indeed. dark red/brown color, clear. truly enjoyable.
Nice malty smell, cloudy golden color. Excellent lace, more carbonated than a lot of beers. Strong malt taste. As it warmed, got a bit of a citrus flavor as well.
Very hoppy for the style. A little sweet and malty. Nice stuff.
UPDATED: JUN 25, 2010  12oz bottle:  Pours a clear orange with a thin white head,  huge malty aroma, medium bodied, ample carbonation, starts and ends lightly sweet.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2003 One year on, re rated. Bumped up the appearance one point, well balanced and hoppy. Bottled, at the GBBF in London. Amber coloured with moderate head and condition. Hoppy aroma becoming malty and caramel like with a hint of yeastiness thrown in. Good level of hop flavour and bitterness balancing out the fruity-yeasty body and a thick chewy aftertaste tempered by a nice bitterness. The first of an evenings drinking of (mostly) American brews.

I tried the St. Rogue Red and this beer back to back.  To me, they tasted very similar malt-wise, however this beer was missing a lot of the hop character of the St. Rogue Red.  It was a good tasting beer that I would try again.  I dont understand the comparisons to IPAs because this beer had a very low hop profile to me.

I havent seen this stuff in close to a decade, so I was very pleased when I stumbled across it in my local GROCERY store (although they really do have a nice selections of exotic beers). On part, I agree with Wakie in that DGA does have some strong similarities with an IPA (after all, it is brewed in Oregon), but it also finishes with the undeniable sweet, full-bodied flavor that was present in a couple Maibock/bocks Ive had. I for one, think the combination is great.
A darker malt flavor.  Reminded me more of an IPA than a bock.  Very basic but not a very good bock.  I was thoroughly disappointed.
Dead Guy Ale. Very tasty.  When I have some money and dont want to buy cheap beer, I get this. Kind of spendy here, 7.50 a 6pk but well worth it, a great beer.

Had this as Dead Guy Ale  Cloudy malt with a refreshing taste. I did not detect much aroma but it had a lovely copper look, with a translucent body. trademarking a good ale. Good feel down. I am gonna try it with the shakespear stout in a black and tan.

Had this beer as Dead guy ale in NC--which has a beer upper limit of 6% (I try not to 
let that bother me when I brew beer).  Complex malt flavor.  Splendid hop flavor--with
a blend of bitterness.  Smooth initial flavor, with some caramel flavor.  The appearance 
is cloudy lending to believe it has some wheat malt.  I didnt think it tasted like a Mai-bock,
but I think it is one of the best light colored beers available.  I love Perle hops in my own 
beer for bittering, so I like it here as well.  While I think it missed the target as far as 
being a maibock, it is still one of the best beers I have had.
Had this as the dead guy ale.  A very nice strong flavor that is slightly sweet, with a very strong, complex malt flavor and moderate hoppiness.  A very tasty beer.
Great Flavor but a very hoppy taste.  Definatly a repeat preformer.  A high quality bock.

me like. me like a lot.
tasty, very easy to drink. i have no complaints at all. god i love the northwest.

Rogue Markets this as Dead Guy Ale.. Picking it up I expected it to be something else flavor wise... I was surprised... It is certainly not what one thinks of as an Ale... It has a darn complex flavor.. Its hard to describe...  It seems more like a fancy-schmancy import than some domestic micro Ale...

Recommend trying to once.. wont appeal to everyones tastebuds, but is pleasant with no annoying lingering taste.
Not quite as much flavor as I would like.  Not bad but could be better. Although Im not the biggest fan of bock in the world.
A good brew. had a nice copper color but not much head. quite malty folowed by a hint of hops but nothin overpowering.

This was a bock?  It had none of the heaviness or extreme maltiness that area apparent in some bocks.  Great looking orange and red tinted copper color.  Expertly balanced..I cant say that either the matls or hops were too much.  Noticed a honey-bready sensation among a few other things, then a crisp bit of hops bitterness at the finish.  Very nice.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 Bread-like yeast, caramel and peach syrupIn the distance, a subtle citrusy hop bitternessA tad too fatty sweet to be quaffable and a tad too lazy to be complex, but this is still drinkable and pleasant
Looks like a Marzen, Advertised as an Ale, classified as a Bock. You tell me! Sweet malty nose. Initial sweet fruit flavor with a hop bite in the finish. A very interesting brew.
Light amber color, small head. Pretty strong hop flavor. Long bitter finish.

Clear, a beautful copper with orange hues. Decent head and lace. Malty nose with some caramel and honey sweetness. Medium bodied,very rich, crisp,earthy hops, honey is definite present, solid malt (cereal like) backbone.  A divinley balanced brew.
True amber color, beige head.  Initially crisp in the mouthfeel.  Tastes then alternate between a sweet malty honey flavor and a refreshing hop taste...well balanced...well done.

This beer has a nice dark amber color and tan head. Nice aroma to it. Some sweetness to the taste, with a bit of tanginess. The title and label may be a way to get some of my punk rock buddies to switch from drinking Rolling Rock.

Doesnt really taste like a bock to me. Has distinctive ale qualities in my book.  Stong hoppiness is out of style.  Decent malt qualities but not in thick and rich enough to qualify as a good bock to me.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2003 Strong hops taste, higher alcohol. Not too bad, but not this brewer's best by any means. Rerate: Sweetness dominates the palate, but that's ok. Really drinkable and an all around good beer.
I was vey upset with this brew by one of the better brewerys in the US.  It was lacking something, but I cant put my finger on it.

Now I find out this is a bock...I wasnt sure what I was drinking.  The hops really came through, but I detected a good malt backbone to support this.  Wasnt as drinkable as I would have liked.  I could sense the alcohol at the end of the sip.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2014 Rerate.  Poured from bottle.  Brown sugar, lemon meringue and hops in aroma.  Translucent amber, thin white head.  Piney hop flavor, with a sweet honey / caramel flavor and some herb and spice notes.  A touch of wood smoke as well.  Great, crisp feel.    Excellent.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 13, 2003  One of the nicest looking beers, deep honey/amber with a nice malty nose, hops almost overpowered by the malt, but evident, one of rouges least hoppy beers around 35 IBU,  malty like a bock with a more pronounced hop flavor and fruiter esters. damn good!
Very Flavorful. Great beer.
UPDATED: AUG 3, 2003 Confusing. Too hoppy for a bock, rich and malty which is consistent for a bock. Hmmm...
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Smelled and looked like an IPA to me. Looks nice, with a golden orange appearance, but not like a bock. The flavor is not that enjoyable, and as Gregor says, smells like rotten pussy. Not a bad beer, but I probably wouldnt get it again. Re-rate 5/14/02 Well, I didnt smell roten pussy this time, just a little roasted malt. The middle was pretty hoppy, and finished dry and bitter. Not as bad as I thought it was the first time, but still nothing fantastic.
UPDATED: JUN 10, 2012 Spicy, refreshing, and enjoyable.  It has the flavor and aroma of springtime.
An ale, not a bock.  Decent, but unremarkable.  Not really that hoppy, considering its a Rogue, thats unusual.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2004 Amber-honey color, with a white fluffy head, nice lacing, smells sweet candy and hops. Starts sweet medium body with noticeable hop bite, strange for the style, goes down very smooth and easy

Wow, so many names for a beer.  I think that dead guy ale is pretty damn cool.  Rogue and Stone come up with the best beer names in the world.  Okay, what do we have here?  Reddish-brown, pretty foamy head.  Sweet, spicy smell.  The taste is slightly complex and hard to pin down at first.  Hops are dominated by the maltiness, which really shows itself in the dry finish.  I found this to be a negative, and it seems a lot more alcoholic than 6.6%.  Hmm.

May is here, and what better way to welcome it than with a very large bottle of Rogues Dead Guy Ale - though I am confused as to why a classic German Maibock is referred to as an Ale.  This brew pours a clear red honey.  The colossal creamy off-white head is fully lasting with excellent lacing.  The well tempered spicy nose is mostly flowery and citrus hops balanced with caramel malt.  The flavor is exceptionally balanced with a very sweet flowery and spicy start and a long bisquity bitter finish.  The thin dry body is soft with a chalky feel to the finish.  Yet another winner from Rogue (BIG SURPRISE!!).

A very good beer from Rogue.  They have a tendency to over-hop their beers but this one is balanced just right.  Nice deep carmel color and off-white head with some duration and nice lacing.  The flavor of the alcohol was completly masked, and the balance from start to finish was excellent.
Very complex and full flavored Bock... Great name and label!! Nice as an after dinner brew.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2003 Why not list as Dead Guy Ale since this is apparently how most are drinking it as.  Not much of a noticeable aroma, but certainly not unpleasant by any means...just doesn't make a strong impression.
Had out of the bottle (had no choice) so appearance rating possibly too low.  Nice malty flavors with slight nutty, estery flavors in the middle and a mild hop finish.  Was much better than I anticipated and worth trying.
very tasty! alot of flavor,hints of fruit..this is a fine ale!

Had it on tap as Dead guy Ale.  Aroma is decent but not very potent.  I loved the look of this beer- nice deep mahogany red with a nice head.  Tasted sweet with a low hop presence. I usually prefer hoppier beers, but this was really good.  I like thier Shakespeare stout and thier brutal bitter better, but this is still good.
I am not a big bock drinker, but this stuff is pretty decent. It is very malty and heavy. Dont take big swigs though, save that for the busch light.

A Maibock thats actually yop fermented. Sugary pretty much defines this beer, syrupy, tofeeish with slight tang in aftertaste. Refreshing and characterful. Not a true bock, but a good introduction and interesting Rogueish twisted interpretation.

Light-brown color (judging by crayola standards,  malty almost fabricated sweetener in the nose (equal or nutrasweet). Just the slightest bit of hops to dry up the finnish. Mine was Dead Guy and that is all Ive seen it as. A nice bock albeit a little expensive.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2005 Caramel aroma, molasses and sweet toasted malts. Mild fruitiness to the hops. Dark amber clear with lacing off-white head. Medium bodied with medium smooth carbonation. A lot of caramel taste - a caramel beer ice cream sundae, so sayeth my wife. Toasted malt, bit of molasses. Finish is medium-heavy nutty harsh bitter. After is light clean bitter and a bit sweet.
Better than average beer.  Good color and nice combination of flavors.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2004 Rerate 02/11/2004: On draught at the MoJoe Lounge at Easton. Pours a clear reddish-amber color with a thin skeleton-bone head. Thin and quick lacing. The aroma is mildly citrusy hops along with a touch of spice. Medium body, with a somewhat flavorable blend of floral hops, citrus, honey and spice. The flavor is kind of like Arrogant Bastard's "Mini Me". The finish is mildly bitter making this for an all-around good-drinking beer.

04/05/02 (3.4): Mine was under the 'Dead Guy' label. Citric aroma and reddish-orange color, thick and long-lasting head. I was a little put off by the flavor at first but it grew on me. Good balance of hops and fruit.
Began with a sweet overtone and then the hop dryness kicked in. There are other bocks I prefer but certainly this is an interesting version. I had this as Dead Guy Ale.
Mmm. Good beer. Like the rest of the Rogues, its hard to beat.

Pretty golden color in the glass, and a sweet, slightly malty aroma make a nice intro to this brew.  I was surprised at the sweet taste as well, since I figured it would be as hoppy as the other Rogue brews Ive tried, but it wasnt.  It was sweet and smooth, but thats about all I can say...its a nice brew, but not spectacular.  It was a slightly hoppier version of Dundees Honey Brown.

Had this as Dead Guy Ale and wasnt disappointed. I like the Shakespeare Stout better, but Rogue does offer a wide variety of beers. This one came off smooth, but not wonderfull, no bitterness, but a full-flavored beer on the whole. Id buy it again, but would rather drink other of their products.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2003 Fairy nice effort by Rogue.  Not an
overwhelming aroma but not unpleasent.
Looks good in the glass and has
a good flavor.  Pretty good.

Update:  Aroma is pleasently hoppy.  Flavor reminds me of a bitter.  Is this brew a bock??

i detect a bit of hops in the aroma, color is a nice red..i dont derive anything that distinct from this brew...not bad at all though...not one of my favorite styles, so take what you will from my rating.
Yummy ale.  Hoppy and bitter, just how I like em!
Not bad but packed quite and after bite. Not on my top ten list.
kinda strong bite.. note too bad
Rogues interpretaton of an Octoberfest / Marzen, so not as hoppy as some other Rogue offerings. May not be a perfect example of the style, (it is an ale, after all) but still good

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2008 Nectarine appearance in this well balanced ale with a feint hop component.  This beer is noticeably bigger on the front and lighter on the finish.  A solid ale.  Re-rated 1-19-08- Was called Rogue White-Crane Bitter - Same nectarine appearance with wonderful of aroma of honey and candi malts and sweet citrusy hops with touch of bubblegum. Medium-bodied with a very dry finish, Malt and hops intermingle, slight hint of crystal/caramel and perhaps a rye crispness on the finish. Nice flavors just very dry.
One of the better Rogue beers. Nice aroma. Terrific finish. Havent had a Rogue beer yet that I havent enjoyed. Rogue is at the top of my list!

I agree with Kilgore415: it looks like a cool beer, it smells allright, but then the taste is strange and unrewarding.  :(

Dont let this beer turn you off to Rogue, though, their Brutal Bitter is wonderful!
Looks better than it actually is.  A jumble of tastes, none of which are that good.
Hm...Ive had better.

Deep golden orange coloured ale.     Dead Guy Ale doesnt seem to be much like a Bock.   Striking grassy flavours and a floral aroma highlighted this brew by Rogue.  The finish provided a pleasent bitter.
didnt seem like a bock - tasted more like a nut brown. malty, too sweet at the finish. (had it under the DeadGuyAle moniker on 1/28/2002)
A bit stronger than I was hopeing for.
Not too heady, bottle very cool, gotta love the name, stomadail!!!
a damn good beer hoppy and bitter.  Goes great with DnD!
Not what I was expecting from a beer that sometimes gets called a bock.  Average palate, quite bubbley.  More hoppy than my liking.

A very enjoyable beer, aroma of malt and hops,nice golden brown color, The flavor is crisp, dry, and bitter with a nice sense of malts in the taste as well.  I very much enjoy the bitter finish.  Excellent beer.

Dark orange color with a medium white head that quickly dissipated.  Fruity, flowery cascade aroma.  Bitter tea and candy sugar flavor.  Substantial mouthfeel but not cloying due to the dryness of the hops.  Tastes like a good but typical California style ale notwithstanding the fact it is called a bock.
A little to hoppy for me, but its a nice beer.
Excellent beer from someone who normally isnt classified a hop head. Small head, deep honey color, strong hop/raisin/fruit taste goin on, slightl;y bittersweet finish. Overall a great NW brew.
Having tried many rogue products, i still feel the rating are a little high on most, but the dead guy ale is pretty good.

my brief websearch on this beer shows it to be something of a hybrid: a bock or oktoberfest brewed as an ale.  since i dont brew em and im just learning the nomenclature, this could be a sasparilla for all i know, but its a typically grand offering from rogue,my favorite domestic brewer. the chesnut color is about pantone 152, like a kestrals back or the crown of a chipping sparrow.  cloudy suggests variability so lets call it transluscent rather.  im guessing my bottle is a tad flat since these reluctant bubbles can only muster a fragile head of 1/4 inch.  the saaz and perle malts bespeak raisin and pumpernickle,  as inviting as a wink from sandra bullock.  its sweetish, but not so much that youd pour it over ice cream or put a paper parasol in it.  yay, rogue!
Fruity flavor with hoppiness.  Reminiscent of Mac and Jack African and similar NW microbrews.
Quite wonderful beer.  Has a little more hop flavor to it than other bocks.  Not only is the label cool, but Rogue Dead Guy Ale is a wonderful bock.
Malty aroma. Slightly cloudy orangish, creamy head. Good palate. An odd (but not unpleasant), dry grainy/vegetable flavor. Trailing bitter.Velvety palate.  Recommend with Italian food.
Id like it better if the hops didnt dominate.

Dead Guy not what I expected -- nice orange amber hue, huge head that faded too quickly.  It had a nice front -- fruity taste of apricots, but then the back end was overboozed and unpleasantly bitter.  It was a decent experience, but I think I will spend my $9 a six on something else next time.
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: Very crisp and hoppy.
Fruity, malty with a nice hop balance. The ABV is apparent after a few sips. Nicely done.
This was nice. Flavorful. Quite hoppy. Rich. This is really a bitter beer. I really enjoyed it.
Pretty good ale.  Very straightforward.
an absolute pleasure to drink, when i think drinking a good ale, this brew has the qualities i dream about
This Dead Guy seems pretty lively to me...hes still kicking!
A decent beer, easy to drink, though the best aspect is the glow in the dark bottle around haloween time.
nice aroma,  malty,  slight bitterness in finish.

Seemed in between an APA and a bock to me. Has a fairly rich malty/caramel flavor to it, but theres a big flavor of (cascade?) hops going on that I wouldnt expect from a bock. It really worked well though.
Dark orange color, fruity and citrusy aroma.  Strong hop bitterness, high carbonation.  Sweet palate and a warming alcohol content.  Too strong in the hop area for me.
UPDATED: MAY 12, 2003 Average bock beer, nicely balanced, very drinkable, but nothing too special
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2003 A deep flavored brew. Good stuff, very solid body and flavor. This one gets the ol thumbs up. Dead guy, what a cool name.
pretty dark amber color with an off biege colored head leaves a nice lacing on the glass. Good balance and mouthfeel with a hoppy bite in the end. Good work here!

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2003 The beer pours a translucent burnished copper color with a monumental head that is frothy in texture, the color a light beige, and as it dissipates leaves behind a sticky thick sheet of lace. The aroma of bubble gum, sweet malt, fresh and pleasing to the senses, start is ambrosial, thickly malt, the top is moderate in feel. Finish is masterfully hopped, middling in its carbonation and the aftertaste bitter and long lasting. This Rogue Ale is a long time favorite with me and I always keep a few on hand and to quote William Congreve. Dead Guy Ale hath charms to soothe the savage breast, To soften rocks, or bend a knotted oak.  Well thats not exactly what he said, but works for me!
This beer is hard to come by, but is a good example of Rogues brewing style.  I highly reccommend this beer, and any other Rogue product
is this what after life taste like?hell im there with a open stomach.
A fine Rogue product. A sweet start and nice bitter finish/aftertaste. Goes great with sausage and kraut.

I have tried several different years of this beer, even the first year with the glow-in-the-dark bottle label.  First time tasted like soapy water.  Next time was better.  Then I had it on Tap - MUCH BETTER!
A very well balanced beer. Shows some malty sweetness along with a fair amount of hop bitterness and spiciness. A bit thinner mouthfeel than I expected based on the appearance and aroma.
nice bittering, honey aftertaste, sweet at first, really good beer
A terrific beer.  Well balanced, rich and a bit hoppy.  Truly a pleasure to drink.

A very tasty amber colored ale.
extremely smooth palate(cask-conditioned)
aromas of cascade hops.

an enjoyable drink

Wow, amazing to see more than a few people other than myself find Rogue to be fallable.  Amber with a quick head and hoppy aroma, I found this to be quite bland, with a slight hoppiness and buttery flavor, and a mildly yeasty aftertaste.
Amber with a lacey head. Sweet, candy-like aroma, but sadly not much taste. Slight hoppiness and a very yeasty aftertaste.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2004 Really remarkable beer.  The past few comments sum it up well:  amazing color and fruity nose (nectarine?), a wonderfully rich, malty mouthfeel and tongue, as strong as any stout or Belgian, and a smooth, warm finish.  My favorite Rogue thus far.

July 03 re-rating.  The dryness in this does not complement the heavy earthiness well, IMHO.  It's good, but I find it harder to drink a bomber of this now; guess I'm not as big a bock fan, and my tolerance for Rogue's overhopping has hit its peak.

I greatly enjoyed this beer.  Your first hint that this is a treat is the supurb color of the brew.  The sight is followed by a slightly hoppy aroma befiting a well balanced beer.  The first sip reveals a malty character up front followed by a slight spicy bitterness which work well together.  This beer possesses a wonderful mouthfeel and represents a job well done by Rogue.  The only questionable aspect of this beer appears to be inconsistancy in quality.  Read some of the other reviews and judge for yourself.
Definitely a unique beer experience.  One of the fullest non-stouts Ive ever encountered--the entire mouth is involved on this one.
Malty aroma -- some carmel. A full mouthy texture (not a tongue slider) without stickiness. Some hoppiness but no real distinct component.
I am not a Bock lover, but this is quite nice. The roasted malt sits in perfect balance with the hops sitting way back. My first Rogue. Not my last by a longshot.
Bizarre. Undrinkable at first, but it grows on you. Not the best Rogue has to offer but worth a taste just for the sake of its obvious complexity.
A well made brew, as is most of Rogue. Not my favorite style by a long shot(Bock). Has that pinpoint malt sharpness for an aftertaste, while totally lacking any hop flavor.

This is the definition of a good bock.  Nice buttery malt boquet, smooth malt flavour, and an assertive hop finish.  If anything, I would like a little less hops (hence the 7 in flavour).  All in all, very good.

Rogues customer service is first rate. Unfortunately even the 6-pack they drop shipped to me was nearly as bad as the one I complained about. Avoid this unless you live in Rogues home town.
Solid, good head, lasting. Malty nose, light in a hop I dont recognize. Truly bizarre flavors, like nothing Ive ever put in my mouth...lacquered roast duck?

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2004 Not much aroma to speak of; faintly fruity.  Pleasant hazy light amber-orange color.  Interesting but very tasty malt choice.  (Northwest Harrington, Klages, Maier Munich and Carastan malts, along with Perle and Saaz Hops, according to the website.  The Saaz spiciness is definitely there!)  This is apparently a Maibock...that being the case, this is one of the more unique Maibocks Ive had.  Quite satisfying on a cool spring day such as today.  Just the right amount of carbonation.  Ive had this beer numerous times, and will again.
kind of a strangely-bitter taste that lingers on your tongue.  I liked the appearance and the aroma better than the actual taste.  Only other Rogue ive had is Artisan Lager.  This isnt close.
damn weird tasting, drank way too much and got a killer hangover..... cool bottle though
uniform amber colour; nice, tight bubbles; good aftertaste leaves you wanting more

Ive tried 4 of the Rogue beers.  Though they start out great, personally I dont think they have a good finish.  Which is true for this one also.  First sip had a nice hoppy taste and aroma, went down smooth, about 3/4 through the bottle I felt it lost its taste and fizz.
A friend bought some of this just after his grandpas funeral. I thought it was a classy touch, and a good beer.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2003 Draught:  Pours a reddish brown.  Not much head to the beer.  Both the aroma and taste are very complex.  There are a great deal of malts and hops in this beer, but neither are overwhelming, but there is a good hop kick in the end.  Extremely well balanced.  This one would get the Mayan's to come back from the dead!

According to their website this beer is a Maibock in style. I guess I can see that.  I just dont think its quite malty enough to really qualify.  This is a good beer, but if its a true Maibock its not an ALE.  But Im being too nit-picky.  Anyway...very drinkable beer.  A little more copper colored than most Maibocks Ive seen.  And the hops seem a touch too apparent.  This is another example of a great beer with an improper lable in my ever so humble opinion.
I tried this randomly at Ashleys in Ann Arbor, MI and was instantly impressed.  Great color and a great all around ale.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2009 from Amstein - cloudy reddish-orange colour under a nice persistent beige foam; beautiful lace; aroma of orange peel and mango with a touch of yeast; smooth palate and quite sweet, medium-bodied; finishes bitter/sour with long fruity notes - balanced and well-brewed

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2005 Nice head and great, reddish-brown color. Very spicy; reminds me of Old Peculiar in a way (has a pinch of cinnamon-like sweetness). Quite an interesting brew, and fairly easy to drink (albeit a bit sticky). Chewy and wholesome caramel exudes throughout. Decent amount of bitterness follows through; kind of orangey, flowery and earthy. Maybe even a little peaty. Pretty good beer to throw back.

Very nice brown color.   Small head forms - doesnt last long.
Nutty aroma - very nice.  Hoppiness apparent as soon as it hits the tongue - becoming
sharper and more bitter as you swallow.  An unexpected flavor.
Mellows some as you finish the bottle.  Maltiness slow becomes more apparent, an interesting trait.  A nice easy drinking ale - a real treat from Rogue (as always....do they make a *bad* beer?).
Not what I expected from Rogue.  Weak flavor overall, with almost a watery taste.  Theres much better stuff from Rogue.
